0,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Transport properties of nonlinear non-equilibrium dynamical systems are not well-understood

column2: ‚Ä¢ Ratchet systems are asymmetric periodic potentials where particles experience directed transport

column1: ‚Ä¢ Chaotic deterministic ratchets have complicated phase-space structure that changes with parameters

column2: ‚Ä¢ Transport properties can change dramatically, such as current reversals

column1: ‚Ä¢ Mateos conjectured current reversal is correlated with bifurcation from chaotic to periodic behavior

column2: ‚Ä¢ Later studies by Barbi and Salerno argued this is not always valid

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors study current properties in the same chaotic ratchet system

column2: ‚Ä¢ They consider the impact of different particle ensembles and show current depends on initial ensemble

column1: ‚Ä¢ Bifurcations for individual trajectories seem associated with abrupt changes in current

column2: ‚Ä¢ Changes may lead to current reversal depending on the specific current value

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors compare bifurcation diagrams with current behavior

column2: ‚Ä¢ They find current reversals can occur without bifurcations, and vice versa

column1: ‚Ä¢ A generalized heuristic is proposed: bifurcations correspond to sudden current changes (spikes/jumps)

column2: ‚Ä¢ Current reversals are a special case of this when the change goes through zero

column1: ‚Ä¢ Open questions remain about when the heuristic rules are violated or valid

column2: ‚Ä¢ Further work is needed to make the reasons more concrete

1,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 1 level of sub-points:
<summary>
* Many extrasolar planets have moderate to high eccentricities, unlike our solar system

column2: * Planet-planet scattering and interactions with stellar companions are possible explanations

column1: * Six highly eccentric extrasolar planetary systems were studied: HD 3651, HD 37605, HD 45350, HD 80606, HD 89744, and 16 Cyg B

column2: * Each hosts a planet with e > 0.6 and was observed by planet search programs at McDonald Observatory

column1: * Updated Keplerian orbital solutions were obtained for HD 3651b, HD 37605b, HD 80606b, and HD 89744b

column2: * No evidence was found for additional objects in any of the six systems

column1: * Test particle simulations were performed to investigate regions where additional low-mass planets could remain stable

column2: * Surviving test particles were found in protected resonances for HD 3651 and HD 37605

column1: * Limits on additional planets were computed using the radial velocity data

column2: * Planets with masses above the limits can be ruled out with 99% confidence

column1: * The best limits were obtained for HD 3651, HD 45350, and 16 Cyg B

column2: * Planets of a few Neptune masses can be excluded in dynamically stable regions for these systems

column1: * Poor limits were obtained for HD 37605, HD 80606, and HD 89744

column2: * Factors include poor phase coverage, short time baselines, and intrinsic scatter in the data

column1: * Combining dynamical simulations with observational limits is particularly effective

column2: * This approach constrains both the presence and location of additional planets

column1: * Further observations and simulations can place tighter constraints on planetary system architectures

column2: * Higher precision measurements and longer time baselines will continue to improve detection limits

column1: 4,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Colliding plane waves (CPW) result in spacelike singularities, but cross polarization or electromagnetic (EM) fields can weaken the singularities
* The Chandrasekhar-Xanthopoulos (CX) solution has a Cauchy horizon (CH) instead of a spacelike singularity
* Yurtsever and CX showed the CH formed in CPW spacetimes is unstable against perturbations
* EM fields coupled to gravity result in weaker singularities compared to pure gravitational waves
* The Bell-Szekeres (BS) solution describes the collision of two linearly polarized step EM waves
* The singularity in the interaction region of the BS solution is a removable CH
* The cross-polarized version of the BS (CPBS) solution has regular Weyl scalars in the interaction region
* The CPBS solution is used to test the validity of the Helliwell-Konkowski (HK) CH stability conjecture
* Test fields are added to the CPBS background to study the stability of quasi-regular (QR) singularities
* Test EM fields predict the QR singularities are unstable and transform into non-scalar curvature singularities
* Test scalar fields also predict the QR singularities are unstable and transform into scalar curvature singularities
* Exact back-reaction solutions are presented for the collision of cross-polarized EM fields coupled with scalar fields
* The stability of QR singularities in the CPBS spacetime is analyzed using test EM fields, scalar fields, and null dust
* Test EM fields indicate the QR singularities become non-scalar curvature singularities
* Test scalar fields predict the QR singularities transform into scalar curvature singularities, confirmed by an exact back-reaction solution
* Test null dust results in the CH becoming a scalar curvature singularity, as predicted by the conjecture and confirmed by an exact back-reaction solution
* The paper concludes that the HK stability conjecture correctly predicts the instability of QR",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 6,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Quantum systems can exhibit non-classical correlations, with degrees of non-classicality:

column2: * Non-separable or entangled states cannot be expressed as a mixture of product states
* Bell-nonlocal states violate a Bell inequality and local causality

column1: * EPR-steering lies between entanglement and Bell-nonlocality:

column2: * Allows verification of entanglement when one party or their detectors are untrusted
* Characterized by the inability to construct a local hidden state model

column1: * The authors investigate EPR-steerability of two-qubit states with maximally mixed marginals (T-states):

column2: * Use the steering ellipsoid formalism to develop a deterministic local hidden state model
* Conjecture that this model is optimal for T-states

column1: * Two sufficient conditions for T-states to be EPR-steerable are obtained:

column2: * Via suitable EPR-steering inequalities
* These conditions are close to the necessary condition in some regions

column1: * The authors discuss the three notions of non-locality in detail:

column2: * Bell-nonlocality, EPR-steerability, and non-separability
* Logical hierarchy of the three concepts leads to a hierarchy for bipartite states

column1: * Properties of the quantum steering ellipsoid for a two-qubit state are introduced:

column2: * Surface of the ellipsoid represents the set of steered states
* Volume of the ellipsoid is bounded for separable states

column1: * The authors develop a deterministic local hidden state model for projective measurements on T-states:

column2: * Motivated by the steering ellipsoid formalism
* Provides a strong necessary condition for EPR-steerability of T-states

7,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The visionary who first thought of using electron spin to encode binary information is unknown

column2: ‚Ä¢ Feynman may have mentioned the idea circa 1985
‚Ä¢ Concrete schemes for spintronic logic gates emerged in the mid-1990s

column1: ‚Ä¢ Encoding information in spin has potential advantages over charge

column2: ‚Ä¢ Possibility of lower power dissipation when switching logic gates
‚Ä¢ Spin is less susceptible to noise from stray electric fields

column1: ‚Ä¢ In 1994, a scheme was proposed for a spintronic NAND gate using 3 spins in quantum dots

column2: ‚Ä¢ Spin orientation becomes a binary variable in a weak magnetic field
‚Ä¢ Anti-ferromagnetic ordering between neighboring spins is assumed

column1: ‚Ä¢ The proposed spintronic logic gates have a serious shortcoming

column2: ‚Ä¢ Exchange interaction is bidirectional and cannot ensure unidirectional logic signal flow
‚Ä¢ This prevents their use in pipelined architectures

column1: ‚Ä¢ Clocking was proposed as a solution to enforce unidirectionality

column2: ‚Ä¢ A multi-phase clock is required, with two adjacent barriers lowered pairwise
‚Ä¢ Clocking negates the energy efficiency advantage of spintronic devices

column1: ‚Ä¢ Minimum energy dissipation in irreversible spintronic logic gates exceeds current chips

column2: ‚Ä¢ Assumes quantum dot density of 10^11 cm^-2 and 1 psec spin flip time
‚Ä¢ Heat sinking this level of power dissipation is a major challenge

column1: ‚Ä¢ Reversible logic gates that are not constrained by the Landauer kT ln(2) limit are needed

column2: ‚Ä¢ In 1996, a logically and physically reversible quantum inverter was devised
‚Ä¢ Later, a universal quantum gate using exchange coupled spins was proposed

column1: ‚Ä¢ Spin is the preferred vehicle to encode qubits in solids due to longer coherence times

column2: ‚Ä¢ Electron spin coherence times of 100 nsec in GaAs at 5 K have been reported
‚Ä¢ Nuclear spins in silicon are expected to have even longer coherence times

column1: ‚Ä¢ All-optical quantum computing using spin qubits has emerged as a viable approach

column2: ‚Ä¢ Avoids the difficulty of electrical readout of single spins",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 8,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Cataclysmic variables (CVs) are short-period binaries with a white dwarf primary and low mass main sequence secondary

‚Ä¢ Theoretical models have been unable to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cut-off
‚Ä¢ An accumulation of systems is expected at the minimum period, but no such spike is observed

column2: ‚Ä¢ Magnetic pressure inside the star could cause a larger deformation factor

‚Ä¢ The combined magnetic and non-magnetic distribution is tested against the models
‚Ä¢ A flat distribution is used as a benchmark for the models

column1: ‚Ä¢ King, Schenker & Hameury (2002) constructed a nearly flat period distribution by superimposing individual idealized PDFs

column2: ‚Ä¢ The authors apply this weighting to their non-idealized model PDFs involving CAML efficiency and deformation factor
‚Ä¢ The weighting produced a marginally",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 9,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 4 sub-points each:
<summary>
* Stephan's Quintet (SQ) exhibits a large-scale intergalactic shock-wave

column2: * Shock produced by high-velocity collision of NGC 7318b with intergalactic medium
* Powerful H2 line emission discovered in the shock, exceeding X-ray luminosity
* H2 forms in denser clouds experiencing slower shocks
* Coexistence of hot X-ray gas and cooler molecular material due to multiphase medium

column1: * H2 is the dominant line coolant in the mid-infrared

column2: * H2 emission extends over 35 kpc2 with luminosity > 1042 erg/s
* Global L(H2)/LX-ray ratio > 3 in main shock and ""bridge"" feature
* Modifies traditional view of X-rays dominating cooling in late-stage compact group evolution
* Dust emission associated with H2 regions, but low intensity radiation field

column1: * Infrared ionic lines interpreted as fast (100-300 km/s) ionizing shocks

column2: * Ne, Si, and Fe line ratios imply Si and Fe depletion onto dust
* Dust not destroyed in the shock
* Projected coexistence of SiII and H2 produced by 200 km/s and 20 km/s shocks
* Consistent with model of multiphase postshock medium from galaxy-wide collision

column1: * Star formation in SQ dominated by SQ-A and 7318b-south at ends of radio shock ridge

column2: * Suggests both are shock triggered starbursts
* H2-dominated regions exhibit very low star formation rates
* Consistent with turbulent model where H2 is reheated and cool clouds too short-lived to collapse
* Requires inventory of lines and continuum at all wavelengths to determine dominant cooling

column1: * SQ provides ideal laboratory for probing H2 cooling mechanism

column2: * Potentially crucial in systems from ULIRGs to radio galaxies to supernova remnants
* Contributions from other lines (e.g. OI, CII) and UV",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 10,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The short-lived radioisotope (SLRI) 26Al was injected into the early solar nebula, potentially reducing its usefulness as a chronometer

column2: * Previous models showed initial spatial isotopic heterogeneity can be reduced in a marginally gravitationally unstable (MGU) disk
* Stable oxygen isotopes appear to have been spatially heterogeneous in the early solar nebula
* MGU disks can accomplish early large-scale transport of small particles
* MGU disks are likely involved in FU Orionis outbursts and offer an alternative mechanism for gas giant planet formation

column1: * The numerical models presented examine the evolution of isotopic heterogeneity in MGU disks around protostars of various masses

column2: * The models use a 3D gravitational hydrodynamics code with radiative transfer and a color field to trace isotopes
* Initial disk masses range from 0.1 to 1.0 solar masses, with outer radii of 10 or 40 AU
* Single-shot or continuous injection of the color field is used to represent isotopic heterogeneity
* The dispersion of the color field about its mean radial value over time is analyzed

column1: * Results show that MGU disks can rapidly homogenize initially heterogeneous distributions

column2: * Mixing occurs on timescales of hundreds to thousands of years, depending on disk size and protostar mass
* Single-shot injection leads to greater homogenization than continuous injection
* Disk evolution is the primary factor determining the radial dispersion profile
* Some refractory grains are transported outward to the outer disk regions

column1: * MGU disk mixing appears to be robust across a range of stellar masses, disk masses, and temperatures

column2: * Mixing can explain the homogeneity of 26Al/27Al ratios and the range of 16O/17O ratios in the solar nebula
* MGU disks may drive FU Orionis outbursts and explain refractory grains found in comet 81P/Wild 2
* Similar mixing processes likely occur in disks around low-mass stars, from G dwarfs to",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

13,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points with 1 level of sub-points:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The spectra of type 1 AGN show diverse broad and narrow emission lines that provide insights into the structure and kinematics of gas near the central black hole

column2: ‚Ä¢ Two populations of type 1 AGN are identified based on the FWHM of the HŒ≤ line: population A (FWHM 1000-4000 km/s) and population B (FWHM 4000-12000 km/s)

column1: ‚Ä¢ FeII emission is ubiquitous in type 1 quasars and is thought to arise from the same region as other low ionization lines like HŒ≤

column2: ‚Ä¢ A recent study by Hu et al. (2008) claimed a systematic redshift of FeII emission relative to [OIII] in most type 1 quasars, with the redshift amplitude inversely correlating with Eddington ratio

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors tested this claim using composite spectra of bright SDSS quasars binned by HŒ≤ FWHM and FeII strength, finding no significant FeII redshift relative to HŒ≤ or [OIII]

column2: ‚Ä¢ Fits to composites generated from the Hu et al. (2008) sample also do not confirm the large claimed FeII redshifts, with only small possible redshifts of <300 km/s for population A sources

column1: ‚Ä¢ The discrepancy is likely due to the lower S/N of the Hu et al. spectra and their omission of HeII Œª4686 emission in the fits, which can mimic an apparent redshift of the FeII blue blend

column2: ‚Ä¢ Careful analysis of high S/N spectra is needed to reliably detect small systematic FeII shifts, but large shifts are not confirmed

column1: ‚Ä¢ The results challenge the idea that FeII emission arises from a dynamically distinct region from HŒ≤ and the use of FeII shifts as an orientation indicator

column2: ‚Ä¢ Small systematic FeII shifts are possible but can only be analyzed reliably in high S/N spectra

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
14,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column2: * Experiments by ALADIN, EOS, and INDRA groups yielded slightly different caloric curves
* Discrepancies attributed to precision of measurements and finite-size effects
* Accurate theoretical descriptions needed to distinguish equilibrium and nonequilibrium parts of excitation energies

column1: * Improvements to the sharp microcanonical multifragmentation model

column2: * Refinements to the primary break-up stage, such as using experimental discrete energy levels for fragments with A‚â§4
* Inclusion of the secondary decay stage via sequential evaporation for A>4 nuclei and secondary break-up for highly excited fragments
* Wigner-Seitz approach used for Coulomb interaction energy in the microcanonical weight formulas

column1: * Reevaluation of caloric curves and heat capacities using the improved model

column2: * Caloric curves for two freeze-out radii exhibit liquid-like, plateau-like, and gas-like regions
* Sharp maxima in heat capacity curves indicate phase transition regions
* Simultaneous fit of calculated <M_IMF> and <Zasy> curves to experimental data used to determine equilibrated source sequence [A,E*]

column1: * Comparison of calculated and experimental helium isotopic temperature curves

column2: * Excellent agreement between calculated T_HeLi and experimental data from Au+Au reactions at 600 and 1000 MeV/nucleon

15,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The solar corona is heated to much higher temperatures than the sun's surface, likely due to magnetic fields or waves

column2: * The energy source is believed to be in the convection zone below the photosphere

column1: * There is debate over whether the heating is caused by dissipation of MHD waves or small-scale magnetic reconnection events (nanoflares)

column2: * Theoretical arguments exist for both mechanisms, but observational evidence for nanoflares is less convincing

column1: * High-frequency MHD waves (>1 Hz) are thought to be capable of significant coronal heating

column2: * Observations of these waves have been made using the Fe XIV green line and Fe X red line, with contradictory results

column1: * The authors describe a setup to search for high-frequency coronal oscillations using the SECIS instrument and a coronagraph at Lomnicky Peak Observatory

column2: * The system consists of the coronagraph, SECIS (two fast-frame CCD cameras), and an opto-mechanical interface

column1: * The optical system was designed to avoid vignetting, limit aberrations, and ensure equal exposure times in narrow-band and broad-band channels

column2: * The system is mounted in a rigid, light-tight box and requires minimal alignment at the telescope

column1: * SECIS has been successfully used during total solar eclipses and for high time resolution spectral observations of solar flares

column2: * Preliminary tests of the entire system were performed in April 2009, but no prominent coronal structures were detectable due to low solar activity

column1: * Tests of the narrow-band filters showed that they require heating to tune the passband to the green line wavelength

column2: * The filter characteristics (transmission, passband width, and central wavelength) vary slightly with radial distance

column1: * Test observations confirmed the good optical and photometric quality of the data, with low noise levels and instrumental scattered light

column2: * The setup is ready to measure prominent active region coronal loops when they appear under favorable conditions

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
16,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column1: 30,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs

column2: ‚Ä¢ Vertices with enough chips ""fire"" one chip to each neighbor simultaneously
‚Ä¢ The game has a finite number of positions that eventually repeat
‚Ä¢ It has connections to number theory, algebra, combinatorics, and physics
‚Ä¢ It can simulate logic gates and solve computational problems

column1: ‚Ä¢ Lemmas are established bounding the number of chips and defining complement positions

column2: ‚Ä¢ In games with nontrivial period, vertices have at most 2n-1 chips
‚Ä¢ Confined positions have vertices with chips in a specific range
‚Ä¢ The complement of a confined position has the same firing behavior
‚Ä¢ A period occurs iff each vertex has fired the same number of times

column1: ‚Ä¢ For complete bipartite graphs, the only possible periods are 1, 2, t, or 2t

column2: ‚Ä¢ t is the number of vertices on the side with fewer vertices
‚Ä¢ Lemmas relate the number of times vertices on each side have fired
‚Ä¢ Specific initial positions are constructed with periods t and 2t
‚Ä¢ Combined with previous results, this characterizes all possible periods

column1: ‚Ä¢ For complete k-partite graphs, positions with period k(t-1)+1 are constructed

column2: ‚Ä¢ t ranges from 1 to the number of vertices in the smallest part
‚Ä¢ Each vertex fires when it has at least as many chips as its degree
‚Ä¢ After k(t-1)+1 steps, each vertex has fired exactly once
‚Ä¢ This shows periods from k to the number of vertices are achievable

column1: ‚Ä¢ Further research directions are proposed

column2: ‚Ä¢ Proving the period is at most the number of vertices for certain graphs
‚Ä¢ Relating period lengths to attributes like activity or subcycle lengths
‚Ä¢ Studying transient lengths and reduced parallel chip-firing games
‚Ä¢ Applying the game to model real-world phenomena like sandpiles

33,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ A choice of nonconstant meromorphic function on a compact Riemann surface realizes it as a finite sheeted branched covering of the Riemann sphere

column2: ‚Ä¢ Log-Riemann surfaces are branched coverings of the Riemann sphere by a punctured compact Riemann surface given by transcendental functions of infinite degree

column1: ‚Ä¢ Log-Riemann surfaces of finite type are given by a compact Riemann surface and a meromorphic function on the punctured surface such that the differential has exponential singularities at the punctures

column2: ‚Ä¢ Spaces of functions and 1-forms with exponential singularities on log-Riemann surfaces give rise to a de Rham cohomology group

column1: ‚Ä¢ An exp-algebraic curve consists of a compact Riemann surface together with equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions modulo holomorphic functions at punctures

column2: ‚Ä¢ Spaces of functions and 1-forms with exponential singularities can be defined on exp-algebraic curves

column1: ‚Ä¢ A degree zero line bundle with a meromorphic connection can be naturally associated to an exp-algebraic curve

column2: ‚Ä¢ The connection 1-form near the punctures determines the exp-algebraic curve

column1: ‚Ä¢ A Torelli-type theorem states that an exp-algebraic curve is determined by the pair of the degree zero line bundle and the image of the homology in the dual of the de Rham cohomology group

column2: ‚Ä¢ The proof uses approximation and exact 1-form theorems

column1: ‚Ä¢ Functions with exponential singularities, such as Baker-Akhiezer functions, have been used in the algebro-geometric integration of integrable systems

column2: ‚Ä¢ They have also been studied in the context of the Weierstrass problem and entire functions satisfying certain topological conditions

column1: ‚Ä¢ Log-Riemann surfaces and exp-algebraic curves are defined and their basic properties are recalled

column2: ‚Ä¢ Spaces of functions and 1-forms on log-Riemann surfaces and exp-algebraic curves are defined

column1: ‚Ä¢ A correspondence between exp-algebraic structures and degree zero line bundles with meromorphic connections is established

column1: 34,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column2: * Merging DMFT with local density approximation (LDA) is promising due to simplicity and correctness in band and atomic limits
* Realistic DMFT simulations require fast scans of parameter space to determine interaction for given doping, degeneracy and bandwidth
* Present approaches based on non-crossing approximation (NCA) or iterative perturbation theory (IPT) are limited in applicable regimes

column1: * Interpolative approach proposed for self-energy in general multiorbital situation

column2: * Not an attempt to develop alternative impurity solver, but follow-up to LDA ideology

40,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is an important topological invariant

column2: ‚Ä¢ It can be used to distinguish between connected components of the moduli space of smooth projective surfaces
‚Ä¢ It can be used to compute fundamental groups of complements of hypersurfaces in projective space via the Zariski-Lefschetz theorem
‚Ä¢ It is useful for finding more examples of Zariski pairs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Fan defined a graph associated to multiple points of a line arrangement and proved results about the projective fundamental group

column2: ‚Ä¢ If the graph has no cycles, the fundamental group is a direct sum of free and infinite cyclic groups
‚Ä¢ Fan conjectured the converse is also true, which was recently proved by Eliyahu, Liberman, Schaps and Teicher
‚Ä¢ If the affine complement is a free group, the arrangement consists of parallel lines

column1: ‚Ä¢ The paper aims to study which line arrangements have a fundamental group with a conjugation-free geometric presentation

column2: ‚Ä¢ Such arrangements are important because the fundamental group can be read directly from the incidence lattice
‚Ä¢ The Ceva arrangement is the minimal arrangement whose fundamental group has no conjugation-free geometric presentation
‚Ä¢ The main result is that arrangements whose graph is a disjoint union of cycles with no line having more than two multiple points have a conjugation-free geometric presentation

column1: ‚Ä¢ The exact group structure is given for an arrangement whose graph is a triangle with all multiple points of multiplicity 3

column2: ‚Ä¢ It is a semidirect product of free groups
‚Ä¢ This family of arrangements is broader than the family of nice or simple arrangements where the lattice determines the fundamental group
‚Ä¢ The conjugation-free geometric presentations are complemented positive presentations in the sense of Dehornoy

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Moishezon-Teicher algorithm and van Kampen theorem are used to compute fundamental groups

column2: ‚Ä¢ A wiring diagram holds the combinatorial data of the arrangement
‚Ä¢ Lefschetz pairs correspond to intersection points
‚Ä¢ Skeletons are computed from the wiring diagram and Lefschetz pairs, giving relations in the fundamental group presentation

column1: ‚Ä¢ Results are proved for arrangements whose graphs are cycles of any length with no line having more than two multiple points

<summary>
‚Ä¢ Organic molecular crystals are promising for nanoscale devices, but the electronic structure of the organic-inorganic interface needs to be understood

column2: ‚Ä¢ Charge transfer between the organic and inorganic components is crucial
‚Ä¢ Image charge effects alter the addition and removal energies of charge carriers
‚Ä¢ Density functional theory (DFT) has limitations in describing these effects
‚Ä¢ Constrained DFT (CDFT) is a more efficient alternative to many-body approaches like GW

column1: ‚Ä¢ CDFT is used to study a benzene molecule adsorbed on graphene in various configurations

column2: ‚Ä¢ CDFT calculates charge transfer energies by constraining electrons to molecule or substrate
‚Ä¢ The molecule-substrate distance and size of the graphene unit cell affect the results
‚Ä¢ Converged charge transfer energies are obtained for sufficiently large unit cells
‚Ä¢ The HOMO-LUMO gap of benzene on graphene approaches the gas phase value at large distances

column1: ‚Ä¢ Structural defects in graphene, like Stone-Wales defects, have little effect on charge transfer energies

column2: ‚Ä¢ The defect does not significantly alter the graphene density of states near the Fermi level
‚Ä¢ The image charge distribution is not strongly affected by the presence of the defect
‚Ä¢ Doping graphene also has a minor effect on the charge transfer energies

column1: ‚Ä¢ The presence of neighboring benzene molecules reduces the charge transfer energies

column2: ‚Ä¢ Induced charge dipoles in nearby molecules lower the electrostatic potential
‚Ä¢ The effect is more pronounced for the molecule than the graphene substrate
‚Ä¢ The reduction in HOMO-LUMO gap is similar regardless of the exact positions of other molecules

column1: ‚Ä¢ The CDFT results agree well with a classical electrostatic model accounting for graphene's dielectric response

‚Ä¢ The level renormalization on graphene differs from that on a perfect metal due to screening

43,"Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The authors studied critical Casimir forces (CCFs) between two spherical colloids immersed in a near-critical binary liquid mixture near a substrate

column2: * CCFs are characterized by universal scaling functions that depend on boundary conditions, geometry, and thermodynamic state
* Mean-field theory and finite element methods were used to calculate order parameter profiles and CCFs
* Both normal and lateral CCFs were analyzed for various boundary conditions, distances, and temperatures
* Many-body effects were quantified by subtracting pairwise colloid-colloid and colloid-substrate forces from the total force

column1: * Results were compared to quantum-electrodynamic Casimir interactions and van der Waals forces

column2: * Lateral many-body CCFs are always attractive regardless of boundary conditions, unlike in the quantum case
* Many-body contributions to normal CCFs decay slower with distance than for van der Waals forces between atoms near a surface
* Many-body van der Waals forces are repulsive while many-body CCFs are attractive
* For vertically-aligned colloids, many-body normal CCFs depend on the boundary conditions

column1: * The preferred arrangement of the colloids depends on boundary conditions

column2: * For symmetric boundary conditions, colloids tend to aggregate laterally and form a monolayer on the substrate
* For asymmetric boundary conditions, colloids tend to aggregate vertically and form 3D clusters
* These tendencies are enhanced near the critical point
* No completely stable configuration was found - there is always a nonzero force in the normal or lateral direction

45,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column2: * A wave function parametrized by relevant factors is introduced to deal with resonance shifts

* The wave function incorporated into an atomic clock's operation can never be unconditionally known

column1: * Quantum theory reflects a distinction between explanation (wave functions and operators) and evidence (probabilities of outcomes)

column2: * Choosing a wave function to explain evidence requires reaching beyond logic based on that evidence
* Evidence acquired after the choice is made can call for revising the chosen wave function
* Not even probabilities of future evidence can be unconditionally foreseen due to the unknowability of wave functions

column1: * Clocks generating UTC are steered toward aiming points depending on a chosen wave function and hypothesized metric tensor field

column2: * Like the wave function, the metric tensor hypothesis is constrained but not determined by measured data
* Guesses enter clock operations through the computational machinery that steers them
* Writing and reading of records with separation is needed in the computational machinery to avoid logical short circuits

column1: * Open machines, which are Turing machines modified to be stepped by a clock and communicate with other devices, are used to model the logic of computers in feedback loops

column2: * Open machines can receive unforeseeable inputs and write commands to external devices
* Calculations on open machines respond to received influences and proceed by moves made according to modifiable rules
* The wider physical world shows up in an open machine as unforeseeable messages and commands to external devices

column1: * Logical synchronization, where a symbol arrives within the writing phase of the receiving machine's cycle, is necessary for logical communication

column2: * Phasing of a computer's receiver is commonly detached from the computer's timing by buffering
* Character-by-character phase meshing without buffering offers the most direct communication possible
* Logical synchronization gives rise to questions about aiming point patterns, steering to approach aiming points, and responding to deviations

47,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* MOPED is an algorithm for compressing data and speeding up likelihood function evaluation

column2: * It is particularly useful when the noise covariance matrix depends on model parameters
* It compresses N data points into m values, one for each model parameter
* It can provide orders of magnitude speed improvement in some cases

column1: * MOPED has limitations and does not always accurately represent the likelihood function

column2: * It only guarantees maintaining the Fisher matrix at a chosen point
* Multimodal and some degenerate distributions can be problematic
* The authors demonstrate cases where MOPED fails to capture the true likelihood

column1: * The validity of MOPED's likelihood representation depends on the intersections of hyper-surfaces where compressed values equal those at the true peak

column2: * A single intersection indicates MOPED is reliable
* Multiple intersections mean MOPED may create erroneous peaks
* Original likelihood must be checked to determine if multiple peaks are real or artifacts

column1: * Potential solutions to MOPED's limitations are presented

column2: * Comparing original likelihoods of MOPED peak values can identify true peaks
* Averaging log-likelihoods across multiple fiducial models maintains true peaks
* However, this can significantly increase the SNR threshold for signal recovery

52,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The rotation curves (RCs) of dwarf galaxies can be used to investigate the nature of dark matter (DM) and test cold dark matter (CDM) models

column2: * The Orion dwarf galaxy is an ideal candidate for this analysis due to its extended HI disk and reliable measurements of gas kinematics
* Previous studies have shown that dwarf galaxy RCs are better fitted by cored DM profiles than cuspy profiles predicted by CDM simulations
* MOND (Modified Newtonian Dynamics) has been successful in reproducing RCs of spiral galaxies without DM, but some cases of tension exist

column1: * The stellar and gas components of the Orion dwarf were modeled using near-infrared photometry and HI observations

column2: * The stellar surface brightness profile is well-fitted by an exponential disk with no prominent bulge
* The HI disk shows well-ordered rotation with some non-circular motions in the inner regions
* The RC was derived using a tilted-ring model and corrected for asymmetric drift

column1: * Mass modeling of the Orion dwarf was performed using both cored and cuspy DM halo profiles

column2: * The cored halo (URCH profile) provides an excellent fit to the observed RC

<summary>
* Transverse spin fluctuations are important low-energy excitations in magnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry

column2: * They significantly reduce the zero-temperature AF order parameter and N√©el temperature

column1: * A new method is described for evaluating transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections in the AF ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model

column2: * The method is based on magnon mode energies and spectral functions obtained in the random phase approximation (RPA)

column1: * The method is illustrated for the pure Hubbard model in 2D and 3D, spin vacancies in the strong coupling limit in 2D, and low-U impurities in 2D

column2: * Results properly interpolate between weak and strong coupling limits, approaching spin-wave theory results as U/t ‚Üí ‚àû

column1: * For the spin vacancy problem, the quantum spin-fluctuation correction is sharply enhanced with increasing vacancy concentration

column2: * The AF order parameter vanishes near the percolation threshold due to spin fluctuations

column1: * For the low-U impurity model, the spin-fluctuation correction is suppressed on average by the impurities

column2: * However, the correction is enhanced locally at the low-U impurity sites

column1: * The local enhancement is due to increased magnon amplitude on the more strongly coupled impurity sites

column2: * The overall decrease is due to stiffening of the low-energy magnon spectrum from the increased average spin coupling

column1: * The highest magnon energy is substantially reduced compared to the localized spin picture

column2: * This shows the compression effect of the low charge gap on the magnon spectrum

column1: * The method allows for exact treatment of defects at the RPA level using numerical diagonalization for finite lattices with finite-size scaling

59,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Dipole moments of elementary particles have provided valuable information on subatomic physics over the past 83 years

column2: * Pioneering work by Stern and the discovery of anomalous magnetic moments of proton and neutron laid the groundwork for spin, QED, and QCD
* Charged particles with spin 1/2 have a magnetic moment related to the gyromagnetic ratio and anomaly

column1: * The anomaly arises from radiative corrections, with QED contributions calculated through eighth order for electron and muon

column2: * Electron anomaly is measured to a relative precision of about 4 parts per billion, better than the precision on the fine-structure constant
* Muon anomaly is measured to 0.5 parts per million, with sensitivity to higher mass scale radiative corrections

column1: * The Standard Model value of the muon anomaly has contributions from QED loops, hadronic loops, and weak loops

column2: * A significant difference between the experimental and Standard Model values would signify the presence of new physics
* Hadronic contribution is determined using dispersion theory and experimental data on e+e- annihilation cross-section

column1: * Measurements of the muon anomaly have placed restrictions on physics beyond the Standard Model, particularly supersymmetric theories

column2: * SUSY contributions to the muon anomaly could be at a measurable level in a broad range of models
* There is complementarity between SUSY contributions to the magnetic dipole moment (MDM), electric dipole moment (EDM), and lepton-flavor violating processes

column1: * The Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) experiment E821 measured the muon anomaly using a precision measurement of the muon spin precession frequency and the magnetic field

column2: * The experimental signal is the decay positron from muon decay, with the highest energy positrons correlated with the muon spin
* Systematic errors were reduced with each data set, reaching a total error of 0.54 ppm in the final measurement

column1: * The BNL E821 result shows a 2.7 to 2.9 standard deviation discrepancy with the Standard Model value, depending on the analysis of the hadronic contribution

69,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The glass transition remains a largely unresolved problem in statistical physics

column2: * It is associated with a sharp increase in relaxation times and departure from equilibrium
* Some propose it is triggered by an underlying thermodynamic transition at the Kauzmann temperature
* Others argue there is no evidence of a thermodynamic transition based on simulations

column1: * Mode-coupling theory (MCT) attempts to connect the glass transition to a rapid increase in relaxation times near a critical temperature

column2: * In its idealized version, MCT predicts a transition at a critical temperature Tc
* The full MCT shows no sharp transition at Tc but predicts all correlations decay in a final process
* Tc can be estimated from the approach of the undercooled melt or temperature dependence of certain parameters

column1: * This study investigates a molecular dynamics (MD) simulation model of the glass-forming Ni80Zr20 alloy

column2: * The model uses a volume-dependent electron-gas term and pair potentials adapted to ab initio potentials
* Simulations involve heating, cooling, relaxation, and modeling the time evolution of the system
* The study focuses on determining Tc from the nonergodicity parameter, Œª-parameter, and diffusion coefficients

column1: * The central objects of MCT are the partial intermediate scattering functions

column2: * These are Fourier components of the microscopic density fluctuations
* MCT predicts the long-time limit of these functions, called the nonergodicity parameters
* The nonergodicity parameters indicate if the system is in a liquid or arrested state

column1: * Beyond MCT, the memory function can be evaluated from MD simulations

column2: * This allows characterizing the undercooled melt and its transition to the glassy state
* The Œª-parameter measures how much the system has approached the arrested state
* The temperature dependence of Œª indicates how the system approaches the arrested state

column1: * The partial structure factors and pair correlation functions show weak temperature dependence

column2: * The incoherent scattering functions show a three-step structural relaxation as predicted by MCT
* Aging effects are observed at lower temperatures, indicating non-steady state",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 71,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

* Quantum electrodynamics predicts that quantum fluctuations of electric and magnetic fields give rise to a zero-point energy that causes two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum to attract each other (the Casimir effect)
* The force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions can be derived using Lifshitz's theory
* Two plates made of the same material always attract, while plates of different materials in a properly chosen liquid can repel each other

* Parsegian, Weiss, and Barash derived equations for the interaction energy and torque between two dielectrically anisotropic plates, showing that a torque develops causing the plates to rotate towards an aligned configuration
* The authors calculate the magnitude of the torque induced by quantum fluctuations for a small birefringent disk placed parallel to a birefringent barium titanate plate in vacuum
* The torque is within the sensitivity of available instrumentation if the plate and disk are kept at sub-micron distances

* To avoid sticking, the authors propose immersing the barium titanate plate in liquid ethanol with the disk placed on top, causing a repulsive van der Waals force to counterbalance the disk's weight and allow it to rotate freely
* Numerical calculations are performed to determine the torque as a function of the angle between the optical axes of the disk and plate, and the distance between them
* The torque varies sinusoidally with the angle, with maximum magnitude at 45¬∞ and 135¬∞, and is inversely proportional to the second power of distance in the non-retarded limit
* The sign of the torque depends on the dielectric properties of the materials; it is opposite for a quartz-barium titanate configuration compared to a calcite-barium titanate configuration
* The authors propose an experimental setup to demonstrate the rotation of the disk driven by quantum fluctuations
* A laser beam can initially rotate the disk, and then a shutter can block the beam to allow the disk to rotate back to its equilibrium position
* The disk's position can be monitored using a microscope objective coupled to a CCD camera

column1: * The authors develop a novel attempt to derive Markovian and non-Markovian master equations using stochastic methods

column2: * The main idea is to build random evolution operators containing the decohering effect of the environment
* Taking the stochastic expectation value with respect to this randomness yields the master equation

column1: * The authors prove that any Lindblad-type master equation with self-adjoint Lindblad operators can be understood as an averaged random unitary evolution

column2: * This allows for a fast method to solve master equations if the unitary solutions are known

column1: * The flexibility of the mathematical language can generalize intrinsic decoherence models

98,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

* Cosmic rays are high-energy particles arriving at Earth from space

column2: * Discovered in early 20th century as a source of natural radiation

* Composition studies are crucial for understanding the cosmic ray puzzle

column1: * Conventional models propose cosmic rays are accelerated in astrophysical objects

column2: * Few known objects are capable of accelerating particles to highest energies
* Difficulties explaining observed spectrum and lack of strong anisotropy
* Heavy nuclei can be accelerated to higher energies than protons
* Accelerated protons may interact to produce pions, neutrinos, and photons

column1: * Alternative models propose cosmic rays are decay products of massive particles

column2: * Typically predict a composition dominated by photons and neutrinos
* Relative fluxes of photons, neutrinos, and nucleons depend on source distribution
* Sources clustered in galactic halo could explain absence of GZK cutoff
* Photon to nucleon ratio sensitive to source clustering

column1: * Inclined air showers can be used to study cosmic ray composition

column2: * Muon density patterns in inclined showers affected by Earth's magnetic field
* Models of muon distributions enable analysis of inclined shower data
* Study of Haverah Park data disfavors photons, favors protons or heavy nuclei
* Inclined shower analysis doubles acceptance and probes composition

* A Lomb-Scargle periodogram confirmed the ~5.6 day period with a false alarm probability of 0.0009
* The observed super-orbital period is ~70% longer than predicted by the authors' previous 3D SPH simulations

column1: * The longer-than-expected super-orbital period suggests a lower donor-to-accretor mass ratio than originally assumed

* However, the accretor may be a particularly massive neutron star (‚â• 2 M‚òâ)

‚Ä¢ Measurement-device-independent QKD (MDIQKD) can be proven secure against eavesdropping, assuming users' devices satisfy certain requirements

column2: ‚Ä¢ Scheme I uses phase locking of two separate laser sources, while Scheme II converts phase encoding into polarization encoding

column1: ‚Ä¢ The security of the schemes is proven, taking into account basis-dependent flaws

column2: ‚Ä¢ Simulations are performed to evaluate the key generation rate based on realistic parameters

column1: ‚Ä¢ Scheme I can cover shorter distances and may require less accuracy in state preparation

column1: ‚Ä¢ The security proof assumes the most general type of attacks allowed by quantum mechanics

column2: ‚Ä¢ It does not rely on any assumptions about the measurement device, which can be fully controlled by an eavesdropper

column1: ‚Ä¢ The fidelity between the density matrices in the two bases is an important factor in the security

column2: ‚Ä¢ Imperfect phase modulation is considered as the main source of basis-dependent flaws

column1: ‚Ä¢ Simulations show that Scheme I is feasible with current technology, assuming precise intensity control

column2: ‚Ä¢ Scheme II requires very high fidelity in the single-photon components of the states

column1: ‚Ä¢ The degradation of the phase modulator accuracy significantly decreases the achievable distance of secure key generation

column2: ‚Ä¢ This highlights the importance of accurate state preparation in both MDIQKD and standard QKD

column2: ‚Ä¢ Conventional entanglement measures based on the density matrix are incomplete

column2: ‚Ä¢ At resonance, the system evolves into a Bell state or oscillates between two Bell states
‚Ä¢ These oscillations are hidden in the mixed state density matrix
‚Ä¢ Measurements on the environment can unravel the mixed state and create entanglement

column2: ‚Ä¢ The process generating the mixed state should be considered

column1: ‚Ä¢ Extensions of this work could consider other types of quantum trajectories

column2: ‚Ä¢ Only certain unravelings are physically realizable when environmental interactions cannot be measured

column1: 122,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Continuous-variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) is an unconditionally secure communication scheme that has achieved advanced improvements in recent years

column2: ‚Ä¢ Practical implementation systems have been demonstrated, but traditional security analysis does not include the local oscillator (LO)

column1: ‚Ä¢ LO intensity fluctuations can leave security loopholes for an eavesdropper (Eve) to exploit

column2: ‚Ä¢ The authors describe an attacking scheme exploiting LO intensity fluctuations and analyze its impact on the secret key rate

column1: ‚Ä¢ If Bob does not scale his measurements with the instantaneous LO intensity values, the secret keys can be severely compromised

column2: ‚Ä¢ Accurate monitoring of LO intensity is necessary to confirm the security of practical CVQKD implementation

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors analyze a practical CVQKD system with homodyne protocol under the LO intensity attack (LOIA)

column2: ‚Ä¢ They calculate the secret key rate with and without Bob monitoring the LO for reverse and direct reconciliation protocols

column1: ‚Ä¢ Reverse reconciliation is more sensitive to LO intensity fluctuations compared to direct reconciliation

column2: ‚Ä¢ Even with a small attenuation of LO intensity, Eve can obtain full secret keys without being detected in reverse reconciliation

column1: ‚Ä¢ Monitoring LO fluctuations carefully and scaling measurements with instantaneous LO intensity values is crucial in practical CVQKD implementation

column2: ‚Ä¢ Using the average LO intensity value to normalize measurements can lead to overestimation of the secret key rate

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors calculate the Holevo bound obtained by Eve for direct and reverse reconciliation using an entangling cloner model

column2: ‚Ä¢ Numerical demonstrations confirm that the entangling cloner can reach the Holevo bound against the optimal Gaussian collective attack

123,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Development of the adiabatic oscillation code ADIPLS

column2: ‚Ä¢ Goal was to have a simple and efficient tool for computing oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions
‚Ä¢ Offers flexibility in choice of integration method and ability to determine all frequencies in a given range
‚Ä¢ Uses a minimal set of dimensionless variables to define the equilibrium model
‚Ä¢ Extensive documentation is provided with the distribution package

column1: ‚Ä¢ Numerical techniques for solving the oscillation equations

column2: ‚Ä¢ Shooting method integrates solutions from inner and outer boundary, finds eigenvalue by matching at a fitting point
‚Ä¢ Relaxation technique solves equations with normalization condition and boundary conditions, finds eigenvalue by requiring continuity
‚Ä¢ High-order modes require special treatment, such as a change of variables near the center
‚Ä¢ Boundary conditions are obtained from series expansions or by matching to solutions in the atmosphere or vacuum

column1: ‚Ä¢ Improving the precision and accuracy of computed frequencies

‚Ä¢ Distinction between precision and accuracy is important, as computed frequencies may be precise but inaccurate if the model is not in hydrostatic equilibrium
‚Ä¢ Mesh redistribution techniques can be used to properly resolve eigenfunctions
‚Ä¢ Comparison between variational principle and Richardson extrapolation provides a measure of reliability

<summary>
* The presence of large HI supershells in some spiral galaxies is difficult to explain by conventional models involving either localized starbursts or infalling gas clouds.

column1: * A new model is proposed where radio jets from the galactic nucleus plow through the interstellar medium and inflate large bubbles of HI gas.

column2: * Numerical simulations show that jets can undergo rapid flaring and deposit large amounts of energy when crossing density discontinuities in the ISM.
* The mechanical luminosity of even a modest radio jet is sufficient to create the observed supershells over their estimated lifetimes.

column1: * The jet model can account for several key observed features of the HI supershells.

column2: * Symmetric pairs of supershells can be explained by bipolar jets.
* The lack of visible radio jets is expected if the active phase is short-lived compared to the supershell lifetime.
* Secondary effects like sporadic star formation in the galactic disk may be triggered when clumps of gas from the shells rain back down.

<summary>
* The paper studies the principal eigenvalue of the fractional Laplacian perturbed by a gradient operator with a divergence-free drift in a bounded domain

column2: * The main result shows the principal eigenvalue remains bounded as the drift strength goes to infinity if and only if there exist non-trivial first integrals of the drift vector field
* The proof uses the Green function, conditioning of nonlocal operators, and approximation techniques for flows
* The domains of the fractional Laplacian and perturbed operator are shown to coincide
* Compactness of the Green and transition operators is proved using Schur's test

* The upper bound is obtained by conditioning truncations of the first integral by the principal eigenfunction

142,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The phase-field method has become popular for simulating microstructure formation during solidification due to its simplicity, but some fundamental questions remain open

column2: * Thin-interface limit analysis shows current approaches cannot eliminate all finite interface thickness effects

column1: * Two independent thin-interface effects exist in the two-sided case: one proportional to interface velocity and one proportional to interface current

column2: * A general solution to eliminate both effects simultaneously does not exist yet

column1: * Orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification use an incorrect relaxation equation for the orientation field

column2: * The standard equation does not account for the connectivity of matter and geometrical conservation laws

column1: * Plastic deformation through dislocation motion provides a more consistent description of orientation field evolution

column2: * Developing a full evolution equation based on dislocation density is a difficult challenge

column1: * Including fluctuations in phase-field models using Langevin terms with amplitudes from the fluctuation-dissipation theorem is insufficient for quantitative nucleation simulations

column2: * Field equations are renormalized by strong fluctuations, modifying the free energy density

column1: * Renormalization effects depend on the discretization and an ultraviolet cutoff is required in the continuum picture

column2: * Adjusting model parameters to match renormalized quantities is challenging, especially for interfaces and critical nuclei

column1: * Orders of magnitude analysis suggests renormalization cannot be neglected when using the ""natural"" interface thickness in simulations

column2: * Larger interface thicknesses and coarser grids reduce fluctuation strength and renormalization effects

column1: * The sharp-interface limit concept needs reexamination when introducing a microscopic cutoff for fluctuations

column2: * Quantitative phase-field models with fluctuations require careful control of discretization effects and couplings between variables

column1: * Developing quantitative phase-field models for specific materials remains challenging despite the method's dual nature as a representation of condensed matter systems and an efficient simulation tool

column2: * Pursuing both viewpoints is likely to benefit the development of more efficient and robust models

column1: 147,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

column2: * The paper considers the tidal interaction between a star and a point source (another star or planet), taking into account the star's evolution

column2: * QSS model is used when short-term dynamics settle down after the contingency

163,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Heavy-fermion systems are characterized by a hierarchy of energy scales and competition between Kondo screening and RKKY interaction

column2: * Kondo screening entangles spins of conduction electrons and local moments, leading to a heavy Fermi liquid with large effective mass
* RKKY interaction indirectly couples local moments via conduction electrons, favoring magnetically ordered states
* Quantum phase transitions between paramagnetic heavy-fermion and magnetically ordered states are not fully understood
* Fermi surface changes have been observed in various heavy-fermion compounds, not always at the quantum critical point

column1: * The authors used the dynamical cluster approximation (DCA) to study the Kondo lattice model (KLM)

column2: * DCA allows for symmetry-breaking antiferromagnetic order and retains temporal fluctuations
* The magnetic phase diagram was mapped out as a function of Kondo coupling and conduction electron density
* Single-particle spectral functions and the evolution of the Fermi surface were investigated
* Results for half-band filling and hole-doping were discussed in detail

column1: * At half-filling, the authors observed the following:

column2: * With particle-hole symmetry, the DCA results agree well with lattice QMC simulations
* Without particle-hole symmetry, the system evolves from a Kondo insulator to an antiferromagnetic state with shadow bands
* The quasi-particle gap tracks the Kondo scale from weak to strong coupling
* The position of the band minima and maxima changes with the coupling strength

column1: * In the hole-doped case, the authors found:

column2: * A continuous magnetic phase transition with the AF order decreasing gradually as the system is doped
* Three distinct Fermi surface topologies: large FS with hole pockets at (œÄ,œÄ), AF-folded large FS, and small FS with hole pockets at (0,0)
* No evidence of a Kondo breakdown or divergence in the effective mass across the transitions
* Mean-field modeling suggests two Lifshitz transitions within the AF phase, leading to a rapid change in the Hall coefficient

173,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Axially symmetric solutions of Einstein's field equations for disklike configurations of matter are of astrophysical interest as models of galaxies or accretion disks

column1: ‚Ä¢ The ""displace, cut and reflect"" method applied to spherically symmetric solutions can generate static disks of perfect fluid

column2: ‚Ä¢ The method involves choosing a surface that divides space into two parts, disregarding the part with singularities, and using the surface for an inversion
‚Ä¢ This results in a disk with a singularity as a delta function, and the Einstein equations separate into two pieces
‚Ä¢ The method is applied to several exact solutions of Einstein's equations for static spheres of perfect fluid to generate disks with halos

column1: ‚Ä¢ Examples of disks generated from specific solutions are presented, including the simplest model based on the Schwarzschild solution

column2: ‚Ä¢ The disks have positive energy density, equal radial and azimuthal pressures, and well-behaved density and pressure profiles

‚Ä¢ Disks with halos are generated from the Buchdahl solution and two solutions by Narlikar, Patwardhan, and Vaidya

column1: ‚Ä¢ Disks with halos composed of fluid layers are also studied

‚Ä¢ Continuity conditions at the layer boundaries are discussed
‚Ä¢ Energy density, pressure, sound velocity, and tangential velocity profiles are analyzed for each example

175,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column2: * Breakdown of external symmetries provides physical explanations (e.g. œÄ0-decay, U(1) problem in QCD)

* Anomalies impose severe restrictions on the physical content of a theory (e.g. existence of top quark in SM)
* Gravitational anomalies include Einstein, Lorentz, and Weyl anomalies

column1: * Anomalies have been calculated using various methods (perturbation theory, heat kernel, path integral, differential geometry, cohomology, topology)

column2: * Deeply related to anomalies are Schwinger terms in the algebra of equal-time commutators
* Schwinger terms in Yang-Mills theory described by Faddeev-Mickelsson cocycle and related to Berry phase
* In gravitation, Schwinger terms occur in ETC of energy-momentum tensors and are related to gravitational anomalies
* Schwinger terms also related to curvature of determinant line bundle

182,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column1: 184,"Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The term ""stochastic resonance"" was introduced in the 1980s to study periodic advance of glaciers on Earth

column2: ‚Ä¢ It refers to the nonmonotone dependence of a system's response on noise added to a periodic input signal
‚Ä¢ Extensive reviews have been done on stochastic resonance and its applications in different fields
‚Ä¢ From a statistical perspective, it involves estimating a signal transmitted through a channel with a threshold

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors study estimation and hypothesis testing for a model with a subthreshold constant non-negative signal and added noise from a diffusion process

column2: ‚Ä¢ Two observation schemes are proposed: 1) proportion of time the perturbed signal is over the threshold, and 2) energy of the perturbed signal above the threshold
‚Ä¢ Asymptotic properties of estimators are studied for the two schemes, showing the phenomenon of stochastic resonance in an example
‚Ä¢ The problem of testing a simple hypothesis against a simple alternative is also solved using a Bayesian approach

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors note that using ergodic diffusions as noise in stochastic resonance problems seems powerful but more complex than i.i.d. noise

column2: ‚Ä¢ The problem of parametric non-constant signals can be treated, but nonparametric non-constant signals require further investigation
‚Ä¢ Other optimality criteria besides Fisher information can be used, as commonly done in information theory
‚Ä¢ The analysis of overall probability of error reveals new insights compared to current literature

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
185,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The order parameter in high-temperature superconductors has been proven to have mainly a d-wave pairing symmetry

column2: ‚Ä¢ Thermal transport measurements show a fourfold oscillation in the longitudinal thermal conductivity when a magnetic field is rotated parallel to the CuO2 planes
‚Ä¢ This oscillation can be explained by Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices and Doppler shift in the quasiparticle energy spectrum, assuming a d-wave gap
‚Ä¢ Deviations from the expected angular pattern have been attributed to vortex pinning effects

‚Ä¢ The variation of thermal conductivity with the angle between heat current and magnetic field depends on quasiparticle heat transport, their interaction with supercurrents, and the order parameter symmetry

column1: ‚Ä¢ Experiments were performed on twinned and untwinned YBa2Cu3O7 single crystals to measure the angular variation of longitudinal thermal conductivity

column2: ‚Ä¢ A heat current was applied along the longest axis of the crystals, and the magnetic field was rotated perpendicular to the c-axis
‚Ä¢ Misalignment between the field rotation plane and CuO2 planes was minimized to less than 1¬∞
‚Ä¢ A field-cooled procedure was used to rule out the influence of vortex pinning on the measurements

‚Ä¢ The untwinned crystal showed a smaller peak in the temperature dependence of thermal conductivity, indicating larger impurity scattering and reduced inelastic scattering compared to the twinned sample

column1: ‚Ä¢ The angular patterns of longitudinal thermal conductivity at different temperatures agree with the theoretical model and confirm the predominance of d-wave gap symmetry up to Tc

column2: ‚Ä¢ Fourfold oscillations were observed at low temperatures, while the angle dependence changed at higher temperatures due to thermal activation of quasiparticles
‚Ä¢ The oscillation amplitudes were smaller in the untwinned sample due to larger impurity scattering
‚Ä¢ Numerical simulations using the Andreev reflection model and a d-wave gap reproduced the experimental results remarkably well
‚Ä¢ The symmetry of the results supports the predominance of d-wave pairing symmet",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 186,"Here is a summary of the text using 2 bullet points with 1 sub-point each:
<summary>

‚Ä¢ Dehn surgery is an operation to modify a 3-manifold by drilling and regluing a solid torus. The cosmetic surgery conjecture states that surgeries on inequivalent slopes are never purely cosmetic (resulting in the same oriented manifold).

column2: ‚Ä¢ The authors prove that for most knots, surgeries on distinct slopes result in different manifolds, using a sufficient condition based on the Jones polynomial and its derivatives. This improves on previous results.

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors use a surgery formula by Lescop involving a knot invariant w_3 that is the same as the third derivative of the Jones polynomial. They also observe that w_3 is a finite type invariant of order 3.

column2: ‚Ä¢ As applications, they prove the nonexistence of purely cosmetic surgeries for certain two-bridge knots and Whitehead doubles, deriving an explicit formula for the order 3 finite type invariant of two-bridge knots.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
187,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Anomaly-mediated supersymmetry breaking (AMSB) models:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Soft SUSY breaking terms calculable from gravitino mass
‚Ä¢ Solves SUSY flavor and CP problems
‚Ä¢ Tachyonic slepton mass problem solved by adding universal scalar mass
‚Ä¢ Minimal AMSB (mAMSB) parameter space: m_0, m_3/2, tan Œ≤, sign(Œº)

column1: ‚Ä¢ Hypercharged anomaly-mediation (HCAMSB) models:

column2: ‚Ä¢ String-motivated scenario with similar setup to AMSB
‚Ä¢ Bino mass M_1 can be the only soft SUSY breaking parameter not determined by anomaly mediation
‚Ä¢ Combination of hypercharge and anomaly mediation leads to viable spectra
‚Ä¢ HCAMSB parameter space: Œ±, m_3/2, tan Œ≤, sign(Œº)

column1: ‚Ä¢ Sparticle mass spectra in HCAMSB:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Spectra depend on Œ± and m_3/2
‚Ä¢ Increasing Œ± leads to heavier scalars (especially those with large hypercharge), lighter stops/sbottoms
‚Ä¢ Wino-like lightest chargino and neutralino; higgsino-like second lightest neutralinos
‚Ä¢ Highly split third generation squarks for moderate to large Œ±

column1: ‚Ä¢ LHC phenomenology of HCAMSB:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Events characterized by high pT b and t quarks, missing ET, and observable chargino tracks
‚Ä¢ Slepton pair production visible for small Œ±; direct gaugino production for large Œ±
‚Ä¢ 100 fb^-1 LHC reach up to m_3/2 ~ 105 (210) TeV for small (large) Œ±
‚Ä¢ Distinguishable from mAMSB by presence of Z ‚Üí l+l- candidates in cascade decays

column1: ‚Ä¢ Conclusions:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Computed HCAMSB sparticle mass spectra and LHC reach
‚Ä¢ Differences from mAMSB: left-right scalar splitting, m(·∫Ω",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 188,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The ideas of zero range potential (ZRP) approach were developed to widen limits of traditional scattering treatment

column2: ‚Ä¢ ZRP allows obtaining exact solutions to scattering problems and can be represented as a boundary condition or pseudopotential

column1: ‚Ä¢ Darboux transformation (DT) allows constructing exactly solvable potentials and can be used to correct the ZRP model

column2: ‚Ä¢ DT modifies the generalized ZRP boundary condition and creates potentials with arbitrarily disposed discrete spectrum levels

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors consider electron scattering by C3 and C4 structures using the ZRP model

column2: ‚Ä¢ Calculations for electron-CH4 scattering are presented and discussed

column1: ‚Ä¢ Partial waves for a multi-centered target with N ZRPs can be expressed as a superposition of Green's functions

column2: ‚Ä¢ Scattering amplitude is obtained by imposing boundary conditions, reducing the calculation to solving a system of equations

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors consider scattering for a dressed multi-center potential to illustrate the possibilities of DT

column2: ‚Ä¢ Structures like dome, regular trihedron, and regular tetrahedron are studied, with phases derived analytically

column1: ‚Ä¢ The C4 structures can model electron scattering by polyatomic molecules like CH4, CF4, CCl4

column2: ‚Ä¢ Integral cross sections for CH4 are calculated within the ZRP model framework and compared with experimental data

column1: ‚Ä¢ DT allows correcting the ZRP model at low energies

column2: ‚Ä¢ In the limiting case, DT induces long-range forces depending on angular momentum, leading to singularities in the cross section at zero energy

column1: ‚Ä¢ The authors demonstrate the possibilities of DT in multi-center scattering problems

column2: ‚Ä¢ DTs can improve agreement with experimental results by considering higher partial waves and adding shape resonances

189,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Presents numerical solutions to 2D convection-diffusion equations using three methods

column2: ‚Ä¢ Modified exponential cubic B-splines DQM (mexp-DQM)
‚Ä¢ Modified trigonometric cubic B-splines DQM (mtb-DQM)
‚Ä¢ Modified extended cubic B-splines DQM (mecdq)
‚Ä¢ Transforms PDE into system of first-order ODEs in time, solved using SSP-RK54 scheme

column1: ‚Ä¢ Analyzes stability of the methods for 2D convection-diffusion equations

column2: ‚Ä¢ Employs matrix stability analysis
‚Ä¢ Confirms proposed methods produce stable solutions
‚Ä¢ Eigenvalues of coefficient matrix are real and negative
‚Ä¢ Sufficient for stability of the system

column1: ‚Ä¢ Conducts numerical study of three test problems with Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions

column2: ‚Ä¢ Compares accuracy and efficiency using discrete error norms
‚Ä¢ Proposed solutions are more accurate than existing schemes
‚Ä¢ In good agreement with exact solutions
‚Ä¢ Order of accuracy is cubic or super-linear for Dirichlet conditions, quadratic for Neumann conditions

column1: ‚Ä¢ Utilizes various cubic B-spline base functions for computing weighting coefficients

column2: ‚Ä¢ Modified trigonometric cubic B-splines
‚Ä¢ Modified exponential cubic B-splines
‚Ä¢ Modified extended cubic B-splines
‚Ä¢ Procedure followed analogously in both x and y directions

column1: ‚Ä¢ Concludes the proposed methods are accurate and efficient for 2D convection-diffusion problems

column2: ‚Ä¢ Suitable for both Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions
‚Ä¢ Stable and higher-order accurate compared to existing schemes
‚Ä¢ Can be applied to various science and engineering problems governed by convection-diffusion equations
‚Ä¢ Further research can extend the methods to 3D and nonlinear convection-diffusion equations

190,"Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Submillimeter galaxy (SMG) surveys have changed our understanding of galaxy formation and evolution

column2: * SCUBA and MAMBO surveys discovered a population of dusty starburst galaxies at high redshifts
* Early studies suggested SMGs had no obvious optical counterparts, making detailed studies difficult
* Recent progress has come from radio imaging of submm survey fields, providing precise positions
* Spectroscopic redshifts indicate a median redshift of z~2.2 for the radio-detected SMG population

column1: * The authors developed a dual-survey extraction technique combining SCUBA and MAMBO data

column2: * Resulted in a robust sample of 19 SMGs in the Lockman Hole, with 15 secure radio detections
* Undetected SMGs explained by spurious sources and large scatter in dust temperatures
* Spectroscopic redshifts for 15 SMGs, with a median of z=2.14, consistent with previous studies
* Suggests most bright SMGs are amenable to study via radio-selected samples down to S_850um > 4mJy

column1: * Analysis of positional offsets between SMGs and radio counterparts allows calibration of uncertainties

column2: * Bright SMGs (>10œÉ) can be located to within ~1"" even without radio counterparts
* Spectroscopy of individual sources reveals a mix of starbursts and AGN, often at z~2-3
* SMGs are a diverse population, with some very faint and red optical counterparts
* Detailed understanding remains difficult due to the faintness and complexity of the SMG population
