191,"Here is a summary of the text using 2 bullet points with 1 sub-point each:
<summary>
* The authors present an analysis of the galaxy luminosity function (LF) from the Norris Survey of the Corona Borealis Supercluster

column2: * The local LF agrees well with the Las Campanas Redshift Survey (LCRS) but has a higher normalization than the Stromlo/APM survey, possibly due to photometric errors in the APM catalog

column1: * The authors observe evolution of the field galaxy LF within their sample, confirming results from previous redshift surveys

column2: * Blue, star-forming galaxies evolve to become more luminous at higher redshifts, while red galaxies do not evolve significantly, and the star formation appears to be long-lived rather than occurring in short bursts

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
192,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 1 sub-point each:
<summary>
* Rapidity gaps have been observed in hadronic collisions at HERA and the Tevatron, attributed to color singlet exchange between partons

column2: * A fraction of dijet events at the Tevatron exhibit rapidity gaps, demonstrating color singlet exchange effects at high momentum transfers

column1: * The two-gluon exchange model predicts the color singlet fraction, but fails to match Tevatron data on the gap fraction's dependence on jet transverse momentum

column2: * Unitarity considerations show that one- and two-gluon exchange amplitudes are incompatible, requiring a more realistic description through phase shift unitarization

column1: * Numerical analysis reveals a strong dependence of color singlet fractions on the regularization of gluon exchange at small momentum transfer, indicating non-perturbative effects

column2: * The unitarized model can fit Tevatron data using two parameters: the gap survival probability and a universal Coulomb phase shift

column1: * The formation of rapidity gaps in hadronic scattering is common, but a quantitative understanding within QCD is challenging due to non-perturbative effects

column2: * The unitarized gluon exchange model, despite limitations, suggests a unified phenomenological description of rapidity gap data via the gap survival probability and a universal phase

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
193,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Various techniques have been proposed for forecasting electric energy consumption, which is useful for power system management, consumer satisfaction, and system security

column2: * Energy demand in the Gaza Strip has grown rapidly, with service and household sectors accounting for 75% of demand

column1: * Previous forecasting approaches can be grouped into time series, functional based, and soft computing based methods

column2: * Each approach has advantages and limitations in terms of accuracy, data requirements, and computational complexity

column1: * This study used historical data from 1994-2013 to develop an artificial neural network (ANN) model for forecasting electric energy consumption in Gaza

column2: * The ANN model was trained on data from 1994-2011 and used to predict consumption for 2012-2013

column1: * The ANN model's performance was evaluated using error criteria such as mean squared error, root mean squared error, mean absolute error, and mean absolute percentage error

column2: * Results showed the ANN model achieved good accuracy in forecasting electric energy consumption for Gaza in 2012 and 2013

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
194,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ LMC X-2 is a persistent LMXB and Z-source with an accretion rate near the Eddington limit

column2: ‚Ä¢ It is one of the most X-ray luminous LMXBs known at 1-2 x 10^38 erg/s
‚Ä¢ Its optical counterpart was identified as a B = 18.5 blue star
‚Ä¢ Orbital period estimates range from 6.4 hrs to 12 days with no periodic variability in MACHO data

column1: ‚Ä¢ Phase-resolved spectroscopy was performed on LMC X-2 using the VLT over 2 nights

column2: ‚Ä¢ Narrow Bowen emission lines were detected, likely originating from the irradiated donor star
‚Ä¢ The HeII 4686 emission line showed a radial velocity curve with a period of 0.32 days
‚Ä¢ Large changes in H-alpha line strength were observed between the two nights

column1: ‚Ä¢ Doppler tomography suggests the presence of an inclined, precessing, warped accretion disk

column2: ‚Ä¢ The HeII Doppler map shows an emission ring with a bright spot that moves between nights
‚Ä¢ The Bowen Doppler map reveals a bright spot at high velocities, likely from the irradiated donor
‚Ä¢ Sub-Keplerian velocities in the HeII map could be explained by a tilted disk

column1: ‚Ä¢ System parameters are constrained using the radial velocity and rotational broadening of Bowen lines

column2: ‚Ä¢ A strict lower limit on the mass function is f(M) > 0.86 M_sun
‚Ä¢ The mass ratio is constrained to 0.10 < q < 0.38
‚Ä¢ LMC X-2 likely contains a neutron star more massive than 1.4 M_sun

400,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Prior to 9/11, significant vulnerabilities existed in aviation security

column2: * Weaknesses in screening passengers, baggage, and controlling airport access
* Air traffic control systems were susceptible to intrusion and attack

column1: * TSA was created after 9/11 to address aviation security issues

column2: * Deployed federal screeners and explosives detection equipment at airports
* Expanded the Federal Air Marshal Service

column1: * TSA is pursuing initiatives to strengthen access control and passenger screening

column2: * Developing a Transportation Worker Identification Credential (TWIC) program
* Implementing the next-generation Computer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System (CAPPS II)

column1: * FAA has worked to improve security of air traffic control systems and facilities

column2: * Developed information systems security policies and conducted assessments
* Completed background investigations of numerous contractor employees

column1: * Vulnerabilities remain in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security

column2: * Limited physical screening of air cargo on passenger flights
* General aviation airports and aircraft are far more open and potentially vulnerable
* Airport perimeters and the areas beyond them are difficult to fully protect

column1: * TSA faces challenges in risk management, funding, coordination, and strategic planning

column2: * Adopting a risk management approach to prioritize resources and efforts
* Paying for increased aviation security costs and controlling spending
* Partnering with federal, state, local agencies and aviation stakeholders

column1: * Building a results-oriented culture is key for TSA within Homeland Security

column2: * Establishing a coherent mission and strategic goals to guide the organization
* Effectively managing its workforce as efficiency improves with new technology and processes

column1: * Continued investment in research and development is critical

column2: * Developing more effective equipment to screen passengers, baggage, and cargo
* Ensuring adequate funding for research and development of new security technologies

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
401,"Here is a summary of the source document using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* LDA, IRC 4911 and 162(e) were passed at different times for different purposes

column2: * LDA requires lobbying organizations to register and report lobbying efforts
* IRC 4911 limits lobbying by 501(c)(3) organizations to maintain tax-exempt status
* IRC 162(e) denies tax deductibility of certain lobbying expenses for businesses

column1: * LDA registration requirements include minimum dollar and time thresholds

column2: * Organization must have $20,500 in lobbying expenses and employee spending 20% time lobbying
* Lobbyists must be listed if making >1 contact and spending 20% time lobbying
* Registered organizations must file semiannual reports disclosing lobbying activities

column1: * LDA and IRC definitions differ in types of lobbying activities and contacts covered

column2: * LDA only covers federal lobbying; IRC also covers state, local and grassroots lobbying
* LDA covers legislative and nonlegislative lobbying; IRC more limited in nonlegislative coverage
* LDA and IRC differ in which executive branch officials are covered

column1: * Using IRC definitions can result in less disclosure than intended by LDA

column2: * Some organizations may avoid registration by using IRC definitions
* IRC definitions can include non-federal lobbying unrelated to LDA's purpose
* IRC definitions may exclude some federal lobbying covered by LDA definition

column1: * For July-Dec 1997, 1,824 organizations lobbied on own behalf; 71% used LDA definition

column2: * 9% used IRC 4911 definition; 20% used IRC 162(e) definition
* Mean expenses highest for IRC 162(e), 87% higher than LDA
* Median expenses $180K for IRC 162(e), $80K for LDA and IRC 4911

column1: * Options to better align LDA with its purpose:

column2: * Harmonize the definitions, though this could significantly alter tax law
* Eliminate option to use IRC definitions, increasing reporting burden for some
* Require those using IRC to only include federal lobbying expenses under IRC

column1: * If IRC option allowed, Congress should consider requiring only federal",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
402,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ GAO has assessed strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade

column2: ‚Ä¢ Reported in 2002 that leading companies committed to strategic approach for acquiring services
‚Ä¢ Emphasized importance of comprehensive spend analysis for efficient procurement

column1: ‚Ä¢ Most agencies leveraged only a fraction of buying power through strategic sourcing as of 2012

column2: ‚Ä¢ DOD, DHS, Energy, and VA accounted for 80% of procurement spending but only 5% through strategic sourcing
‚Ä¢ Agencies cited impediments like data challenges, lack of expertise, leadership support, and metrics

column1: ‚Ä¢ Federal government obligated $307 billion to acquire services in FY2012, over half of all procurement

column2: ‚Ä¢ Agencies have difficulty managing services acquisition and miss opportunities to increase competition
‚Ä¢ In contrast, leading companies strategically source the full range of services and tailor tactics based on complexity and supplier availability

column1: ‚Ä¢ OMB and agencies have recently taken actions to expand strategic sourcing

column2: ‚Ä¢ In 2012, GAO recommended DOD, VA and OMB take steps to improve efforts
‚Ä¢ OMB directed agencies in 2012 to strategically source new products/services and reinforce leadership commitment

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
403,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Current surface transportation programs are not effectively addressing challenges due to lack of clear federal role, goals not linked to performance, and unsustainable funding

column2: * Federal role has expanded without well-defined vision of national interests
* Most funds distributed through formulas with little link to needs or performance
* Highway Trust Fund spending exceeds revenues, threatening fiscal sustainability

column1: * Principles for restructuring surface transportation programs include:

column2: * Creating well-defined goals based on national interests
* Establishing clear federal roles
* Incorporating performance and accountability into funding decisions

column1: * Options for funding transportation infrastructure investments include:

column2: * Altering existing or introducing new taxes and user fees
* Using financing mechanisms like bonding, loans, and revolving funds
* Leveraging public-private partnerships

column1: * Challenges in funding and financing infrastructure include:

column2: * Generating adequate and sustainable revenues
* Determining appropriate federal role and funding share
* Protecting public interests in public-private partnerships

column1: * Reexamining federal transportation programs is needed to:

column2: * Review relevance and priority of existing programs
* Tailor funding and financing to relevant programs addressing national interests
* Improve program design, service delivery, and accountability for results

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
404,"Here is a summary of the source document using 2 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation each:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ FAA engages in aviation safety oversight, air traffic control (ATC), and airport infrastructure development

column2: ‚Ä¢ Safety activities include licensing pilots and mechanics and inspecting aircraft and airline operations, with costs driven by the volume of each

‚Ä¢ ATC guides aircraft through the National Airspace System (NAS) using control towers, terminal radar approach control, and air route traffic control centers, with costs influenced by the amount and nature of services used

column1: ‚Ä¢ The current excise tax funding system raises revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency concerns

column2: ‚Ä¢ Trends suggest revenues are falling relative to FAA's workload and costs, while comparisons of revenue contributed and costs imposed by different flights support equity and efficiency concerns

‚Ä¢ Alternative funding options like fuel taxes, en-route/flight segment charges, and certification charges could address these concerns to varying degrees, but would involve administrative and transition issues

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
405,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* DOD conducted secret chemical weapons tests during WWII involving 60,000 military personnel

column2: * VA lacked information about exposed individuals
* DOD and VA developed a task force to identify exposed personnel
* The task force identified approximately 6,400 exposed servicemembers and civilians
* Congress continued investigating the issue in the 1990s

column1: * DOD was required to submit a plan to Congress and VA about Project 112 records

column2: * DOD identified 5,842 servicemembers and 350 civilians potentially exposed in Project 112
* DOD ceased actively searching for additional Project 112 participants in 2003
* GAO found DOD's decision was not supported by a cost-benefit analysis
* Additional exposed individuals from Project 112 have been identified since 2003

column1: * DOD's current effort to identify exposures outside Project 112 has shortcomings

column2: * Objectives, scope, and information needs are unclear and inconsistent
* Management, oversight, and transparency are lacking
* Work of other organizations that identified exposed individuals is not fully utilized
* Congress, veterans, and the public are not kept well informed

column1: * DOD and VA have had limited success notifying exposed individuals

column2: * DOD has inconsistently transmitted information to VA
* VA has not used all available resources to obtain contact information
* DOD has not taken action to notify identified civilians

column1: * Challenges remain in DOD's and VA's notification efforts

column2: * Some records have been lost, destroyed, or have limited information
* It is unclear if DOD or another agency is required to notify civilians
* Without guidance, civilians may remain unaware of potential exposure
* As the exposed population ages, timely notification becomes more critical

column1: * GAO made recommendations and matters for congressional consideration

column2: * DOD should conduct a cost-benefit analysis on searching for Project 112 participants
* Congress should consider requiring DOD to develop guidance on notifying civilians
* DOD and VA should take steps to improve their identification and notification efforts

column1: * DOD partially agreed with GAO's recommendations

column2: * DOD disagreed with conducting a cost-benefit analysis on Project 112
* DOD agreed to",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 406,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Mexican drug trafficking organizations (DTOs) have expanded their criminal activities, including firearms trafficking

column2: * DTOs require a constant supply of firearms, which are primarily transported overland from the U.S. into Mexico

column1: * From 2009 to 2014, the majority of firearms seized in Mexico and traced originated in the U.S., especially from Southwest border states

column2: * Most of these firearms were purchased in the U.S. and then illegally transferred to Mexico

column1: * The use of firearms parts to assemble guns in Mexico has become a new challenge in combating firearms trafficking

column2: * Firearms parts are not regulated like complete firearms, making them difficult to trace and easier to smuggle

column1: * ATF and ICE have taken steps to improve coordination on efforts to combat firearms trafficking, as outlined in their 2009 MOU

column2: * However, some challenges persist in information sharing and defining agency roles in investigations

column1: * Changes in U.S.-Mexico collaboration under the Pe√±a Nieto administration have impacted bilateral efforts to combat firearms trafficking

column2: * Access to ATF's eTrace system in Mexico was centralized and the GC Armas working group meetings were suspended

column1: * Corruption among some Mexican officials and frequent turnover in Mexican law enforcement pose challenges to U.S.-Mexico collaboration

column2: * U.S. officials are sometimes hesitant to share sensitive information due to concerns about corruption

column1: * The indicator used in the National Southwest Border Counternarcotics Strategy to measure progress in stemming firearms trafficking is inadequate

column2: * The number of firearms seized and traced does not accurately reflect the effectiveness of efforts to combat trafficking

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
407,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* NCHIP is a federal grant program to help states improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records

column2: * Grants totaled over $438 million from fiscal years 1995-2003
* Recipients must conform to FBI standards for national data systems
* Majority of funds used for NICS-related purposes from 2000-2003

column1: * States have made progress in automating records, but some gaps remain

column2: * Percentage of nation's automated criminal history records increased from 79% in 1993 to 89% in 2001
* Challenges include lack of disposition data and records on certain prohibited purchasers
* Mental health and substance abuse records are particularly problematic

column1: * Demand for background checks is growing due to employment screening and homeland security needs

column2: * Civil fingerprint submissions to the FBI exceeded criminal submissions in 5 of 7 years from 1996-2002
* Recent laws require background checks for sensitive positions and to protect against terrorism
* Millions of additional checks expected as laws are fully implemented

column1: * BJS is developing a records quality index to measure jurisdictions' progress and allocate funds

column2: * Based on key indicators like percentage of records that are automated
* Will be used to pinpoint deficiencies and target funds to specific problems
* Data collection from states was still ongoing as of January 2004

column1: * Policymakers should consider cumulative progress and remaining needs in debating NCHIP's future

column2: * Much progress made, but disposition reporting and records on certain prohibited purchasers still lacking
* Growing demand for background checks and evolving technology require continued improvements
* States rely on NCHIP as ""seed money"" to supplement state funds for upgrades

column1: * GAO's review focused on providing national perspectives on NCHIP

column2: * Analyzed BJS and FBI data on automation progress and use of funds
* Conducted case studies of 5 states to provide more in-depth information
* Assessed reliability of key data sources used in the review

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
408,"Here is a summary of the text using 2 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Superfund program was created by Congress in 1980 to clean up the nation's most contaminated hazardous waste sites

column2: ‚Ä¢ EPA investigates contaminated areas and places the most contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for cleanup
‚Ä¢ Through fiscal year 1995, EPA had selected incineration as a cleanup remedy 43 times, or in about 6% of remedy decisions
‚Ä¢ Incineration involves burning substances in an enclosed kiln, converting contamination into ash and gases
‚Ä¢ EPA relies on setting emissions standards, safety features, emissions monitoring, and 24-hour oversight to ensure safe incinerator operation

column1: ‚Ä¢ EPA had planned additional methods to promote safe incinerator operation but did not fully implement them

column2: ‚Ä¢ EPA issued a directive requiring periodic inspections of Superfund incinerators by its hazardous waste inspection program, but this was not followed at 2 of 3 operating incinerators
‚Ä¢ EPA intended to systematically share lessons learned about incinerator operations between projects but relied on informal communication instead
‚Ä¢ The GAO recommends that EPA implement its inspection guidance for Superfund incinerators and institute a process to document and share lessons learned from incineration projects
‚Ä¢ EPA agreed with the report's facts, conclusions and recommendations

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
409,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 are presented fairly in all material respects

column2: ‚Ä¢ Misstatements may occur in other financial information reported by SEC due to internal control deficiencies
‚Ä¢ SEC changed its method of accounting for user fees collected in excess of current-year appropriations in fiscal year 2007

column1: ‚Ä¢ SEC did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007

column2: ‚Ä¢ Significant control deficiencies were identified in SEC's financial reporting process, collectively considered a material weakness
‚Ä¢ Three significant deficiencies in internal control were identified, concerning property and equipment, information security, and accounting for budgetary resources

column1: ‚Ä¢ SEC's financial management system does not conform to the systems requirements of OMB Circular No. A-127

column2: ‚Ä¢ SEC's period-end financial reporting process is supported by systems that are not integrated or compatible with its general ledger system
‚Ä¢ Extensive compensating manual and labor-intensive accounting procedures are required, increasing the risk of errors

column1: ‚Ä¢ Errors were identified in SEC's calculation of disgorgement and penalty accounts receivable and in its year-end financial statement disclosures

column2: ‚Ä¢ The process for calculating accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties presents a high risk of significant undetected errors
‚Ä¢ Numerous errors were noted in SEC's year-end draft financial statement disclosures

column1: ‚Ä¢ Tests of compliance with selected provisions of laws and regulations disclosed no reportable instances of noncompliance

column2: ‚Ä¢ The objective of the audit was not to provide an opinion on overall compliance with laws and regulations
‚Ä¢ No opinion is expressed on the consistency of SEC's Management's Discussion and Analysis and other accompanying information with the financial statements

column1: ‚Ä¢ SEC management is responsible for the financial statements, internal control, and compliance with applicable laws and regulations

column2: ‚Ä¢ GAO is responsible for obtaining reasonable assurance about the financial statements and internal control
‚Ä¢ GAO tested compliance with selected provisions of laws and regulations that could have a direct and material effect on the financial statements

column1: ‚Ä¢ SEC's Chairman said he was pleased to receive an unqualified opinion on SEC's financial statements

column2: ‚Ä¢ SEC plans to remediate the material weakness before the end of fiscal 2008 and address each of the findings and recommendations
‚Ä¢",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 410,"Here is the summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Women and minorities were underrepresented in the Postal Service workforce compared to the Civilian Labor Force in 1997

column2: * Black and Asian men and women were fully represented
* White, Hispanic, and Native American women and men were underrepresented

column1: * Representation of women and minorities in EAS 17+ positions increased from 1993 to 1997

column2: * Black men's representation decreased slightly
* White men's representation also decreased

column1: * In 1997, women and minorities were promoted to EAS 17+ positions at higher rates than their existing representation in those positions

column2: * Asian women were an exception at the cluster level
* White men were promoted at lower rates across all levels

column1: * Women and minorities were less represented in EAS 17+ positions compared to EAS 11-16 positions in 1997

column2: * This was true across cluster, headquarters, and area office levels
* White men had higher representation in EAS 17+ vs 11-16 positions

column1: * The Aguirre study on Postal Service diversity had some limitations but used reasonable methodologies

column2: * The 6-month timeframe and pre-selected sites limited the study
* The ""glass ceiling"" finding was not well-supported by evidence

column1: * The Postal Service is implementing initiatives to improve diversity but needs better data

column2: * 23 initiatives are underway to address Aguirre report recommendations
* Reliable promotion applicant data is needed to identify barriers

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
411,"Here is a summary of the text using 2 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation each:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Military Working Dogs (MWDs) are used by the Department of Defense (DOD) for various purposes and can be adopted after their service

column2: ‚Ä¢ Robby's Law, enacted in 2000 and amended several times, promotes the adoption of MWDs and establishes adoption priorities
‚Ä¢ The Air Force and Army use three systems to track information on MWDs, including their removal from service and adoption

column1: ‚Ä¢ Data from 2014-2015 shows prevalent medical conditions in adopted MWDs, and potential costs for their care can vary

column2: ‚Ä¢ Owners of adopted MWDs are responsible for their care costs, but some assistance is available through nonprofit organizations
‚Ä¢ DOD offers veterinary services for adopted MWDs to owners with access to medical care at military installations, but services vary by location

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
412,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The Comanche helicopter program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet

column2: * The program has experienced significant cost increases and schedule delays
* In 1994, the Secretary of Defense directed the Army to restructure the program to meet budgetary constraints
* The restructuring reduced funding, extended development by 3 years, and deferred the production decision
* The Army proposed acquiring 6 additional aircraft within the funding constraints by deferring some development efforts

column1: * The restructured program continues risks of making production decisions before the aircraft is fully tested and of higher costs

column2: * According to DOD guidelines, programs should have low concurrency to avoid costly retrofits and ensure thorough testing
* Under the restructured program, operational testing will begin after the low-rate production decision is made
* The 6 additional ""early operational capability"" aircraft are estimated to cost over $300 million
* Committing to production before completing testing continues the risks of the highly concurrent program

column1: * The Comanche program has experienced significant increases in unit cost and decreases in planned quantities

column2: * In 1985, the program was estimated to cost $61 billion for 5,023 aircraft ($12.1 million per aircraft)
* As of 1995, the program is estimated to cost $44 billion for 1,292 aircraft ($34.4 million per aircraft)
* The restructuring extends development by 3 years and increases the risk of higher total program and unit costs
* There are concerns that deferred development efforts may not have sufficient funding in future years

column1: * The Comanche faces risks in successfully developing its complex software and meeting maintainability goals

column2: * The Comanche will have over 2.7 million lines of code, mostly in the Ada programming language
* Software development issues exist with the Ada compilation system, testing delays, and configuration management
* Key maintainability requirements like maintenance man-hours per flight hour and mean time to repair may not be met
* Collectively, maintainability shortfalls could impact operating costs and wartime availability goals

column1: * GAO recommends the Army complete operational testing before committing to production and address risks

column1: 413,"Here is a summary of the source text using 5 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Food Stamp Program provides benefits to low-income households to purchase food

column2: ‚Ä¢ FNS funds benefits and half of states' administrative costs and sets regulations
‚Ä¢ States determine eligibility, calculate benefits, and issue benefits to households
‚Ä¢ Households must meet income and asset limits to qualify for benefits

column1: ‚Ä¢ FNS introduced options and waivers to increase access and reduce reporting burden

column2: ‚Ä¢ Options relate to eligibility, reporting, extending benefits, and TANF recipients
‚Ä¢ Most states used options to exempt vehicles from asset tests
‚Ä¢ Most states used reporting options/waivers to reduce payment errors and paperwork

column1: ‚Ä¢ FNS monitors states' payment accuracy through its quality control system

column2: ‚Ä¢ States review samples of cases to determine if correct benefits were issued
‚Ä¢ Over- and underpayment errors totaled about $1.3 billion in FY 2000
‚Ä¢ About half of errors are due to incorrect income determinations

column1: ‚Ä¢ Few states are using the Transitional Benefit Alternative or Simplified Program options

column2: ‚Ä¢ 20 states are considering the 3-month transitional benefit option
‚Ä¢ 27 states would implement a 6-month transitional benefit option
‚Ä¢ No states plan to fully implement the complex Simplified Program option

column1: ‚Ä¢ States want additional changes to food stamp rules and quality control system

column2: ‚Ä¢ Allow one vehicle exemption per household and increase vehicle exemption value
‚Ä¢ Allow same reporting rules for all households, not just those with earnings
‚Ä¢ Do not focus quality control solely on payment accuracy

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
414,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* HUD, established in 1965, is responsible for housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues

column2: * Staffed by 9,386 employees as of February 1999

column1: * HUD provides housing assistance through public housing authorities and private-market housing assistance

column2: * Benefits are limited by budgetary constraints to about one-fourth of those eligible

column1: * HUD provides community development funds through grants to states and local areas

column2: * Funding may also be distributed directly to nonprofit groups and organizations

column1: * HUD is responsible for housing finance through the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) and Government National Mortgage Association

column2: * FHA insures lenders against losses on mortgages

column1: * HUD regulates various housing-related issues and supports fair housing programs

column2: * Responsible for enforcing federal fair housing laws

column1: * For fiscal year 2000, HUD is proposing a budget of about $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority

column2: * Represents a 9-percent increase over fiscal year 1999

column1: * HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs not funded in fiscal year 1999

column2: * Raises questions about HUD's capacity to manage the increase during its organizational reform

column1: * Issues with HUD's Section 8 housing assistance program budget proposal warrant review

column2: * Basis for contract renewal costs and substantial increase in outlays should be examined

column1: * Concerns exist regarding HUD's Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) Program and contracting practices

column2: * CDBG's Integrated Disbursement and Information System has problems providing detailed performance information

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
415,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Military Health System operated by DOD provides medical services to armed forces during contingency operations and to eligible beneficiaries

column2: ‚Ä¢ DOD plans to consolidate the aging Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC) and 86th Medical Group (MDG) clinic into one new replacement medical center

column1: ‚Ä¢ DOD used beneficiary population data, contingency operations, and troop strength to plan the replacement medical center

column2: ‚Ä¢ More recent posture changes announced in 2012 are being assessed for their impact on the replacement medical center

column1: ‚Ä¢ DOD incorporated patient quality of care and environmentally friendly design standards into the facility requirements

column2: ‚Ä¢ However, DOD's documentation had inconsistencies in projecting workload, inadequate details on estimating requirements, and calculation errors

column1: ‚Ä¢ DOD's cost estimate followed many best practices but minimally documented data sources, calculations, and estimating methodologies

column2: ‚Ä¢ The replacement medical center is expected to be the hub of a larger medical campus, but cost estimates and time frames have not been developed for the additional facilities

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO recommends DOD provide clear documentation on determining facility requirements, correct calculation errors, revise the cost estimate to reflect posture changes, and thoroughly document the data and methodology used
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
416,"Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* ICE officers exercise discretion throughout the alien apprehension and removal process, particularly in the initial phases

column2: * Officers have more latitude when encountering aliens who are not investigation targets or have humanitarian issues
* Guidance instructs officers to consider factors like flight risk, threat to community, and humanitarian issues when deciding to detain aliens
* Officers can pursue alternatives to apprehension like mailing a Notice to Appear or scheduling a future appointment

column1: * ICE has taken some steps to guide officer decision-making but guidance is not comprehensive

column2: * ICE updated some training to reflect expanded enforcement efforts but guidance in field manuals is outdated
* Various ICE memos provide some instruction on discretion but are not comprehensive and only apply to certain officers
* ICE lacks a mechanism to consistently disseminate legal developments to officers across all field offices

column1: * ICE has controls to monitor removal operations but cannot analyze trends in discretionary decisions

column2: * Supervisory reviews and a new inspection program monitor compliance with policies and procedures
* However, these do not allow analysis of data on discretionary decisions across field offices to identify trends
* Databases do not capture details on discretionary decisions and ICE has not assessed costs and benefits of collecting this data

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
417,"Here is a summary of the source text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Ground ambulance services are provided by a variety of organizations that differ in structure, staffing, types of transports, and revenue sources

column2: * Medicare pays ambulance providers through a national fee schedule with a service-level payment and a mileage payment
* Providers' costs per transport in 2010 were highly variable, ranging from $224 to $2,204, with a median of $429
* Personnel costs accounted for the largest percentage of providers' total costs in 2010
* Providers with lower transport volumes generally had higher costs per transport than providers with greater volumes

column1: * The median Medicare margin for providers in the sample was 2% in 2010 with add-on payments, but -1% without add-on payments

column2: * Ambulance transports for Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries increased by 33% from 2004 to 2010
* The increase was primarily due to a 59% rise in BLS nonemergency transports
* Increased billing by local governments and the introduction of the national fee schedule in 2002 may have contributed to the increase
* The HHS OIG has cited improper payments as a potential cause of the increase in utilization

column1: * The GAO provided a draft of the report to HHS and AAA for review

column2: * HHS had no comments on behalf of CMS
* AAA generally agreed with the findings but had some questions about the methodology and conclusions
* AAA noted that the sample represents mature, well-established providers and may not be representative of all providers
* AAA questioned some of the regression analysis results and noted that current Medicare payments are lower than in 2010

column1: * The GAO conducted the study from April to September 2012 using a survey of ambulance providers and analysis of Medicare claims data

column2: * The survey collected data on costs, revenues, transports, and organizational characteristics for 2010
* The sample was drawn from a 2007 sample of providers that billed Medicare in 2003 and were still operational in 2012
* Medicare claims data was used to calculate 2010 payments for providers in the sample and to examine ambulance utilization
*",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 418,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The military services have maintained accountability of SRC I ammunition at sampled locations, but there are gaps in some service-level guidance and procedures

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Air Force does not track SRC I ammunition by serial number but plans to revise guidance
‚Ä¢ Air Force procedures have not maintained accountability for items owned by other services
‚Ä¢ The services generally recorded shipment and receipt, but not always in a timely manner

column1: ‚Ä¢ The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Army has not ensured timely and complete information of items returned to the contractor
‚Ä¢ The Army inaccurately categorized two variants of SRC I rockets but took action to correct it
‚Ä¢ The services have not always entered timely, accurate, and complete data in the Defense Transportation Tracking System

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO made six recommendations to enhance DOD's policy, procedures, accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition

column2: ‚Ä¢ Revise Air Force guidance to maintain accountability of all SRC I items regardless of ownership
‚Ä¢ Finalize Army and Marine Corps guidance on required timeframes for receipting SRC I ammunition
‚Ä¢ Have the Army evaluate actions to retain accountability for in-transit items

column1: ‚Ä¢ DOD concurred with all six recommendations and plans to implement them

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Air Force issued a memo directing units to account for all SRC I items regardless of ownership
‚Ä¢ The Army and Marine Corps will include receipting timeframe procedures in their guidance
‚Ä¢ The services will collaboratively determine information needed to improve DTTS data and tracking

column1: ‚Ä¢ Previous GAO reports since 1994 have identified issues with DOD's management of SRC I ammunition

column2: ‚Ä¢ Weaknesses were found in serial number registration, physical inventories, and transportation
‚Ä¢ Most of the recommendations from these prior reports have been implemented by DOD
‚Ä¢ A few recommendations remain open, such as selecting an authoritative data source for ammunition

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
419,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ SSA maintains personal information on individuals to administer Social Security programs

column2: ‚Ä¢ SSA has a long history of protecting the confidentiality of this information
‚Ä¢ SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and most federal agencies
‚Ä¢ SSA cites the personal nature of the information and its pledge of confidentiality as reasons

column1: ‚Ä¢ SSA's disclosure policy allows sharing limited information with law enforcement under certain conditions

column2: ‚Ä¢ Information is generally limited to verification of name and SSN
‚Ä¢ More information may be provided for investigations involving SSA programs or serious crimes
‚Ä¢ All disclosures must meet specific criteria outlined in SSA's policy

column1: ‚Ä¢ Some SSA field office staff are confused about the disclosure policy, leading to inconsistent application

column2: ‚Ä¢ Requests from law enforcement are infrequent, so staff must often consult the complex policy
‚Ä¢ SSA's responsibilities to assist law enforcement and protect privacy may exacerbate confusion
‚Ä¢ Consistent application cannot be fully assessed as SSA does not maintain aggregated disclosure data

column1: ‚Ä¢ Most law enforcement officials were satisfied with information from SSA, but many wanted more

column2: ‚Ä¢ Name and SSN verification was often helpful, but many wanted additional details
‚Ä¢ Some state and local officials were unfamiliar with SSA's process for obtaining information
‚Ä¢ Many SSA field office and OIG staff agreed the policy was too restrictive

column1: ‚Ä¢ SSA has concerns about expanding its disclosure policy

column2: ‚Ä¢ Officials believe it would hamper SSA's ability to protect privacy and administer programs
‚Ä¢ Balancing privacy and assisting law enforcement are important but sometimes conflicting objectives
‚Ä¢ SSA's complex policy attempts to uphold its privacy pledge while complying with applicable laws

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO recommends SSA take steps to ensure consistent policy application and inform law enforcement

column2: ‚Ä¢ Eliminate staff confusion through training, clarification, or delegating disclosure authority
‚Ä¢ Provide clear information to law enforcement on SSA's disclosure policy and procedures
‚Ä¢ SSA agreed to consider additional training and review public materials on its policy

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
420,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ RCRA establishes national policy for managing hazardous waste to minimize threats to health and environment

column2: ‚Ä¢ Governs hazardous waste from generation to disposal
‚Ä¢ Contains provisions for identifying and listing hazardous waste

column1: ‚Ä¢ Three RCRA requirements cited as creating disincentives for cleanups

column2: ‚Ä¢ Land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements add cost and time
‚Ä¢ Can lead to cleanup remedies that are too stringent or not stringent enough

column1: ‚Ä¢ Land disposal restrictions require waste to be treated to minimize threats before land disposal

column2: ‚Ä¢ Treatment to meet standards may be more stringent and costly than necessary for some waste
‚Ä¢ Can drive use of cleanup technologies more stringent and costly than needed to be protective

column1: ‚Ä¢ Minimum technological requirements establish design and operating specifications for treatment/disposal facilities

column2: ‚Ä¢ Requirements designed for waste from ongoing operations may be too stringent for some remediation waste
‚Ä¢ Disposing of lower-risk remediation waste per requirements adds unnecessary costs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Permit requirements involve substantial documentation and review, increasing costs and delays

column2: ‚Ä¢ Costs to obtain permit can range from $80,000 to $1 million
‚Ä¢ Process to obtain permit is lengthy, typically taking 5-6 years

column1: ‚Ä¢ To avoid triggering RCRA requirements, parties may leave waste in place without treatment

column2: ‚Ä¢ Leaving waste in place, especially ""old waste,"" may pose health or environmental risks
‚Ä¢ Contaminated land is not placed back into productive use

column1: ‚Ä¢ EPA has modified RCRA's application to remediation waste through policy statements and regulatory alternatives

column2: ‚Ä¢ Alternatives have lessened but not solved adverse effects
‚Ä¢ States have varied experience using alternatives; some find them burdensome and overly complicated

column1: ‚Ä¢ In 1996, EPA proposed new rules to more comprehensively reform RCRA's remediation waste requirements

column2: ‚Ä¢ Stakeholders disagree on technical and legal issues associated with proposed rule
‚Ä¢ EPA concluded comprehensive reform can best be addressed through legislation

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO recommends EPA take steps to ensure regulators have consistent understanding of alternatives

column2: ‚Ä¢ Steps could include consolidating alternatives into guidance, training managers, providing legal assistance
‚Ä¢ EPA agrees but notes benefits may be limited until comprehensive legislative reform achieved

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
421,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Before 1996, Medicare program integrity activities were constrained by funding and budget procedures

column2: * Funding constraints reduced contractors' ability to conduct audits and review claims
* HHS advocated for dedicated program integrity funding outside the annual appropriations process
* Fluctuations in funding made it difficult for contractors to retain experienced staff

column1: * HIPAA established MIP in 1997 and provided dedicated funding for program integrity activities

column2: * MIP funds increased from $440 million in 1997 to $720 million in 2003
* MIP funds are used to enter contracts to promote Medicare program integrity
* CMS allocates MIP funds to contractors for claims processing and program integrity activities

column1: * CMS uses MIP funds to support five main program integrity activities

column2: * Audits review cost reports from institutional providers
* Medical review identifies claims for noncovered or medically unnecessary services
* Secondary payer seeks to identify other sources of payment that should pay claims

column1: * CMS increased funding for each program integrity activity from 1997 to 2005

column2: * Provider education received the largest percentage increase in funds
* Audit and medical review received the largest amount of funds overall
* Secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education funding also increased

column1: * CMS's current allocation approach relies primarily on historical funding

column2: * Approach does not fully consider effectiveness, workload, or risk
* CMS lacks quantitative data to compare effectiveness of program integrity activities
* CMS is developing initiatives to measure results of audit and provider education

column1: * CMS has not always allocated funds optimally within program integrity activities

column2: * Funds are not always allocated based on vulnerabilities, workload, and effectiveness
* CMS used relative savings information to allocate funds within secondary payer
* More detailed audit cost information could help CMS allocate funds more effectively

column1: * Medicare is undergoing significant changes that will impact MIP funding allocations

column2: * Part D prescription drug benefit will require new choices in MIP fund allocation
* Contracting reform will change contractors' program integrity responsibilities
* CMS plans to increase MIP funds for contractor award payments tied to performance

column1: * GAO recommends that CMS develop a method to allocate",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
422,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ TSA has taken actions to enhance screener training but faces challenges

column2: ‚Ä¢ Added dual-function screening course and deployed hands-on training tools

column1: ‚Ä¢ TSA lacks adequate internal controls to ensure screeners complete required training

column1: ‚Ä¢ TSA completed first round of annual screener recertification testing

column2: ‚Ä¢ Less than 1% of screeners failed to complete recertification requirements
‚Ä¢ Image recognition not included for checked baggage screeners in first two rounds

column1: ‚Ä¢ TSA developed passenger screener improvement plan but not for checked baggage

column1: ‚Ä¢ TSA established performance measures and indexes for screening systems

column1: ‚Ä¢ TSA faces challenges in delivering training and measuring screener performance

423,"Here is a summary of the source document using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* IRS operates a network of 25 call sites with 10,000 customer service representatives providing 24/7 service

column2: * Calls are routed to sites with shortest hold times for tax law, account services, or refund status questions
* Operations Center is responsible for forecasting call demand, planning call routing, developing staffing requirements, and monitoring network status
* IRS lacks a long-term level-of-service goal based on taxpayer needs and costs/benefits of meeting them

column1: * IRS faces challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives

column2: * Difficulties include job characteristics, keeping representatives proficient, retaining skilled staff, and scheduling to meet forecasted requirements
* IRS is developing a national recruiting strategy and refocusing training, but lacks a system to identify individual refresher training needs
* IRS does not actively monitor attrition and determine steps to address it

column1: * IRS faces challenges in effectively scheduling staff due to inaccurate demand forecasting and complicated scheduling

column2: * During first 6 months of FY2000, call sites were over/understaffed 60% of the time compared to established tolerances
* IRS is adapting an automated system used by other organizations to facilitate forecasting, scheduling, and tracking adherence
* However, the system is not yet fully operational and restructuring could cause further delays

column1: * IRS evaluates human capital practices to make improvements, but evaluations do not assess how practices affect ability to achieve service goals

column2: * Evaluations focus on short-term adjustments rather than strategic planning
* Unlike IRS, some organizations evaluate how changes in one practice affect other practices and overall telephone assistance results
* IRS lacks a basis for assessing the soundness of its human capital practices without considering their contribution to service goals

column1: * GAO recommends the IRS Commissioner take steps to improve human capital management practices:

column2: * Establish long-term and annual service-level goals based on taxpayer needs and obtain stakeholder support
* Establish a system to assess competency gaps and meet identified refresher training needs
* Develop a system to monitor attrition, identify causes, and develop strategies to deal with it
* Ensure evalu",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

‚Ä¢ Options exist to help Ginnie Mae avoid rationing its commitment authority

425,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ DOD has reversed $592 million of $615 million in illegal or improper closed account adjustments from FY 2000

column2: ‚Ä¢ Reversing the adjustments revealed additional accounting problems requiring detailed reviews
‚Ä¢ 30 contracts with $457 million in reversed transactions will take over 21,000 hours to correct
‚Ä¢ DOD plans to complete reaudits to correct FY 2000 adjustments by September 30, 2002
‚Ä¢ Air Force is investigating a contract with a $79 million illegal adjustment for possible Antideficiency Act violations

column1: ‚Ä¢ DOD made $172 million in illegal or improper closed account adjustments in FY 2001 out of $291 million reviewed

column2: ‚Ä¢ DOD agreed to reverse and correct the $172 million in adjustments
‚Ä¢ DOD plans to review an additional $1.1 billion of FY 2001 closed account adjustments
‚Ä¢ Reaudits and corrections for FY 2001 adjustments are planned to be completed by September 2004
‚Ä¢ Lack of controls and oversight led to illegal adjustments to maximize use of funds

column1: ‚Ä¢ DOD implemented controls in FY 2002 that reduced closed account adjustments by 80% in the first 6 months compared to FY 2001

column2: ‚Ä¢ Controls prevent illegal backward and forward adjustments
‚Ä¢ Default payment allocation method changed from ""oldest funds first"" to proration
‚Ä¢ $253,212 in illegal adjustments still processed due to one computer terminal not having proper controls
‚Ä¢ DOD's inability to accurately account for disbursements are long-term, complex problems

column1: ‚Ä¢ Contracts with numerous Accounting Classification Reference Numbers (ACRNs) and changes in payment allocation terms contribute to payment errors and adjustments

column2: ‚Ä¢ 101 contracts reviewed had an average of 74 ACRNs per contract
‚Ä¢ Even simple purchases can require extensive rework if assigned many ACRNs
‚Ä¢ Contract modifications changing payment allocations across ACRNs compound the problems
‚Ä¢ DOD has started writing contracts with more specific payment terms to reduce errors

column1: ‚Ä¢ Options for Congress include taking no legislative action or prohibiting adjustments to closed accounts

column2: ‚Ä¢ Taking no action",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 426,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Internet relies on the domain name system (DNS) to ensure unique addresses

column2: ‚Ä¢ The U.S. government supported DNS implementation and began transitioning it to the private sector in 1998

column1: ‚Ä¢ ICANN was created to take over DNS management

column2: ‚Ä¢ ICANN made progress on increasing competition but has been slow to improve security and representation

column1: ‚Ä¢ ICANN's president concluded in 2002 that the organization faced serious problems and needed reform

column2: ‚Ä¢ An internal committee was established to recommend reform options

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Department of Commerce (DOC) has oversight of the transition but its public assessment has been limited

column2: ‚Ä¢ DOC states it would not intervene in ICANN unless its actions were inconsistent with the memorandum of understanding (MOU)

column1: ‚Ä¢ The effort to privatize DNS management has reached a critical juncture

column2: ‚Ä¢ Congress recommends that the Secretary of Commerce issue a status report on the transition progress and timeframe

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Internet is not controlled by a single entity and relies on voluntary standardized protocols

column2: ‚Ä¢ The hierarchical domain name system uses root servers to help direct queries and translate names to numerical addresses

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
427,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820

column2: * The General Allotment Act of 1887 divided Indian tribal lands into allotments for individual tribal members and families
* The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the period the federal government would hold allotted lands in trust

column1: * The Secretary of the Interior is required to account for revenue generated by each interest in the allotted lands

column2: * Much of this responsibility has been delegated to the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA)
* Beginning in 1997, Interior has issued several strategic plans for implementing trust reforms

column1: * In 2003, Interior issued the Comprehensive Trust Management Plan and the As-Is Trust Business Model Report

column2: * These documents serve as the foundation for the Fiduciary Trust Model, which contains implementation strategies for major business processes
* The Fiduciary Trust Model currently serves as Interior's guide for trust reform

column1: * In 2001, Interior contracted with Electronic Data Systems to determine how trust reforms were being conducted and how they could be improved

column2: * In response to the firm's recommendations, the Secretary of the Interior reorganized BIA and the Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) in 2003
* OST's budget and staff have grown significantly from 1997 to 2006 to support trust reform efforts and other Indian-related activities

column1: * OST has implemented several key trust fund management reforms

column2: * However, OST has not prepared a timetable for completing its remaining trust reform activities
* OST also has not identified a date for its termination under the 1994 American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act

column1: * OST is responsible for trust reforms associated with the trust funds accounting system and the integration of trust reform automated systems

column2: * BIA and OST are responsible for reforms associated with the Trust Asset and Accounting Management System (TAAMS) for managing land title records and leasing activities
* The National Business Center is responsible for developing an appraisal management system for Indian land appraisals

column1: * OST managers plan to implement two additional trust reforms beyond those scheduled for completion by November 2007

column2: *",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

‚Ä¢ The departments have made progress but still face challenges in achieving their long-term goal of a virtual lifetime electronic record

429,"Here is a summary of the source document using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality

column2: ‚Ä¢ Standards address scope, techniques, conclusions, reports, time management, and workpaper preparation
‚Ä¢ Each standard has one or more key elements
‚Ä¢ Workpapers provide documentation on audit scope and diligence

column1: ‚Ä¢ Audit workpapers assist in planning, record procedures and evidence, support conclusions, and provide basis for review

column2: ‚Ä¢ Primary tool to control quality is supervisory review of ongoing audit work by group managers
‚Ä¢ After audit closes, IRS uses Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) to assess compliance with audit standards
‚Ä¢ To pass a standard, the audit must pass all key elements

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO's observations based on 1996-1997 work on IRS' use of financial status audit techniques

column2: ‚Ä¢ Reviewed random sample of 354 audits from population of 421,000
‚Ä¢ Sample focused on frequency of financial status audit techniques rather than workpaper adequacy
‚Ä¢ Several cases identified where workpapers did not meet IRS standard

column1: ‚Ä¢ IRS audit workpaper standard requires workpapers to support auditor's conclusions

column2: ‚Ä¢ GAO found IRS auditors did not always meet the workpaper standard requirements
‚Ä¢ Examples of problems: tax adjustments not agreeing, missing documents, incomplete or illegible workpapers
‚Ä¢ EQMS evaluations indicate no more than 72% of audits met all key elements of workpaper standard from 1992-1997

column1: ‚Ä¢ Workpapers are important for formulating findings, serving as quality control, and supporting adjustments

column2: ‚Ä¢ Inadequate workpapers may result in more work or overturned adjustments
‚Ä¢ IRS' primary quality control is supervisory review, but GAO found limited documentation of this in sampled audits
‚Ä¢ IRM requires group manager review but not documentation; draft changes may address this

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO estimated only 6% of sampled audits had documentation of group manager review

column2: ‚Ä¢ If assuming all unagreed audits were reviewed, estimate increases to 26%
‚Ä¢ In unagreed audits, only 12% had documentation of review before taxpayer notification
‚Ä¢ IRS officials noted other",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 430,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Congress authorized the Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program in 1983 to enhance counterterrorism skills of partner nations

column2: * ATA offers training courses and equipment grants
* Appropriations increased significantly from 2000 to 2007

column1: * The Coordinator for Counterterrorism (S/CT) and Bureau of Diplomatic Security (DS/T/ATA) have key roles in ATA

column2: * S/CT leads initial assessments of partner nations' needs
* DS/T/ATA develops annual country-specific plans

column1: * S/CT provides minimal policy guidance to DS/T/ATA for determining assistance priorities

column2: * S/CT places countries on a tiered priority list
* Other factors beyond the list also influence which countries receive assistance

column1: * DS/T/ATA did not systematically use needs assessments and program reviews for planning assistance

column2: * Assessments had weaknesses and inconsistencies
* In-country officials did not consistently use or find the assessments useful

column1: * S/CT has mechanisms to coordinate ATA with other U.S. counterterrorism efforts

column2: * S/CT chairs interagency meetings and established the Regional Strategic Initiative
* No significant duplication was found in the four countries visited

column1: * State took action to define ATA goals and measures but did not systematically assess sustainability

column2: * State developed specific goals and measures for ATA's mandated objectives
* S/CT and DS/T/ATA lacked clear measures and processes for assessing sustainability

column1: * State has not complied with a mandate to report to Congress on all U.S. counterterrorism assistance since 1996

column2: * State submitted ATA annual reports instead of the broader required report
* Officials noted confusion over requirements and difficulty compiling all assistance

column1: * ATA annual reports contained inaccurate data and lacked systematic assessments of program results

column2: * Reports had discrepancies in numbers of students trained and courses offered
* Reports varied in content and format and did not systematically assess performance

column1: * Deficiencies in ATA guidance, management, implementation and assessment could limit program effectiveness

column2: * Minimal S/CT guidance makes it difficult to align assistance with policy goals",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 431,"Here is a summary of the source text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* There are two approaches for reorganizing or terminating large financial companies:

column2: * Judicial bankruptcy process under Chapters 7 or 11 of the Bankruptcy Code
* Special legal and regulatory resolution regimes for insured depository institutions and insurance companies

column1: * The Bankruptcy Code provides for equitable treatment of creditors and allows business debtors to seek liquidation or reorganization

column2: * Regulators often play a role in financial company bankruptcies
* Safe harbor provisions allow counterparties to exercise contractual rights for qualified financial contracts

column1: * Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) under the Dodd-Frank Act allows FDIC to resolve large financial companies outside of bankruptcy

column2: * FDIC proposed a Single Point of Entry (SPOE) approach for resolving systemically important financial institutions
* OLA uses a regulatory approach while bankruptcy reform bills maintain a judicial approach

column1: * The resolution of globally active large financial firms faces complex international legal and operational challenges

column2: * Insolvency laws vary across countries and some lack tools to share information and cooperate with foreign authorities
* The U.S. adopted Chapter 15 of the Bankruptcy Code to promote coordination in cross-border insolvencies

column1: * Two bills were introduced in the 113th Congress to address challenges with reorganizing large financial firms under Chapter 11

column2: * The bills contained provisions affecting the role of regulators, treatment of qualified financial contracts, and designation of judges
* Neither bill was signed into law nor re-introduced in the current Congress

column1: * Some experts suggest modifying safe harbor provisions could help avoid rapid loss of asset values, while others argue it could cause systemic risk

column2: * A proposal to repeal safe harbor provisions was neither signed into law nor re-introduced
* Experts disagree on the impact of repealing safe harbor provisions on financial stability

column1: * While structural challenges remain, regulatory actions are being taken to facilitate orderly cross-border resolutions

column2: * The Federal Reserve and FDIC have taken actions to address obstacles to global cooperation
* International bodies have issued principles and requirements for resolution regimes and derivatives contracts

column1: * GAO has reported on the status of bankruptcy proceedings for Lehman Brothers, MF Global, and Washington Mutual

column2: * Additional payments",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 432,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The electricity industry has four main functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations

column2: * Utilities and others own and operate electricity assets like power plants, power lines, and substations
* System operators manage the flow of electricity to balance supply and demand

column1: * The electricity grid is being modernized with new technologies to make it a ""smart grid""

column2: * Smart grid technologies include advanced metering infrastructure, transmission and distribution monitoring, and control systems
* Smart grid systems are expected to improve reliability, efficiency, integration of renewables, and attack detection and response

column1: * Federal and state authorities oversee the electricity industry

column2: * FERC regulates interstate transmission and wholesale electricity sales
* State public utility commissions regulate local distribution and retail electricity sales

column1: * Cyber threats to the electricity industry are growing and evolving

column2: * Threats can be unintentional (e.g. natural disasters, equipment failures) or intentional (e.g. criminal groups, nation-states)
* The growing use of IT systems and networks increases the attack surface and introduces new vulnerabilities

column1: * Multiple entities are working to secure the electricity grid against cyber threats

column2: * NERC develops and enforces cybersecurity standards for the bulk power system
* NIST, DHS, and DOE provide cybersecurity guidance and support to the electricity subsector

column1: * Key cybersecurity challenges remain for the electricity industry

column2: * Challenges include monitoring implementation of voluntary standards, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, and establishing security metrics
* GAO has made recommendations to FERC to address these challenges, some of which have been implemented

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
433,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Mission-critical skills gaps in the federal workforce pose a high risk to the nation

column2: ‚Ä¢ Gaps can be due to insufficient number of people or lack of appropriate skills
‚Ä¢ Current budget pressures and potential wave of retirements could worsen skills gaps
‚Ä¢ Over 34% of federal employees will be eligible to retire by 2020

column1: ‚Ä¢ Problems exist across various federal personnel systems and functions

column2: ‚Ä¢ Classification system has not kept pace with evolving requirements
‚Ä¢ Recruiting and hiring processes need to be more applicant-friendly and flexible
‚Ä¢ Pay system rewards length of service rather than performance

column1: ‚Ä¢ Federal jobs require more advanced skills compared to 30 years ago

column2: ‚Ä¢ Professional, administrative, and technical roles have increased
‚Ä¢ Federal workforce is more highly educated on average than private sector
‚Ä¢ Agencies given pay exemptions for more flexibility in setting market-based pay

column1: ‚Ä¢ Agencies have tools to build high-performing workforce but need accountability

column2: ‚Ä¢ Effective use of available tools is important, with tone set by agency leaders
‚Ä¢ OPM has taken steps like finalizing the Human Capital Framework regulation
‚Ä¢ Areas needing attention include hiring, classification, and managing performance

column1: ‚Ä¢ Human resource capacity issues hinder strategic human capital management

column2: ‚Ä¢ Many HR offices focused on transactional activities vs. strategic priorities
‚Ä¢ Lack of HR capacity adversely impacts agencies' ability to fulfill missions
‚Ä¢ OPM leading efforts to improve HR specialist skills but more progress needed
