497,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ OPM's mission is to manage the federal employee retirement program, but its retirement modernization initiatives have faced challenges since 1987

column2: ‚Ä¢ Multiple attempts to automate antiquated paper-based processes have failed due to management weaknesses

column1: ‚Ä¢ As of March 2009, OPM has only partially implemented 2 of 8 planned modernization capabilities

column2: ‚Ä¢ The remaining 6 capabilities have not been implemented and future plans are uncertain

column1: ‚Ä¢ OPM lacks a complete plan for the restructured RetireEZ program to guide future modernization efforts

column2: ‚Ä¢ Various reports and documents describe planned activities but do not provide a comprehensive plan

column1: ‚Ä¢ OPM has significant management weaknesses in cost estimating, earned value management, requirements management, testing, and program oversight

column2: ‚Ä¢ These weaknesses have persisted and put the retirement modernization program at risk of failure

column1: ‚Ä¢ OPM has not completed key steps to develop a reliable cost estimate for the restructured program

column2: ‚Ä¢ Initial steps like defining the estimate's purpose and determining the estimating structure are incomplete

column1: ‚Ä¢ OPM is not prepared to perform reliable earned value management reporting on the restructured program's progress

column2: ‚Ä¢ A credible cost estimate and validated performance measurement baseline have not been established

column1: ‚Ä¢ OPM has begun revising system requirements but lacks a requirements management plan and key processes

column2: ‚Ä¢ Insufficiently detailed requirements and inadequate management contributed to past program issues

column1: ‚Ä¢ OPM has not begun planning test activities in coordination with developing requirements for the restructured program

column2: ‚Ä¢ Lack of early test planning increases the risk of deploying a system that does not meet user needs

column1: ‚Ä¢ OPM's oversight bodies have been ineffective in monitoring the program and ensuring corrective actions are taken

column2: ‚Ä¢ Management weaknesses have been allowed to persist without adequate oversight and guidance for addressing deficiencies

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
498,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The number of school-aged children with limited English proficiency (LEP) in the U.S. has grown dramatically over the last 2 decades

column2: * LEP student enrollment grew exponentially between 1989-90 and 1997-98 despite small growth in total K-12 enrollment

column1: * The Bilingual Education Act (BEA) of 1968 aims to educate LEP students to reach the same academic standards as all students

column2: * The 1994 BEA reauthorization created 4 bilingual education grant programs to distribute funds to school districts serving LEP children

column1: * The Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs (OBEMLA) administers the 4 competitive bilingual education grant programs

column2: * In FY2000, Education funded about 28% of the 665 applications received, awarding 18 Systemwide, 75 Comprehensive, and 92 PDI grants

column1: * The 107th Congress is considering several bills as it deliberates BEA reauthorization in FY2001

column2: * One bill recommends eliminating the 4 grant programs while another seeks to increase funding and consolidate them into a single program

column1: * All 4 bilingual education programs share the same performance goals, measures, eligibility criteria, and allow similar uses of funds

column2: * The programs target LEP students in K-12 to help them reach high academic standards through bilingual or special alternative education

column1: * The effectiveness of the 4 bilingual education programs nationally is unknown because locally collected data are not comparable

column2: * Grantees use different assessment tests and define terms differently, so student outcome data are not comparable among grantees or nationally

column1: * The 4 bilingual education programs lend themselves to consolidation as they share the same goals, target the same students, and provide similar services

column2: * Program consolidation would allow Education to redirect resources used to manage 4 separate grant competitions to other activities

column1: * Consolidating the 4 programs into one would likely result in small federal cost savings, if any

column2: * Congressional appropriations are made as a single line item for the 4 programs, so eliminating programs may not change the funding level

column1: *",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
499,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ NCIC is an FBI-maintained criminal justice information system that serves as a repository of data on crimes and criminals

column2: ‚Ä¢ Over 92,000 law enforcement agencies have access to NCIC

column1: ‚Ä¢ CSA audit approaches for assessing LEA compliance with the 2-hour requirement varied, raising questions about the reliability of compliance information

column2: ‚Ä¢ Some CSAs were not using the 2-hour criterion to assess timeliness

‚Ä¢ Lack of minimum audit standards from CJIS and the Board contributes to the inconsistent CSA audit approaches

column1: ‚Ä¢ Officials from 8 of 9 LEAs identified custody disputes and coordination with child welfare as potential impediments to timely reporting

column2: ‚Ä¢ Determining custodial arrangements or waiting for court paperwork can delay reporting
‚Ä¢ Lack of information from foster-care group homes can delay reporting and investigation
‚Ä¢ DOJ, NCMEC, and other organizations have developed guidance to address these issues

column1: ‚Ä¢ CJIS and OJJDP could use existing mechanisms to assess the extent of LEA challenges and share successful mitigation approaches

column2: ‚Ä¢ CJIS Advisory Policy Board working groups and subcommittees could obtain information on challenges
‚Ä¢ CJIS annual training and OJJDP-funde",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 500,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Automobile crashes cause nearly 29,000 fatalities annually in the US

column2: ‚Ä¢ NHTSA has the lead role in federal efforts to reduce crashes and minimize consequences
‚Ä¢ Fatality rates vary by automobile type and driver characteristics

column1: ‚Ä¢ Crash type, severity, automobile size, safety belt use, and occupant age and gender affect injury likelihood

column2: ‚Ä¢ One-car rollover crashes have the highest driver injury rates
‚Ä¢ Heavier cars are generally safer except in rollover crashes

column1: ‚Ä¢ Women drivers have a higher injury risk than men drivers

column2: ‚Ä¢ Women are injured more in multi-vehicle collisions while men are injured more in single-vehicle crashes
‚Ä¢ Safety belts may be less effective for women than men

column1: ‚Ä¢ Drivers age 65+ have a much higher injury risk than younger drivers

column2: ‚Ä¢ Older drivers are injured primarily in multi-vehicle collisions
‚Ä¢ The inherent frailty of older drivers makes it difficult to reduce the injury gap with younger drivers

column1: ‚Ä¢ NHTSA is implementing new safety regulations but some approaches could be improved

column2: ‚Ä¢ Requiring air bags and automatic safety belts would provide the greatest aggregate safety benefit
‚Ä¢ Crash tests should use dummies of different sizes, not just an average male dummy

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: * The Coast Guard's FY 2008 budget request of $8.73 billion reflects a smaller increase than previous years, with reduced spending on new acquisitions like Deepwater in favor of reorganizing internal operations and support command infrastructure

column2: * Despite meeting fewer performance targets, overall trends remain positive for most Coast Guard mission programs

column2: * The Coast Guard is also pursuing organizational changes to acquisitions, deployable specialized forces, and overall command structure to improve mission execution and oversight

502,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Families First offices experiencing organizational changes and staffing shortfalls
‚Ä¢ Lack of stakeholder agreement on some program elements like business rules and DPS functions

column1: ‚Ä¢ Despite DOD focus, long-standing problems in personal property program persist

column1: 503,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Tobacco is a high-value, pesticide-intensive crop in the U.S. and globally

column2: ‚Ä¢ Tobacco ranks 9th in crop value and 6th in pesticide use per acre in the U.S.
‚Ä¢ The U.S. is the 3rd largest tobacco exporter and 2nd largest cigarette producer
‚Ä¢ Over 90% of tobacco grown in the U.S. and globally is used for cigarettes
‚Ä¢ 37 pesticides were commonly used on U.S. tobacco in the 1990s

column1: ‚Ä¢ EPA conducts health risk assessments of pesticides used on tobacco

column2: ‚Ä¢ Assessments evaluate toxicity and residue levels on tobacco and in smoke
‚Ä¢ EPA generally finds low residue levels in smoke do not require mitigation
‚Ä¢ EPA's approach to assessing tobacco pesticide risks has become more formal
‚Ä¢ Documentation of EPA's residue data evaluations was inconsistently available

column1: ‚Ä¢ USDA regulates and tests for residues of pesticides not approved for tobacco use

column2: ‚Ä¢ Testing ensures trade equity and protects from highly toxic pesticide residues
‚Ä¢ Less than 1% of tested domestic and imported tobacco exceeds residue limits
‚Ä¢ USDA has not updated the list of pesticides it regulates and tests since 1989
‚Ä¢ GAO recommends USDA periodically review and update its pesticide testing

column1: ‚Ä¢ EPA and USDA do not regulate residues of approved pesticides on tobacco

column2: ‚Ä¢ Tobacco is not a food crop, so approved pesticide residues are not limited
‚Ä¢ Three major tobacco-importing countries do set limits on approved pesticides
‚Ä¢ Limited data shows residue levels on U.S. tobacco vary relative to other limits
‚Ä¢ The portion of U.S. tobacco tested by USDA has declined as marketing changed

column1: ‚Ä¢ Pesticides used on tobacco pose risks especially to workers who handle them

column2: ‚Ä¢ Long-term effects of low-level exposures to pesticides are not well understood
‚Ä¢ Risks from tobacco use itself are thought to dwarf those of pesticide residues
‚Ä¢ Better documentation has made EPA more accountable for its risk assessments
‚Ä¢ GAO examined EPA's risk assessment process and found it",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 504,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ User fees can help assign costs to readily identifiable users of federal programs

column2: ‚Ä¢ Fees represent a charge for a service or benefit received from a government program
‚Ä¢ Payers expect a link between payments and cost/quality of the related service

column1: ‚Ä¢ The beneficiary-pays principle suggests costs should be assigned based on benefits

column2: ‚Ä¢ If a program primarily benefits the public, it should be supported by general revenue
‚Ä¢ If a program primarily benefits users, it should be funded by fees

column1: ‚Ä¢ Setting fee rates requires determining program costs and assigning costs among users

column2: ‚Ä¢ Fees can be set using average cost or marginal cost
‚Ä¢ User-specific fees vs. systemwide fees involve trade-offs between efficiency and admin costs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Striking a balance between compliance and administrative costs is key when collecting fees

column2: ‚Ä¢ Point-of-sale/service collection decreases admin costs but may not ensure compliance
‚Ä¢ Billing users adds admin costs but may be necessary in some cases

column1: ‚Ä¢ Congress determines agency access to fee collections, balancing oversight and flexibility

column2: ‚Ä¢ Annual appropriations of fee collections allow regular Congressional oversight
‚Ä¢ Permanent or direct access to collections gives agencies more flexibility to respond to needs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Regular fee reviews and stakeholder input improve transparency and acceptance of fees

column2: ‚Ä¢ Reviews help ensure fees remain aligned with program costs and activities
‚Ä¢ Stakeholder input is important since government is often a monopoly supplier of services

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
505,"Here is a summary of the text using 2 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The District of Columbia's school system enrolled over 72,300 students in 2009-2010 across 58 local educational agencies, including D.C. Public Schools (DCPS) and 57 public charter schools

column2: * The Office of the State Superintendent of Education (OSSE) and DCPS received nearly $190 million in federal payments from 2004-2009 to expand charter schools and improve public education

column1: * GAO found that while OSSE and DCPS expended federal payments on a range of school improvement activities, they lacked detailed information on the use of some funds and had weaknesses in their monitoring of grants and contracts

column2: * GAO made recommendations for OSSE and DCPS to establish and implement written policies and procedures to ensure funds are appropriately and consistently monitored

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
506,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Agencies may not fully link budgets to strategic goals or consider resource limitations

column2: ‚Ä¢ Service budgets allocated based on historical percentages rather than strategic assessments
‚Ä¢ Capabilities based on individual service wants versus collective, affordable defense needs
‚Ä¢ Agencies overpromise and underdeliver on major systems in terms of capabilities, costs, quantities, and schedule
‚Ä¢ ""Plug and pray approach"" used when costs escalate, relying on Congress for more funding

column1: ‚Ä¢ Contracts often lack definitive requirements and do not accurately reflect project complexity or allocate risk

column1: ‚Ä¢ Inadequate oversight and lack of accountability for recurring, systemic problems

column1: 507,"Here is the summary with 8 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* DOD sets a standard price per barrel for fuel charged to customers, estimated to approximate actual price during budget execution

column2: * Standard price based on crude oil price forecast, refinement markup, and nonproduct costs
* Differences between estimated and actual fuel costs accounted for by fuel price fluctuations and differences between estimated and actual consumption

column1: * DOD has taken actions to manage fluctuations in Defense-wide Working Capital Fund cash balance caused by differences in estimated and actual fuel costs

column2: * Actions included transferring funds into the Working Capital Fund from other accounts
* DOD also adjusted the standard price charged to fuel customers to manage cash balance

column1: * DOD has studied aspects of its bulk fuel program since 2004 but has not updated approach for setting standard price

column2: * Studies reviewed alternatives for managing Working Capital Fund balances
* DOD has not reevaluated using WTI crude oil price given changes in market conditions

column1: * DOD's assumptions for setting crude oil component of standard price do not reflect current market conditions

column2: * Assumptions do not consider differences between crude oil benchmarks, domestic and international prices, and decreasing relationship between crude and refined prices
* Other agencies like EIA have shifted from WTI to Brent crude oil prices

column1: * DOD has not fully documented rationale and assumptions for establishing each component of the standard price

column2: * GAO Cost Estimating Guide states estimate should be supported by detailed documentation on methodology and data limitations
* DOD has not documented rationale for continuing to select WTI or factors considered in setting refinement markup

column1: * Reevaluating approach for estimating standard price components would allow DOD to develop more informed estimates and minimize risks from changing market conditions

column2: * Documenting rationale for assumptions would provide greater transparency on DOD's process
* GAO recommends DOD reevaluate approach for estimating standard price components and document assumptions

column1: * DOD concurred with recommendation to reevaluate approach, stating it continually evaluates methods to better estimate fuel price

column2: * DOD noted challenges due to rate-setting process taking place in advance of execution and fuel market volatility
* However, DOD did not specify initiatives to reevaluate approach for estimating standard price components

508,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* DOD's procurement process spans numerous agencies and services, beginning with a requirement and ending at contract closeout

column2: * In 1994, DOD initiated the Standard Procurement System (SPS) program to acquire a single automated system for all contract management functions
* SPS was to be deployed in incremental releases, with 4 releases deployed so far to 773 locations supporting 21,900 users
* The 5th release was sent back for rework due to deficiencies and has not been deployed

column1: * DOD has not met key SPS commitments regarding timing of delivery, user satisfaction, and use of a commercial solution

column2: * The fully operational milestone has slipped by 3.5 years with further delays likely
* 60% of surveyed users were dissatisfied with SPS functionality and performance
* Extensive modifications were made to the chosen commercial product, resulting in a DOD-unique solution

column1: * DOD does not know if SPS is meeting expectations for benefits like cost savings, standardization, and reducing problem disbursements

column2: * Only 2 of the original 76 legacy systems have been retired, with unclear cost savings
* Each military service is developing its own unique procurement processes rather than standardizing
* There is no evidence that SPS has reduced problem disbursements as originally claimed

column1: * DOD has not economically justified investing in SPS as its own analysis shows life-cycle benefits are less than costs

column2: * The 1997 and 2000 economic analyses estimated costs exceed benefits, with a negative return on investment
* Most cost estimates were carried forward from 1997 without updating for program changes
* The latest analysis in 2000 is outdated and does not reflect the current program status and risks

column1: * DOD is not approaching its SPS investment incrementally to spread risks over smaller, manageable components

column2: * Investment decisions are not being made for each release based on costs, benefits, and risks
* Actual benefits and costs are not being measured for completed releases to inform subsequent decisions
* DOD risks spending large sums on SPS before knowing if it will produce commensurate value

509,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* USCIS is responsible for processing immigration benefit applications and detecting fraud

column2: * In fiscal year 2005, USCIS received 6.3 million applications and adjudicated 7.5 million
* USCIS had about 3,000 adjudicators in service centers and district offices in fiscal year 2005

column1: * Immigration benefit fraud is accomplished by submitting fraudulent documents or false claims

column2: * Fraudulent schemes can result in large profits for criminals
* Some individuals seeking benefits pose national security and public safety threats

column1: * USCIS data indicates immigration benefit fraud is a serious problem

column2: * In fiscal year 2005, USCIS denied over 20,000 applications due to detected fraud
* Other agencies like the State Department and Department of Labor also find significant fraud

column1: * USCIS has taken some actions to detect fraud, but has not fully implemented internal controls and best practices

column2: * USCIS established the Office of Fraud Detection and National Security (FDNS) as a focal point
* FDNS outlined a fraud detection strategy and is conducting fraud assessments

column1: * USCIS lacks a comprehensive risk management approach and other internal control mechanisms

column2: * FDNS fraud assessments are limited and do not incorporate full threat and consequence information
* USCIS lacks clear guidance on balancing fraud prevention with other objectives

column1: * DHS does not actively use administrative sanctions available in the Immigration and Nationality Act

column2: * Most benefit fraud is not criminally prosecuted due to resource constraints
* A 1998 court ruling hampered INS procedures for civil document fraud penalties

column1: * GAO made six recommendations to the Secretary of Homeland Security to enhance USCIS's fraud detection efforts

column2: * Expand the risk management approach with more assessments and threat/consequence analysis
* Implement a feedback mechanism to address identified fraud vulnerabilities

column1: * DHS agreed with four recommendations and cited actions indicating two are already in place

column2: * DHS will expand fraud assessments, enhance adjudicator access to information, and study sanctions
* DHS believes a feedback mechanism exists and that leadership advocates balancing objectives

column1: * GAO believes DHS and USCIS are moving in the right",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 511,"Here is a summary of the source document using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Medicaid established in 1965 as federal-state program for low-income persons

column2: * States design own programs subject to federal requirements
* Federal government pays portion of state Medicaid expenditures
* States can obtain waivers from HCFA to move to managed care

column1: * Tennessee received waiver in 1993 to move Medicaid to statewide demonstration

column2: * First state to move entire Medicaid program to managed care
* Interviews conducted with state officials, MCOs, providers, advocates
* Financial data obtained from MCOs and state insurance department

column1: * TennCare designed to expand coverage and control costs

column2: * Allowed non-Medicaid eligible uninsured persons to enroll
* Set capitation rates substantially below historical Medicaid costs
* Discontinued Medicaid DSH program, established smaller fund

column1: * In first year, TennCare expanded coverage and controlled costs

column2: * Over 400,000 uninsured enrolled in addition to 800,000 Medicaid
* Expenditures less than 1% over prior year despite enrollment increase
* Monitoring of access and quality delayed due to MCO data issues

column1: * Capitation rate setting methodology questioned

column2: * Rates 25% below projected fee-for-service costs per consultants
* Not based on actuarial methods, lacked documentation
* Regional cost variations and administrative costs not considered

column1: * Many MCOs reported losses in first year even with supplemental payments

column2: * 5 of 12 MCOs covering 60% of enrollees reported losses
* Largest MCO reported $8.8 million loss
* Supplemental payments to MCOs expected to be reduced

column1: * TennCare's impact on providers uncertain but appears negative

column2: * Analyses inconclusive but suggest hospitals incurred losses
* Most physicians reported being worse off financially vs Medicaid
* Lower reimbursement rates and administrative burdens cited

column1: * Rapid implementation led to problems and confusion

column2: * State and MCOs lacked experience with managed care
* Communication issues affected beneficiaries and providers
* Delays in enrollment, claims processing, premium collections",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

516,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

column1: 517,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* DOD launched the Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative in 1989 to improve business practices and eliminate redundant information systems

column2: * Initial efforts focused on integrating systems across DOD
* Scope later broadened to include all DOD functional areas
* Primary objective is to improve business processes through reengineering and continuous process improvements

column1: * The Joint Logistics System Center (JLSC) was established to achieve CIM goals for materiel management and depot maintenance

column2: * JLSC serves as a facilitator while the services and DLA design, develop, and implement new corporate logistics systems
* JLSC implemented some near-term initiatives that resulted in cost savings
* DOD later directed JLSC to focus on selecting and testing migration information systems

column1: * DOD believes selecting common information systems is necessary to enable functional integration and establish a foundation for process improvements

column2: * Concerns exist that this approach may delay significant process improvements and result in systems that don't meet operational needs
* Some DLA officials believe the migration system focus is impacting their ability to implement innovative pilot projects
* Accelerated migration system schedule adds risk but is seen by JLSC as necessary to force implementation

column1: * JLSC selected 32 migration systems for materiel management and depot maintenance

column2: * Selection process involved consensus among service, DLA, and JLSC representatives
* JLSC also began documenting current processes to identify improvement opportunities
* JLSC used its review authority to eliminate redundant funding requests for logistics systems

column1: * Three critical impediments are jeopardizing JLSC's ability to implement its CIM strategy

column2: * Some DOD managers have not fully accepted CIM, viewing it as a threat to their authority
* DOD has not integrated its various CIM efforts, leading to potential duplication and conflicts
* Program management authority is unclear due to confusing DOD guidance

519,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ DOD relies on research labs, industry, and academia to develop new technologies, but has problems transitioning them to real use

column2: ‚Ä¢ Technologies may not leave the lab due to lack of demonstrated potential or recognition
‚Ä¢ Acquisition programs may be unwilling to fund final development stages or prefer to develop technologies themselves
‚Ä¢ DOD's budgeting process makes it difficult to seize opportunities for introducing technological advances

column1: ‚Ä¢ DOD has established several ""technology transition"" programs to address transition challenges

column2: ‚Ä¢ Advanced Concept Technology Demonstration (ACTD) program allows military operators to test prototypes
‚Ä¢ Foreign Comparative Testing (FCT) Program identifies and procures mature technologies from other countries
‚Ä¢ Other programs include Manufacturing Technology Program (MANTECH) and Dual Use Science and Technology

column1: ‚Ä¢ Three recent initiatives are the Technology Transition Initiative (TTI), Defense Acquisition Challenge Program (DACP), and Quick Reaction Fund

column2: ‚Ä¢ TTI focuses on speeding transition of DOD S&T programs into acquisition
‚Ä¢ DACP introduces innovative, cost-saving technologies from inside and outside DOD
‚Ä¢ Quick Reaction Fund supports field testing of technology prototypes

column1: ‚Ä¢ The programs have reported benefits in performance, affordability, manufacturability, and operational capability

column2: ‚Ä¢ DACP is also expanding the defense industrial base by inviting non-traditional partners
‚Ä¢ However, it is too early to determine overall impact due to few completed projects and limited performance measures

column1: ‚Ä¢ Effective technology transition requires sound selection, management and oversight, and assessment processes

column2: ‚Ä¢ DACP has well-defined processes for selecting and managing projects
‚Ä¢ TTI has disciplined selection but less formal management and oversight
‚Ä¢ Quick Reaction Fund is the least formal, relying on flexibility and senior management attention

column1: ‚Ä¢ The transition programs have limited performance measures to gauge progress and return on investment

column2: ‚Ä¢ After action reports are collected but not consistently
‚Ä¢ Officials agree more should be done to capture return on investment information
‚Ä¢ Other transition programs like FCT and ACTD have developed metrics that could serve as starting points

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO recommends actions to strengthen the transition programs:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Develop data and measures to assess performance and return on investment
‚Ä¢ Implement formal feedback mechanisms and agreements
‚Ä¢ Improve communication to",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

521,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Clean Air Act of 1963 regulates air pollution and was significantly amended in 1970, 1977, and 1990

column2: ‚Ä¢ The 1990 amendments established new programs to control acid rain, urban air pollution, and toxic air emissions

column1: ‚Ä¢ EPA has completed most of the 452 required actions under Titles I, III, and IV of the 1990 amendments

column2: ‚Ä¢ Many requirements were met late due to their number, scope, and complexity, as well as challenges EPA faced

column1: ‚Ä¢ Air quality has improved significantly, but many areas still have pollution levels exceeding standards at times

column2: ‚Ä¢ As of 2004, 159 million people lived in areas that sometimes exceeded ozone standards and 62 million lived in counties that exceeded particulate matter standards

column1: ‚Ä¢ EPA had not met 45 requirements with statutory deadlines that had passed as of April 2005

column2: ‚Ä¢ These include reviewing residual health risks from emissions sources and regulating volatile organic compound emissions from consumer products

column1: ‚Ä¢ Stakeholders prefer legislation with specific emissions reduction amounts, deadlines, and regulated sources

column2: ‚Ä¢ The acid rain program under Title IV could serve as a model for other air quality problems by setting emissions goals and using market-based approaches

column1: ‚Ä¢ EPA has applied cap-and-trade programs to achieve further reductions in some pollutants since 2000

column2: ‚Ä¢ However, EPA's authority to use this approach for hazardous air pollutants like mercury, absent express statutory authority, is unclear

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
522,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* OJJDP established the Girls Study Group in 2004 to develop research on preventing and reducing girls' delinquency

column2: * Objectives included identifying effective programs and developing program models
* The group reviewed over 1,000 documents and identified 61 programs targeting girls' delinquency
* The group assessed the methodological quality of studies of evaluated programs
* OJJDP's effort was consistent with accepted social science research practices and standards

column1: * The Study Group found few girls' delinquency programs had been studied and available studies lacked conclusive evidence of effectiveness

column2: * 44 of the 61 identified programs had not been studied by researchers
* None of the 17 studied programs provided conclusive evidence of effectiveness
* The group reported a need for more rigorous evaluations and assistance to prepare programs for evaluation
* OJJDP plans a technical assistance workshop and funding to support evaluations in response

column1: * OJJDP has not developed a documented plan with specific funding and timelines for meeting girls' delinquency goals

column2: * Standard practices call for conceptualizing and documenting desired outcomes and projects to achieve them
* Internal control standards call for policies establishing communication with stakeholders
* OJJDP officials said the office is in transition and developing an overall juvenile justice plan
* A documented plan would demonstrate leadership and help ensure girls' delinquency goals are met

column1: * GAO recommended in July that OJJDP develop and document a plan to respond to the Study Group's findings

column2: * The plan should include timelines, funding requirements, and be shared with stakeholders
* OJP agreed and outlined planned efforts including publishing a proposed juvenile justice program plan
* OJJDP anticipates publishing a final plan by the end of 2009 after soliciting public feedback

column1: 523,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

* Assumed control of finance and accounting operations at the installation level
* Designated as a Defense Business Operations Fund business area in 1992
* Developing a new concept of operations to consolidate activities at fewer locations

column1: * DFAS and the military services share finance and accounting responsibilities

column2: * DFAS negotiated division of responsibilities with each service
* Two chains of command - DFAS under DOD Comptroller, services under respective secretaries
* DFAS issues policies and procedures binding on all DOD activities
* Services retained some functions to support local commanders and customers

column1: * DOD's finance and accounting infrastructure is large but exact size is uncertain

* DFAS tracks its personnel numbers, currently has 23,500 employees
* Services do not centrally track finance and accounting personnel, estimate 17,300
* Total DOD finance and accounting budget unknown but exceeds $2 billion

column1: * DFAS is working to reduce and standardize finance and accounting systems

column2: * Inherited 324 systems in 1991, now reduced to 217

* Has reduced finance systems by 47% and accounting systems by 24%

524,"Here is a summary of the source document using 2 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Federal Reserve Act established the Federal Reserve as an independent central bank with a decentralized structure to ensure monetary policy decisions are based on a broad economic perspective

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Federal Reserve consists of the Board of Governors, 12 Reserve Banks, and the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC)
‚Ä¢ The Federal Reserve is not operated for profit and remits excess earnings to the U.S. Treasury
‚Ä¢ The Federal Reserve has a relatively high degree of independence compared to other central banks, which research has shown is important for maintaining low inflation

column1: ‚Ä¢ Modifying the stock ownership requirement for member banks could have wide-ranging policy implications on the structure and independence of the Federal Reserve

column2: ‚Ä¢ Retiring Reserve Bank stock could disrupt the balance between the Federal Reserve's public and private interests and reduce the autonomy of the Reserve Banks
‚Ä¢ Making stock ownership voluntary likely would not significantly impact Federal Reserve membership but could concentrate stock ownership and voting rights
‚Ä¢ Allowing the entire capital contribution to be callable would preserve the Reserve Banks' corporate structure but could cause public perception problems in times of financial distress

527,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Enterprise architectures are blueprints describing an organization's current and desired states in logical and technical terms

column2: ‚Ä¢ They are a recognized tenet of organizational transformation and IT management

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO has promoted the use of enterprise architectures for over a decade

column2: ‚Ä¢ GAO developed an enterprise architecture management maturity framework (EAMMF) to assess agency architecture efforts

column1: ‚Ä¢ Most major federal agencies have not fully satisfied all stage 2 core elements of the EAMMF

column2: ‚Ä¢ On average, agencies have fully satisfied 80%, 78%, 61%, and 52% of stage 2, 3, 4, and 5 elements respectively

column1: ‚Ä¢ Key challenges agencies face include overcoming organizational parochialism, ensuring adequate funding, and obtaining skilled staff

column2: ‚Ä¢ Sustained organizational leadership is crucial to overcoming these challenges

column1: ‚Ä¢ Agencies reported accruing benefits from their architecture efforts

column2: ‚Ä¢ Benefits include improved alignment between business operations and IT, information sharing, and productivity

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO recommends agencies develop and implement plans to fully satisfy the EAMMF core elements

column2: ‚Ä¢ Doing so can help agencies realize the significant benefits of well-managed architecture programs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Agencies have collectively invested $836 million to date on architecture development

column2: ‚Ä¢ The majority of costs are attributable to contractor support (84%) and agency personnel (13%)

column1: ‚Ä¢ Agencies use various frameworks and tools for their architectures with varying levels of satisfaction

column2: ‚Ä¢ Commonly used frameworks include FEAPMO reference models, FEAF, and Zachman; tools include System Architect, Microsoft Visio, and Metis

column1: ‚Ä¢ GAO assessed 28 agency architecture programs against its EAMMF

column2: ‚Ä¢ Evaluation included analyzing supporting documentation and meeting with agency representatives to discuss elements not fully satisfied

column2: * The FTA eliminates tariffs, opens markets, and includes labor and environmental protections. It is expected to have a small positive impact on the U.S. economy.

<summary>
‚Ä¢ Hate crimes are criminal offenses motivated by bias against protected characteristics

column2: ‚Ä¢ Congress has enacted several laws to address hate crimes

column1: ‚Ä¢ Current federal law allows prosecution of hate crimes based on race, color, religion, or national origin during federally protected activities

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act expanded protected categories and federal jurisdiction

column1: ‚Ä¢ Congress's authority to expand hate crime legislation is derived from the Commerce Clause and the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Supreme Court has limited Congress's power under the Commerce Clause in cases like United States v. Morrison

column1: ‚Ä¢ The 13th Amendment, which prohibits slavery, may provide a basis for expanding hate crime legislation

column2: ‚Ä¢ It is unclear if violence based on bigotry constitutes a ""badge and/or incident of slavery"" under the 13th Amendment

column1: ‚Ä¢ The 1st Amendment limits hate crime legislation, distinguishing between punishing conduct and punishing speech or expression

column2: ‚Ä¢ Cases like R.A.V. v. City of St. Paul and Wisconsin v. Mitchell provide a framework for constitutionally valid hate crime laws

column1: ‚Ä¢ The 6th Amendment's right to a jury trial also limits hate crime statutes

column2: ‚Ä¢ In Apprendi v. New Jersey, the Supreme Court ruled that any fact increasing a sentence beyond the statutory maximum must be proven to a jury beyond a reasonable doubt

530,"Here is a summary of the text using the specified format:
<summary>
* Exchange rate policies of some East Asian nations have been sources of tension with the U.S.

column2: * Some analysts argue these policies constitute currency manipulation
* The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires Treasury to analyze exchange rates of major trading partners
* In its April 2017 report, Treasury did not find any major trading partner met all three criteria of currency manipulation

column1: * East Asian governments have adopted various exchange rate policies

column2: * Hong Kong maintains a fixed exchange rate with the U.S. dollar
* Japan, the Philippines, and South Korea have allowed their currencies to float freely
* Most East Asian governments have chosen a ""managed float"" policy

column1: * Categorizing a government's exchange rate policy can be complicated

column2: * South Korea's interventions in forex markets in 2008 led some to claim it had a de facto pegged exchange rate
* China's relatively stable exchange rate with the U.S. dollar from 2008-2010 initially led some to assert it had abandoned its crawling peg
* Japan's fluctuating yen value has been attributed to both market confidence and possible government intervention

column1: * There are indications of ""competitive"" adjustments in exchange rates among some East Asian countries

column2: * Observers have speculated about a possible ""renminbi bloc"" emerging at times in Southeast Asia
* China has become the largest trading partner for many Asian nations
* More recent divergences in exchange rates have weakened the case for an emerging ""renminbi bloc""

column1: * The Department of the Treasury provides biannual reports to Congress on the exchange rate policies of foreign countries

column2: * The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 required annual reports
* The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 expanded the reporting requirements
* In the past, Treasury has identified South Korea, Taiwan, and China for currency manipulation

column1: * The latest Treasury report, released in April 2017, did not find any major trading partner met all three criteria for currency manipulation

column2: * The report placed China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan on a ""Monitoring List""
* The report made specific observations about each country's foreign exchange practices
* China and Taiwan were noted for their history of asymmet",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 531,"Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Chiefs of Mission (COMs) are the principal officers in charge of U.S. diplomatic missions abroad

column2: * Appointed by the President and have full responsibility for directing and supervising all executive branch employees in their country of assignment
* Authority derives from the President's constitutional powers, the Foreign Service Act of 1980, and executive orders and directives
* Responsible for keeping fully informed of all U.S. government activities in their country and ensuring compliance with COM directives
* Promote U.S. goods and services for export to their country of assignment

column1: * COM authority has expanded over time but has some limitations

column2: * Applies to executive branch agencies but generally not to legislative and judicial branches
* Extends to most Department of Defense personnel in the country except those under command of a Geographic Combatant Commander
* COMs are still in charge of U.S. missions in countries with severed/strained diplomatic relations or during hostilities
* Members of Congress can travel to foreign countries without COM approval but should notify the COM

column1: * There are concerns about the effectiveness of COM authority and suggestions for improvement

column2: * Some weaknesses in COM leadership and management have been identified that impact productivity and morale at some posts
* Proposals include selecting COMs with strong interagency experience and expertise, enhancing COM training, and providing more support and resources from the State Department
* Specific steps could include longer training for new COMs, making interagency experience a standard expectation, and ensuring agency representatives fully understand their obligations to the COM

536,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for listing and protection of endangered or threatened species

column2: * Federal agencies must consult with FWS or NMFS to determine if projects jeopardize listed species or critical habitat

column1: * In rare cases, federal agency actions may be exempted from the ESA through an exemption process

column2: * Only 6 exemptions have been sought and 2 granted in over 40 years

column1: * The Endangered Species Committee (ESC) reviews exemption applications and makes the ultimate decision

column2: * The ESC is composed of cabinet-level officials and representatives from affected states

column1: * Exemption applications are limited to the federal action agency, state governor, or permit/license applicant

column2: * Applicants must show they have met certain requirements before an exemption can be considered

column1: * The Secretary of the Interior conducts a formal hearing and prepares a report for the ESC

column2: * The ESC must make specific determinations to grant an exemption based on the report and other evidence

column1: * If an exemption is granted, the ESC must specify mitigation measures that the applicant is responsible for funding

column2: * Exemptions are permanent unless the Secretary later finds it would result in extinction of a species

column1: * Exemptions apply to specific agency actions, not species, so FWS/NMFS must still work to recover the species

column2: * Conservation burden may fall more heavily on remaining habitat/resources after an exemption

column1: * Practical and political challenges make the exemption process difficult and explain its rare use

column2: * Applicants must weigh costs of the process and mitigation against benefits of an exemption

column1: * The ESA tends to force decisions on contentious land/water use issues, but the exemption process is rarely used

column2: * Consultation process allows for project modifications to avoid jeopardy and the need for exemptions

column1: * Past exemption attempts illustrate the complexity and rarity of the process (Tellico Dam, Grayrocks Dam, BLM timber sales)

column2: * Some attempts were withdrawn or abandoned before completion (Pittston refinery, Mound City docking area, Suwanee Sound dredging)

537,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Capital gains taxation has been a perennial topic of debate in Congress since 1913

column2: * Numerous bills are introduced every session to change capital gains taxation
* Congress has also shown continuing interest in the tax treatment of capital losses
* Many have proposed increasing the $3,000 limit on capital losses deductible against ordinary income

column1: * The $3,000 loss limit prevents selective realization of losses from being a significant problem

column2: * Individuals can achieve tax benefits by realizing losses and holding assets with gains
* The problem is exacerbated by the current asymmetrical treatment of capital gains and losses
* Long-term gains are taxed at a maximum 15% rate while losses are deductible at up to 35%
* Increasing the loss deduction would increase rewards for gaming the system

column1: * Capital gains and losses are heavily concentrated in upper income ranges

column2: * Taxpayers in middle income ranges tend to hold gains-producing assets in tax-favored plans
* Assets in retirement plans are not affected by the net loss restrictions
* Benefits of increasing the loss deduction would accrue mainly to upper income taxpayers

column1: * It is unclear if increasing the loss deduction would stimulate the economy

column2: * Measures to stimulate should focus on spending or tax cuts likely to be spent
* An expanded loss deduction has a tenuous connection to expanded spending
* It might increase sales of poorly performing stocks and depress markets further

column1: * Historically, Congress has repeatedly changed the tax treatment of capital gains and losses

column2: * Between 1913-1916, losses were only deductible if associated with a trade or business
* From 1916-1918, losses were deductible up to the amount of gains
* From 1918-1921, losses in excess of gains were deductible against ordinary income

column1: * The Revenue Act of 1921 significantly changed the treatment of gains and losses

column2: * It divided assets into short-term and long-term categories
* It created an asymmetrical treatment of long-term gains and losses
* Excess long-term losses could be deducted at higher rates than gains were taxed

column1: * Major changes to capital loss treatment occurred in 1",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
538,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes employees' right to collective bargaining

column2: * The NLRA attempts to mitigate labor-related obstructions to commerce
* The right to collective bargaining only applies to ""employees,"" not supervisors
* The NLRB and courts have sought to define the term ""supervisor"" under the NLRA

column1: * The Supreme Court case NLRB v. Kentucky River Community Care, Inc. addressed the definition of ""independent judgment"" for determining supervisory status

column2: * The Court rejected the NLRB's exclusion of judgment based on ""ordinary professional or technical"" skill
* The Court's three-part test considers supervisory functions, independent judgment, and employer interest
* The dissent argued that the NLRB's interpretation deserved deference

column1: * In Oakwood Healthcare, Inc., the NLRB defined key terms related to supervisory status

column2: * ""Assign"" refers to designating an employee to a place, time, or overall duties
* ""Responsibly to direct"" requires oversight and accountability for others' performance
* ""Independent judgment"" involves acting free from others' control and forming opinions by comparing data

column1: * The NLRA prohibits unfair labor practices by employers and unions that interfere with employees' rights

column2: * Employer violations include threats, coercion, and interrogation about union sympathies
* Union violations include violence, encouraging employees to quit, and threatening job security
* The actual effect of the misconduct is immaterial; the test is whether it reasonably tends to restrain or coerce

column1: * Employers may make noncoercive antiunion speeches to employees on company property without allowing unions equal opportunity

column2: * The NLRB distinguishes last-minute speeches within 24 hours of an election as unfair
* Employers can prohibit nonemployee union organizers from distributing literature on company property if other communication channels exist
* Exceptions apply if the employer's location places employees beyond reasonable union communication efforts

column1: * The Supreme Court cases NLRB v. Babcock & Wilson Co. and Lechmere v. NLRB addressed union access to employer property

542,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

column1: 543,"Here is a summary of the text using the specified format:
<summary>
* Cuba has been on the U.S. state sponsors of terrorism list since 1982

column2: * Being on the list restricts trade, foreign aid, and other benefits
* Cuba's retention on the list has received more attention recently due to initiatives to lift sanctions
* Sanctions have not been removed and Cuba remains subject to a comprehensive U.S. embargo

column1: * A country can be removed from the terrorism list by the President through two options

column2: * Certify there has been a fundamental change in the country's government and policies
* Certify the government has not supported terrorism recently and has provided assurances it will not in the future
* Congress could still block removal by passing legislation

column1: * Cuba was originally added to the list in 1982 for supporting terrorist groups in Latin America

column2: * The Reagan administration alleged Cuba's ties to international terrorism in the early 1980s
* Cuba was accused of providing training, arms, and other support to guerrilla groups
* Being added to the list had little practical effect since the U.S. already had comprehensive sanctions on Cuba

column1: * The State Department's rationale for keeping Cuba on the list has evolved over time

column2: * Recent reports say Cuba opposes the U.S. war on terror and has not undertaken counterterrorism efforts
* Cuba is accused of providing safe haven to members of foreign terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives
* There are controversial allegations Cuba may have a limited biological weapons program

column1: * Supporters argue there is ample evidence Cuba supports terrorism and hosts terrorists

column2: * They point to Cuba's history of supporting armed insurgencies in Latin America and Africa
* Cuba's strong anti-American statements and alleged biological weapons program are also cited
* The presence of wanted U.S. fugitives in Cuba is another key reason given

column1: * Critics argue Cuba's designation is a Cold War relic and that politics keeps Cuba on the list

column2: * They say Cuba has ratified counterterrorism conventions and offered support after 9/11
* Past State Department reports stated Cuba was no longer actively supporting armed struggles
* Foreign terrorists in Cuba may be there via agreements with or consent of their home countries

column1: * There is debate over whether there should be a more calibrated approach to sanctions

column2: * Countries on the terrorism list vary",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 544,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is an alternative tax calculation that adds back certain deductions and taxes income at 26% and 28% rates

column2: ‚Ä¢ The AMT base is broader than the regular tax base but excludes some major tax preferences
‚Ä¢ AMT exemptions are not indexed to inflation, causing more taxpayers to be subject to AMT over time

column1: ‚Ä¢ The number and percentage of taxpayers subject to AMT has increased dramatically and is projected to continue growing rapidly

column2: ‚Ä¢ In 1987, about 140,000 returns (0.1%) paid AMT; by 2009, over 9 million (6.3%) are projected to pay AMT
‚Ä¢ AMT will increasingly affect middle and upper-middle income taxpayers, not just the highest earners

column1: ‚Ä¢ Fixing the AMT is costly - indexing exemptions and eliminating credit limits would cost tens of billions per year

column2: ‚Ä¢ Interaction with tax credits adopted in 1997 causes millions more to be affected by AMT
‚Ä¢ Any tax cuts that reduce regular tax without changing AMT will further increase AMT coverage and costs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Marriage penalty relief provisions in tax cut bills can be substantially limited by the AMT

column2: ‚Ä¢ AMT will ""take back"" an increasing share of marriage penalty tax cuts over time if not adjusted
‚Ä¢ Expansion of 15% bracket and standard deduction will push more couples into AMT

column1: ‚Ä¢ Various approaches could address the AMT, such as indexing exemptions, adjusting AMT as regular tax changes, or eliminating it

column2: ‚Ä¢ Indexing AMT parameters is necessary to maintain its relative importance in the tax system
‚Ä¢ AMT base may need to be re-examined regarding which preferences are included or disallowed

column1: ‚Ä¢ Growth of AMT is a long-standing issue exacerbated by recent tax cuts in 1997 and 2001

column2: ‚Ä¢ AMT causes many taxpayers to lose part or all of tax cut benefits and increases filing complexity
‚Ä¢ Fixing AMT becomes increasingly costly each time the problem is deferred as more taxpayers are affected

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

547,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ U.S. imports of milk protein concentrates (MPCs) have limited trade restrictions compared to other dairy products

column2: ‚Ä¢ MPCs are derived from raw milk and used in various food, animal feed, and industrial products
‚Ä¢ Advocates of stricter MPC import controls say it would encourage domestic protein use and raise milk prices for farmers
‚Ä¢ Opponents argue it would increase costs and retail food prices, and major MPC suppliers would likely seek WTO compensation
‚Ä¢ MPC imports rose sharply in the late 1990s but have remained at or below 2000 peak levels since 2001

column1: ‚Ä¢ Milk composition and protein types

column2: ‚Ä¢ Milk is 87.4% water and 12.6% milk solids (fat, protein, lactose, minerals)
‚Ä¢ Milk protein is casein (82% of protein) and whey protein (18% of protein)
‚Ä¢ Casein is used in foods and industrial applications; whey protein is used in various food products
‚Ä¢ MPCs contain casein and whey protein and are identified by protein percentage (e.g. MPC42 has 42% protein)

column1: ‚Ä¢ U.S. dairy product imports and proposed legislation

column2: ‚Ä¢ The U.S. produces little casein or MPCs; federal dairy policies may have encouraged nonfat dry milk production instead
‚Ä¢ In 2008, cheese was the largest U.S. dairy import (38%) followed by MPCs and casein/caseinates combined (35%)
‚Ä¢ Proposed legislation (S. 1542, H.R. 3674) would introduce tariff-rate quotas on MPC and casein/caseinate imports
‚Ä¢ If enacted, the U.S. would likely need to negotiate compensation with major MPC supplier countries under WTO rules

column1: ‚Ä¢ Potential impact of import restrictions

column2: ‚Ä¢ Dairy farmers generally support MPC import restrictions to close a ""loophole"" and improve farm-level prices
‚Ä¢ Dairy processors oppose restrictions, arguing it would increase costs, consumer prices, and jeopardize export gains
‚Ä¢ Impact depends on farm prices relative to government support levels; above-quota imports equate to ~0.7% of U.S. milk production",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

549,"Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases in its October 2012 term

column2: * Florida v. Jardines: A trained drug-sniffing dog's sniff at the front door of a suspected marijuana grow house is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause
* Florida v. Harris: An alert by a well-trained narcotics-detection dog certified to detect illegal contraband is sufficient to establish probable cause to search a vehicle

column1: * In Bailey v. United States, the Court held that under the Summers rule, the detention of an individual who has just left premises to be searched under warrant is only permissible in the immediate vicinity of the premises

column2: * The Court disagreed with the Second Circuit's extension of the Summers rule to allow off-site detention incident to the execution of a search warrant under certain conditions
* The majority emphasized the narrow scope of the Summers rule exception to the Fourth Amendment's limits on personal liberty intrusions

column1: * Missouri v. McNeely addressed whether the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream presents a per se exigency justifying a warrant exception for nonconsensual blood testing in drunk-driving cases

column2: * The Court rejected a per se exception, holding that the existence of exigent circumstances must be determined on a case-by-case basis considering the totality of the circumstances
* The majority reaffirmed that the general rule requiring a warrant for searches involving bodily intrusions is particularly compelling, with exceptions only in certain emergency situations

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

552,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* S. 1796 would establish new health insurance plans and define existing ones in the private market

column2: * New plans include ""qualified health benefits plans"" (QHBPs) and ""qualified basic health plans""
* Essential health benefits coverage is defined as coverage under a QHBP, grandfathered plan, Medicare, Medicaid, and other specified coverage

column1: * The bill includes an individual mandate to have health insurance and potential employer requirements

column2: * Individuals would be required to maintain essential health benefits coverage for themselves and dependents
* Employers with over 50 employees who do not provide coverage could face penalties for certain employees

column1: * The bill would establish new federal standards for private health insurance plans

column2: * Standards would primarily affect plans in the individual and small group markets
* Large group plans would be prohibited from imposing unreasonable annual or lifetime limits and would have other requirements

column1: * States would be required to establish exchanges through which individuals and small businesses could obtain QHBPs

column2: * Separate exchanges would be created for individuals and small businesses
* The federal government would provide funding for exchanges' start-up costs but not ongoing operations

column1: * Certain individuals with incomes below 400% of the federal poverty level could qualify for premium credits and cost-sharing subsidies

column2: * Premium credits would be available on a sliding scale from 2% to 12% of income
* Cost-sharing subsidies would reduce out-of-pocket maximums and provide other assistance

column1: * The bill provides incentives for creating non-profit, member-run health insurance co-ops

column2: * $6 billion in federal funds would be provided as loans for start-up costs and grants for solvency
* Co-ops would compete on a level playing field with other plans in the reformed markets

column1: * The bill includes provisions related to abortion coverage

column2: * Plans would not be required to cover elective abortions
* Funds from premium assistance credits and cost-sharing subsidies could not be used for elective abortions

column1: * The bill includes revenue provisions to offset the costs of expanded coverage

column2: * An excise tax would be imposed on high-cost employer-sponsored plans
* Contributions to flexible spending accounts would be limited and other changes would be made to",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 553,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* 35 states have established high risk health insurance pools to provide coverage for individuals who cannot obtain affordable insurance due to preexisting conditions

column2: * Pools generally cover people denied coverage, quoted high premiums, or offered policies excluding preexisting conditions
* Many states use pools to comply with HIPAA portability and availability provisions
* Pools tend to enroll a small percentage of the uninsured due to their narrow focus
* The Affordable Care Act requires HHS to establish a temporary high risk pool program prior to 2014

column1: * High risk pools fill a niche in the patchwork health insurance system for those without access to employer-sponsored insurance or public programs

column2: * Applicants to the individual market undergo medical underwriting
* Federal and state laws restrict insurers' ability to reject or design coverage based on health factors
* Rigorous underwriting results in a fairly healthy enrollee population, excluding those with moderate to severe conditions
* High risk pools were designed to assist individuals with health conditions who have few options for private coverage

column1: * Supporters argue high risk pools allow states to use existing regulatory infrastructure to efficiently insure the uninsurable and make individual market coverage more affordable

column2: * Removing high risk individuals from the individual market may help stabilize it and promote competition
* High risk pools function as a safety net, assuring access to insurance for those willing to pay
* Others contend the pools are too small and underfunded to meet the needs of most who cannot access private insurance
* Premiums and cost-sharing can make coverage unaffordable, and most pools exclude preexisting conditions for 6+ months

column1: * Congressional support of state high risk pools began in the 1990s

column2: * HIPAA specified state pools as acceptable mechanisms for complying with group-to-individual market requirements
* The Trade Act of 2002 authorized grants to state pools and made appropriations for FY2003-2004
* The program was reauthorized through FY2010 with appropriations made in FY2006 and additional appropriations in 2007-2009
* PPACA requires HHS to establish a temporary high risk pool program prior to 2014

column1: * States have discretion",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

555,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
