805,"Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

‚Ä¢ The committee discussed the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 with the Minister for Education Kirsty Williams and Huw Morris, director of skills, higher education and lifelong learning at the Welsh Government

column2: ‚Ä¢ They discussed the Act's objectives, powers of intervention, fee and access plans, managing risk, governance, and quality assurance

column1: ‚Ä¢ Kirsty Williams indicated the Act would be superseded by the new post-compulsory education and training (PCET) bill

column2: ‚Ä¢ The new bill aims to encourage collaboration across the tertiary education sector and introduce outcome agreements

column1: ‚Ä¢ Concerns were raised about the Act's limited powers, bureaucratic fee and access plans, and the need for more consultation with stakeholders

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Minister acknowledged these issues and said they would be addressed in the new PCET bill

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
806,"Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 will likely be superceded by the new post-compulsory education and training (PCET) Bill

column2: * The Act had four main objectives around regulation, public good, fair access, and institutional autonomy
* The new Bill aims to strengthen these objectives and be fit for current circumstances

column1: * Fee and access plans are important but can be improved in the new legislation

column2: * Plans should focus more on outcomes over a longer time period rather than annual inputs
* Despite limitations, access to higher education in Wales is improving, especially for postgraduates and disadvantaged groups

column1: * Private higher education providers in Wales are limited in number and regulated on a case-by-case basis

column2: * The Act struck a balance in regulating providers proportional to the public funding they receive
* The new commission will need powers to regulate any potential future changes in the higher education provider landscape

column1: * Quality assurance in the new PCET sector is a concern for some universities

column2: * The government aims to ensure a coherent, effective and comprehensive quality framework compatible with UK and European standards
* Opportunities exist to improve quality assurance of work-based learning and provision by overseas providers

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
807,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Kirsty Williams AM responded to concerns about the governance of universities:

column2: ‚Ä¢ The 2015 Higher Education (Wales) Act will be superceded by the new PCETR Bill
‚Ä¢ The Act aimed to regulate institutions, safeguard public good, focus on fair access, and protect institutional autonomy

column1: ‚Ä¢ Kirsty Williams plans to strengthen the legislation to better achieve the Act's objectives:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Remit letters are used to articulate national priorities and drive change
‚Ä¢ The new Bill will introduce outcome agreements to align with national goals

column1: ‚Ä¢ Private higher education providers in Wales are limited and regulated on a case-by-case basis:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Only 6 organizations were designated in 2018-19, including 3 FE colleges and 3 charities
‚Ä¢ The new legislation will consider how to regulate this part of the sector

column1: ‚Ä¢ Fee and access plans will be reformed in the new legislation:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Plans will shift from annual to multi-year and focus on outcomes rather than inputs
‚Ä¢ Despite limitations, access to higher education is improving for underrepresented groups

column1: ‚Ä¢ The 2015 Act struck the right balance in regulating institutions proportional to public funding received:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Private providers are regulated on a course-by-course basis to ensure quality
‚Ä¢ The new commission will have powers to regulate and futureproof for potential changes in the sector

column1: ‚Ä¢ Governance arrangements in universities are being reviewed and may be addressed in the new Bill:

column2: ‚Ä¢ An independent review is advising on governance changes
‚Ä¢ Diversity in governing bodies needs improvement, including representation of women, minorities, students and staff

column1: ‚Ä¢ Quality assurance across the tertiary sector will be reformed while maintaining high standards:

column2: ‚Ä¢ A single quality assessment body is being considered, with stakeholder concerns being addressed
‚Ä¢ Any changes will be compatible with UK and European standards to maintain the strong reputation of Welsh universities

column1: ‚Ä¢ Transnational education (TNE) presents opportunities but also risks to the sector's reputation if not properly regulated:

column2: ‚Ä¢ The new legislation may strengthen oversight of TNE to protect the high quality of Welsh higher education

811,"Here is a summary of the meeting in the requested format:
<summary>
* The team reviewed the final prototype remote control design

column2: * It has an LCD screen, scroll wheel, and confirm button instead of opening up with many buttons inside to reduce cost
* The slogan will be printed on the side of the remote
* The dimensions will be about 10cm long, 3cm wide, and 2.5cm thick

column1: * The team evaluated the design against the original criteria

column2: * It scored well on being simple to use and having the company logo
* It scored lower on having a stylish look and soft/spongy feel due to cost constraints
* Overall it achieved about 70% of the original design goals

column1: * The team discussed the product development process and environment

column2: * Creativity was limited by the short timeframe and specific requirements
* Leadership provided structure but also limited freedom and ownership
* Teamwork was hindered by not being able to communicate outside of formal meetings

column1: * The team found the whiteboard and prototype helpful for sharing ideas

column2: * PowerPoint and individual computers were distracting
* The digital pens were usable but clunky
* Play-Doh was engaging and helped make the design more tangible

column1: * The project stayed within budget and was evaluated to be complete

column2: * The team was disappointed they couldn't use multiple colors and materials
* They decided to name the prototype ""Ninja Homer"" based on its shape
* In summary, the team felt the process was very structured but limited true collaboration and creativity

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
812,"Here is a summary of the key points from the discussion:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The team discussed the functional requirements for a new TV remote control

column2: ‚Ä¢ The remote should only control the TV and not be too complex in order to get it to market quickly
‚Ä¢ Teletext is considered outdated and will not be included

column1: ‚Ä¢ The industrial designer presented the basic components and how they interact in a remote control system

column2: ‚Ä¢ Components include a power source, user interface buttons, a chip, an infrared sender, and a receiver in the TV
‚Ä¢ Pressing a button sends a message to the chip which tells the sender to transmit a signal to the TV receiver

column1: ‚Ä¢ The user interface designer showed some example remotes and recommended a simple design with limited buttons

column2: ‚Ä¢ The team agreed to include numbers 0-9, volume and channel buttons, power, and a mute button on the main interface
‚Ä¢ More detailed functions like brightness, contrast, and tuning will be hidden in a slide-out panel on the back

column1: ‚Ä¢ Marketing research found that most people find remotes ugly and 3/4 would pay more for a fancier design

column2: ‚Ä¢ The most used buttons are for channels, volume, and power; setting buttons are rarely used
‚Ä¢ The biggest frustrations are losing the remote and difficulty learning a new remote

column1: ‚Ä¢ The team decided on the main functions to include and to keep the design simple to get it to market quickly

column2: ‚Ä¢ They will have a clap-activated feature to help locate a lost remote
‚Ä¢ Speech recognition was considered but deemed too complex and time-consuming to implement now

column1: ‚Ä¢ Detailed audio settings may not be needed since devices have their own controls, but this requires more research

column2: ‚Ä¢ Any additional information obtained should be shared with the team via email before the next meeting
‚Ä¢ Each team member will work on their assigned tasks and report back at the next meeting in 40 minutes

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
813,"Here is a summary of the meeting in the requested format:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The team discussed the components and design of a new TV remote control

column2: ‚Ä¢ It will have a power source, user interface buttons, a chip, and an infrared sender
‚Ä¢ The receiver will be in the TV, not the remote itself
‚Ä¢ The team decided on a simple design with minimal buttons to be user-friendly

column2: ‚Ä¢ Most people find current remotes ugly and would pay more for an improved design
‚Ä¢ The most used buttons are for channels, volume, and power; setting buttons are rarely used
‚Ä¢ Younger people are more receptive to speech recognition, but it may be too complex to include

column1: ‚Ä¢ The team made final decisions on the remote control functions and design

‚Ä¢ Numbers, volume, mute, power, and channel buttons will be on the front
‚Ä¢ Brightness, contrast, and tuning buttons will be hidden on the back to keep the design sleek

814,"Here is a summary of the key points from Marketing's presentation on functional requirements:
<summary>
* Tested 100 subjects and found users are not happy with current remote controls

column2: * 75% think current remotes are ugly
* 80% are willing to spend more for a fancier remote
* Need something snazzy yet simple

column1: * Current remotes do not match well with user operating behavior

column2: * Users only use 10% of the buttons
* 34% say it takes too much time to learn a new remote
* Need to vary somewhat from standard remote but still be identifiable

column1: * People typically lose remotes like other small appliances

column2: * Channel, volume and power are the most used buttons
* Specific usage statistics available on company website

column1: * Need a modern, eye-catching but simple design

column2: * Consider what functionality and buttons are really needed
* Appeal to a wide range of consumers and uses (DVD, TiVo, etc.)
* Develop a hip but not corny marketing scheme

column1: * Speech recognition is an up-and-coming feature

column2: * Consumers are very interested in speech recognition
* Since people are willing to pay more, could consider including it

column1: * Next steps

column2: * Interpret how to incorporate different types of speech recognition
* Aim for larger buttons in general compared to small examples shown
* Use unique button shapes like ovals/bubbles vs. typical small squares

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

816,"Here is a summary of the meeting in the requested format:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The project manager introduced the meeting and explained the unusual setting with cameras and microphones

column2: ‚Ä¢ The team did an icebreaker exercise drawing their favorite animals on the smartboard
‚Ä¢ The project manager gave an overview of the project to design a new remote control
‚Ä¢ The aim is to make it original, trendy and user-friendly with a selling price of 25 euros

column1: ‚Ä¢ The marketing expert presented some initial ideas and requirements

column2: ‚Ä¢ The remote should be intuitive, small, fairly cheap, and brand independent
‚Ä¢ He thinks it should be multi-purpose to distinguish it from current products on the market
‚Ä¢ Suggestions included using radio waves or Bluetooth instead of infrared, and adding an LCD screen

column1: ‚Ä¢ The user interface designer emphasized the need to keep it simple and focus on core functions like changing channels

column2: ‚Ä¢ He questioned adding an LCD screen and wanted to know the purpose
‚Ä¢ He said they need to agree on key aspects like whether it will control multiple devices before proceeding
‚Ä¢ Technical functions can't be designed without knowing what devices it needs to be compatible with

column1: ‚Ä¢ The industrial designer suggested they each come up with ideas and requirements from their own perspective first

column2: ‚Ä¢ Then at the next meeting they can decide which features to include or remove
‚Ä¢ He said looking at specific components and technologies is a step further than they need to go now
‚Ä¢ They should start with general concepts and narrow down from there

column1: ‚Ä¢ The project manager agreed they should each think about the most important aspects from their own point of view

column2: ‚Ä¢ At the next meeting in 30 minutes they will try to fit all the pieces together
‚Ä¢ He said they will receive more specific instructions from their personal coaches
‚Ä¢ The meeting was adjourned so they could begin working individually

column1: ‚Ä¢ In general, the team began brainstorming initial ideas and requirements but did not make any firm decisions yet

column2: ‚Ä¢ The marketing expert focused on distinguishing features and new technologies
‚Ä¢ The user interface designer emphasized simplicity and deciding on key functionality first
‚Ä¢ The industrial designer wanted to start general and then narrow down specifics later

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
817,"Here is a summary of the meeting discussion in the requested format:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Discussed how to represent and store annotations and features for speech data

column2: ‚Ä¢ Considered using an XML format developed by Adam with time-based tags
‚Ä¢ Compared to NIST's ATLAS format which uses a more generic graph representation
‚Ä¢ Debated pros and cons of each approach and ability to translate between them

column1: ‚Ä¢ Talked about how to efficiently query and search the annotation data

column2: ‚Ä¢ Using a relational database vs. flat files with Perl scripts to parse the structure
‚Ä¢ Leveraging existing XML query languages and tools vs. custom programming
‚Ä¢ Balancing quick solutions with a framework that can expand to future needs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Covered representation of hierarchical structures like utterances, sentences, prosodic phrases

column2: ‚Ä¢ Mapping between non-nesting linguistic units via pointers in the annotation graph
‚Ä¢ Encoding speaker information and mapping annotations to time-based word transcripts
‚Ä¢ Linking to external feature files for frame-level acoustic data like pitch tracks

column1: ‚Ä¢ Decided to evaluate NIST's ATLAS framework as a starting point

column2: ‚Ä¢ ATLAS provides an external XML format and API for annotation graphs
‚Ä¢ Offers path from simple flat file scripts to full database infrastructure later
‚Ä¢ Adam to review ATLAS in more detail and report if it will meet project needs

column1: ‚Ä¢ Also discussed compact binary formats for storing frame-level acoustic features

column2: ‚Ä¢ Considered ICSI-developed ""P-file"" format and existing tools to support it
‚Ä¢ Acknowledged 2GB file size limitations and need to split large feature files
‚Ä¢ Compared to other site-specific formats used in previous research projects

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
818,"Here is a summary of the discussion in the specified format:
<summary>
* The project manager welcomed everyone and outlined the goals of designing a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly

column2: * The design process will involve functional design, conceptual design, and detailed design
* The project has financial objectives of a production cost under 12.5 euros and a selling price of 25 euros to target a profit of 50 million euros
* Each team member drew their favorite animal on the whiteboard as a warm-up exercise
* The user interface designer drew an abstract orangutan, the marketing expert drew her cat Caramel, and the project manager drew a simplified cow/donkey

column1: * The team discussed whether the remote should control a single device or multiple devices

column2: * If bundled with another product, it could be single-device, otherwise multi-device would be preferable
* It was suggested the remote have few buttons and be able to light up for use in the dark
* The remote should have a non-square shape that fits well in the hand
* Making the remote waterproof and shockproof was discussed as a potentially original feature

column1: * An idea was proposed to make the remote emit a sound when whistled at to help locate it when lost

column2: * This ""whistle tracking"" feature was seen as cool and original
* However, there was some concern about the added cost of including audio components
* The industrial designer was tasked with looking into the cost and feasibility

column1: * The project manager assigned tasks to each team member to complete before the next meeting in 30 minutes

column2: * The industrial designer will look into the proposed features and their feasibility
* The user interface designer will consider the optimal number of buttons, lighting, and user convenience
* The marketing expert will determine the absolute must-have requirements for the remote from a user perspective
* The project manager said to expect some follow-up messages with further guidance

819,"Here is a summary of the key points from the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The group discussed differences in early childhood education and care provision across Wales

column2: * Provision varies by local authority due to historical differences and local decision making
* The Welsh Government is working on making the system more integrated and consistent

column1: * The Welsh Government's primary objectives are supporting both child development and helping parents work

column2: * High-quality early years provision is seen as benefiting children and enabling parents to work
* The government wants to simplify the complex current system of programs and funding

column1: * The childcare offer has had limited impact so far since it only recently became available across Wales

column2: * 94% of parents using the offer were already using formal childcare before it began
* The government plans to expand the offer to parents in education and training and promote it more

column1: * Flying Start is geographically targeted to disadvantaged areas but does not reach all children in poverty

column2: * About 45% of children in Flying Start areas are estimated to be in poverty
* The government is looking at ways to extend elements of Flying Start to more children

column1: * Take-up of some Flying Start services like parenting courses is relatively low

column2: * Only 18% of Flying Start parents attend parenting courses
* Health visitors and childcare workers also provide important parenting support and advice

column1: * The government decided not to use HMRC to administer the childcare offer in order to have more flexibility

column2: * Working with local authorities will allow expanding the offer in ways HMRC's system would not
* There were also some issues with HMRC meeting Welsh language standards in their IT systems

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

‚Ä¢ Flying Start is geographically targeted based on income benefit data to reach areas with the highest proportion of disadvantaged children

column2: ‚Ä¢ They are looking at expanding Flying Start to make it more accessible to more children

821,"Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points with 1 level of sub-points:

column2: ‚Ä¢ This will help identify where capacity needs to be built to meet the needs of the early years sector in a bilingual Wales

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Welsh Government has established a programme with the National Centre for Learning Welsh to develop Welsh language skills in the childcare and play workforce

column2: ‚Ä¢ Recruiting staff with good Welsh skills is challenging, so upskilling the existing workforce is key, in addition to attracting new people with Welsh skills

column1: ‚Ä¢ Mudiad Meithrin struggles to find staff with the right Welsh language skills

column2: ‚Ä¢ Doing more to offer training courses in Welsh and bilingually will help start the pathway of children interacting with education and childcare through Welsh at an earlier stage

column1: ‚Ä¢ Most people coming through the education system in Wales will have some awareness of Welsh, but it may not be at the level needed to teach the language to children

column2: ‚Ä¢ There is a lot of focus in early years training on how to develop children's Welsh skills, especially if they come from non-Welsh speaking homes

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Welsh Government aims to increase the number of Welsh-medium childcare places in parallel with Welsh-medium education places as part of the Cymraeg 2050 strategy

column2: ‚Ä¢ Baselining work will be done to determine current provision and identify what is needed to expand Welsh-medium childcare

827,"Here is a summary of the meeting in the requested format:
<summary>
* The team discussed the conceptual design of the remote control
* Reviewed energy sources, case materials, interface options, and chip choices
* Decided on basic battery or kinetic energy, titanium case, and simple rubber buttons with a regular chip
* Discussed adding a help button to display the user manual on the TV screen
* Considered a cube design where turning the cube changes the button functions
* Marketing survey results were presented showing user frustrations with current remotes
* 70% find remotes ugly, 80% willing to spend more for a fancy remote
* Current remotes don't match user behavior - 75% zap a lot, 50% use only 10% of buttons
* 50% say remotes get lost often, 34% say complex remotes take too long to learn
* Proposed solutions: LCD screen on remote, speech recognition, simpler remotes
* The team debated including an LCD screen on the remote vs. using the TV display
* LCD adds cost; TV display can provide same functionality and fanciness
* Decided to research cost of adding LCD and speech recognition for next meeting
* Discussed using a few simple buttons and on-screen menus for most functions
* Considered a ""find"" button on the charger to locate a misplaced remote by making it beep
* The team discussed challenges with using speech recognition in the remote
* Background noise from TV could unintentionally trigger remote functions
* Multiple people giving commands could confuse the remote
* Large vocabulary needed to navigate many channels by name vs. number
* Recognition may not work well in noisy environments like factories
* Discussed ideas for making the remote control more user-friendly
* Allow user to train the remote with a custom voice command vocabulary
* Display a matrix of images from available channels to select from visually
* Include an on/off switch for speech recognition mode
* Provide a ""child lock"" feature to limit kids' access to certain functions
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

833,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The Welsh Government has been working closely with higher education (HE) and further education (FE) institutions to understand the potential impact of Brexit

column2: * A ""no deal"" Brexit could have significant negative consequences for the HE and FE sectors in Wales
* Officials have been visiting individual institutions to discuss their preparedness for a ""no deal"" scenario
* Funding for many activities is believed to be secure until December 2020 even under ""no deal""
* The Welsh Government is encouraging institutions to make their own plans to deal with Brexit scenarios

column1: * EU student applications to Welsh universities have seen a significant drop, likely due to changes in tuition fee grants previously available to them

column2: * This puts Wales in a similar position as England in terms of attracting EU students
* The Welsh Government is working with universities to increase international student recruitment to offset potential losses
* Specific action is being taken with institutions seeing the biggest drops to prevent further declines due to Brexit
* An additional ¬£6.4 million was provided to the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales to help with Brexit challenges

column1: * The Welsh Government wants to maintain the range of learning opportunities in FE that are currently funded by the EU

column2: * They are pushing the UK government to fulfill promises that Wales will not lose funding due to Brexit
* Replacing lost EU funding for FE would require around ¬£15 million per year
* Apprenticeship programs are currently on track to meet targets, but a ""no deal"" Brexit could undermine this

column1: * Cooperation is happening across Welsh Government departments to safeguard FE and HE interests

column2: * Work is underway on a rural skills policy to support sectors like agriculture that may be hardest hit
* ¬£10 million in funding is being used to encourage FE to be more responsive to employer needs
* Reviews of FE funding are considering how to adapt to the impacts of Brexit

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

842,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The team is working on the semantics of a belief-net inference engine for the system to make decisions

column2: * They need to figure out the choices, what influences the choices, and do technical work on belief relations and probability estimates
* They will work with Fey on what should be in the dialogues to collect data from subjects
* The goal is to get information on how people phrase different intentions

column1: * Fey will collect dialogue data from subjects who think they are interacting with a computer system

column2: * Subjects will read tasks with German words, read isolated proper names, choose 6 tasks to do in Heidelberg, and call a computer system that works perfectly
* After 3 tasks, the system will ""break down"" and Fey will come on as a human operator to continue
* This will show differences in how people speak to a machine vs a human

column1: * The team reviews a table of the kinds of things that might come up and the kinds of decisions needed

column2: * The middle column of decisions seems feasible to build belief-nets for
* They discuss whether to make the scenarios/choices for data collection more complex or keep them simpler at first
* Keeping choices simpler and more constrained will make the data easier to handle, especially for the speech recognition

column1: * For the first round of data collection, they decide to limit the detail and types of places/activities

column2: * Provide one member of each category rather than all options (e.g. zoo or castle, not both)
* This will allow more pronunciations of the same things rather than a few pronunciations of many things
* They can expand the complexity later if needed after reviewing the initial data

column1: * The decision nodes in the system include things like:

column2: * Whether to go somewhere (yes/no), the reason for going (sightseeing, socializing, errands, business), timing (now, later, next day)
* The endpoint (enter, view, approach), mode of transportation, length of visit, cost willing to spend
* Whether the user wants any information about the object/place (open/closed, location, history, etc.)

column1: * In parallel, the team will:

column2: * Build a belief-net with conditional probability tables",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 843,"Here is a summary of the key points from the meeting discussion:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The focus was on planning data collection and designing the belief network for the dialogue system

column2: ‚Ä¢ They will collect data from subjects interacting with a simulated system, then a human, to see differences

column1: ‚Ä¢ The belief network will make decisions about parameters to pass to other system modules

column2: ‚Ä¢ They discussed the decision nodes and factors that influence the system's choices

column1: ‚Ä¢ For data collection, they will have subjects choose from a list of tourist activities and interact with the system

column2: ‚Ä¢ They want to collect data on how people phrase different intentions and requests

column1: ‚Ä¢ They plan to do a first batch of data collection with 10 subjects, then review the complexity of the dialogues

column2: ‚Ä¢ They may adjust the scenarios to elicit more complex interactions if needed after the first round

column1: ‚Ä¢ In parallel, the team will build an initial belief network while data collection gets started

column2: ‚Ä¢ The belief network will try to infer the decision node values from the collected data

column1: ‚Ä¢ They also discussed what semantic constructions and phrasings they want to try to elicit in the data

column2: ‚Ä¢ This ties into Keith's thesis work on building a limited parser to handle the constructions

column1: ‚Ä¢ The plan is to implement a subset of constructions to provide end-to-end understanding of some dialogues

column2: ‚Ä¢ Choosing which constructions to focus on will depend on Keith's research interests as well

column1: ‚Ä¢ They may design some ""ideal"" sample dialogues to demonstrate the system's capabilities when finished

column2: ‚Ä¢ These would have complete coverage of the targeted constructions and phrasings

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

847,"Here is a summary of the discussion about production finance in 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

‚Ä¢ The team evaluated their remote control design using a questionnaire with a 7-point scale

column2: ‚Ä¢ The design scored mostly 2s (with 1 being best), indicating it met most criteria well
‚Ä¢ Key criteria included being fancy, innovative, easy to use, and having easy-to-find buttons

column1: ‚Ä¢ To determine production costs, the team filled out a spreadsheet of the remote's components

column2: ‚Ä¢ Initial estimated cost was ‚Ç¨18.50, significantly over the ‚Ç¨12.50 target cost
‚Ä¢ To reduce cost, they removed the speech recognition, sample speaker, and scroll wheel

column1: ‚Ä¢ After the changes, the estimated production cost was reduced to ‚Ç¨12.50, meeting the target

column2: ‚Ä¢ However, this required eliminating some of the more advanced features of the remote
‚Ä¢ The team was disappointed to lose the scroll wheel and speech recognition capabilities

column1: ‚Ä¢ With the revised, lower-cost design, the team created an updated prototype drawing

column2: ‚Ä¢ The updated prototype maintained the core functionality and overall style of the original
‚Ä¢ Some final tweaks were made to the drawing to remove the microphone and other elements

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

849,"Here is a summary of the key points from the text, with 2 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The User Interface and Industrial Design disagreed on redesigning the remote control due to the limited budget

column2: ‚Ä¢ They had to drop many features like speech recognition, special colors, and curved design to meet the budget
‚Ä¢ This resulted in a very basic remote with only 1 scroll wheel button and a LCD screen
‚Ä¢ The User Interface felt this made the remote hard to use and not very fashionable anymore
‚Ä¢ However, they had no choice due to the strict budget constraints from management

column1: ‚Ä¢ Despite the limitations, the team tried to make the remote as appealing as possible

column2: ‚Ä¢ They used a special color (red with purple dots) for the plastic casing
‚Ä¢ The LCD screen will display ""Welcome, this is your Real Remote"" and the company logo
‚Ä¢ However, the Industrial Designer admitted the final design was ""really ugly"" compared to the original
‚Ä¢ The Marketing rep said it still has some trendy features like the LCD screen, even if not ideal

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
850,"Here is a summary of the key points from the discussion:
<summary>
* The industrial designer did not initially agree with marketing and user interface because:

column2: * An LCD screen and speech recognition would be very expensive and difficult to include
* The remote control needs to be universal which adds complexity
* There are significant space constraints for fitting all the desired components

column1: * Marketing presented survey data showing users want:

column2: * A way to find the remote when it's lost, like a beeping noise
* An LCD screen and speech recognition and are willing to pay more for it
* Changeable covers for customization

column1: * They discussed the key buttons and layout of the remote:

column2: * Power, channel, and volume buttons should be most prominent
* Other buttons like menu and mute are less important
* Debated whether LCD screen should go on top or bottom

column1: * The remote should be distinct and appeal to people under 40:

column2: * Stylish design with curves, different from other remotes
* Changeable covers for trendiness and customization
* Rechargeable with a docking station

column1: * Next steps are for each team member to research:

column2: * User interface designer - button layout and design
* Industrial designer - component costs and technical feasibility
* Marketing - price sensitivity and essential features

column1: * Key decisions to make:

column2: * Whether to include an LCD screen
* Placement of LCD screen and main buttons
* How to fit all components into the device

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

853,"Here is a summary of the discussion in 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The team discussed the prototype remote control design

column2: ‚Ä¢ It has a mango shape, rubber coating, and circular button layout for ergonomics

column1: ‚Ä¢ They explained the plus button is used for entering channel numbers greater than 9

column2: ‚Ä¢ There was some confusion over whether to press the number or plus button first

column1: ‚Ä¢ The color scheme is based on fruits like banana (yellow and black) to match the company colors

column2: ‚Ä¢ Other color options discussed were watermelon, apple green, pomegranate, and vanilla

column1: ‚Ä¢ An alarm feature causes the remote to light up and make noise when lost

column2: ‚Ä¢ This was not shown on the prototype but will be included

column1: ‚Ä¢ The team evaluated the prototype based on the original criteria and goals

column2: ‚Ä¢ Ratings were given on a 1-7 scale, with 1 being the best

column1: ‚Ä¢ Key criteria included: fancy look and feel, technological innovation, ease of use, appearance, price point, matching user behavior, ability to find when lost, ease of learning, minimizing RSI effects, incorporating company color and logo

column2: ‚Ä¢ The prototype scored well overall, averaging between a 1 and 2 rating

column1: ‚Ä¢ The project stayed within the target budget of 12.50 euros per unit

column2: ‚Ä¢ Kinetic power and a double curved shape added to the cost

column1: ‚Ä¢ In evaluating the project, the team felt more time and materials could have enabled greater creativity

column2: ‚Ä¢ However, leadership, teamwork and idea generation were all positive

column1: ‚Ä¢ The project was deemed a success - it met the budget and evaluated positively

column2: ‚Ä¢ The team planned to celebrate and complete a final questionnaire and meeting summary

854,"Here is a summary of the meeting in the requested format:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Mango-shaped design with rubber coating for comfort and to reduce repetitive strain injury

855,"Here is a summary of the meeting in the requested format:
<summary>
* The team introduced themselves: Adam Duguid (Project Manager), Ebenezer Ademesoye (Marketing Expert), Tarik Rahman (Industrial Designer), and Dave Cochrane (User Interface Designer)

column2: * They drew their favorite animals on the whiteboard as an icebreaker
* The project goal is to design an original, trendy, and user-friendly remote control

column1: * The project will have 3 phases: functional, architectural, and detailed design

column2: * The budget is 12.50 Euros per unit, aiming to sell for 25 Euros each
* The profit target is 50 million Euros, requiring a large volume of sales

column1: * Ideas were discussed for differentiating the remote control in the market

column2: * High-end remotes have touch screens and advanced programmability, but are expensive
* Suggested creating a lower-cost remote with some advanced functionality using conventional buttons

column1: * The remote could control multiple devices in an integrated way and allow for programming macros

column2: * For example, turning on the TV, DVD player, and sound system with one button press
* Or pressing play on the DVD remote could turn on the TV and switch to the correct input

column1: * Marketing suggested targeting the gaming and interactive TV market

column2: * Current remotes wear out easily and are not ideal for gaming
* Large, dedicated buttons for gaming functions and changing camera angles could be incorporated

column1: * Industrial Designer proposed including a small joystick or control pad for easier navigation and gaming

column2: * Most people are familiar with this type of interface from game consoles and even mobile phones
* The joystick could also enable easy menu navigation

column1: * User Interface Designer emphasized the importance of an ergonomic design that fits comfortably in the hand

column2: * An unconventional, attractive shape could be used to make the remote stand out
* A curved, biomorphic form could both conform to the hand and look stylish

column1: * The meeting wrapped up with a plan to write up the discussion points and share with the team

column2: * The next steps are to start working on the remote control design based on the ideas generated
* Microphones were left in the room and team members took their laptops with them

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
856,"Here is a summary of the key points from the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ There is debate over whether eligibility for free school meals is the best measure for targeting PDG funding

column2: ‚Ä¢ PDG should only be used for individual interventions for free school meal eligible pupils, but can fund universal interventions if they disproportionately benefit those pupils
‚Ä¢ The government is looking at ways to provide more flexibility in PDG allocations to schools

column1: ‚Ä¢ Attainment of looked after children remains disappointing despite PDG funding

column2: ‚Ä¢ An external evaluation is being done on the impact of PDG funding for looked after children
‚Ä¢ Cross-government collaboration is needed to improve educational outcomes for looked after children, not just relying on PDG

column1: ‚Ä¢ Some Schools Challenge Cymru schools made good progress while others did not during the 3-year program

column2: ‚Ä¢ Differences were due to factors like school leadership, quality of advisors, and complexity of challenges faced
‚Ä¢ The government is applying lessons learned, like the importance of leadership, to the wider school improvement system

column1: ‚Ä¢ There are differing views on whether the Schools Challenge Cymru program had sufficient time and transition support

column2: ‚Ä¢ The government maintains it was always intended as a 3-year program and transitioned support to regional consortia
‚Ä¢ Some feel the program faded out in the final year and more time was needed to sustain momentum

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
857,"Here is a summary of the key points from the text in the requested format:
<summary>
* The PDG is being used effectively by the majority of schools, but there is room for improvement in ensuring consistent best practices across all schools

column2: * New regional PDG advisers will help spread good practices and provide strategic advice

column1: * The PDG should be used to support all eligible pupils, including more able and talented free school meal pupils, not just low attainers

column2: * Schools need to demonstrate that universal PDG interventions have a disproportionate positive impact on free school meal pupils

column1: * The Welsh Government is looking at ways to make PDG funding more flexible for schools, such as providing allocations for multiple years, but an ""Ever 6"" model would cost an additional ¬£40 million

column2: * Officials are working to understand the impact of Universal Credit on identifying pupils eligible for free school meals

column1: * Attendance rates are much lower for free school meal pupils compared to other pupils

column2: * Some schools are using PDG creatively to improve attendance, such as sending staff to walk eligible pupils to school

column1: * The Welsh Government wants to improve data collection and information sharing to better track and support adopted pupils, but cannot force families to disclose adoptions

column2: * Making parents aware of PDG support for adopted children could encourage voluntary disclosure

column1: * The latest attainment data for looked after children is disappointing

column2: * An independent review is evaluating the impact of regional PDG spending on looked after children

column1: * Schools Challenge Cymru had mixed results - some schools made more progress than others

column2: * Differences were due to factors like the initial challenges faced, quality of advisers, leadership changes, and how early a new head teacher was appointed

column1: * Key lessons from Schools Challenge Cymru are being applied to the wider school improvement system, such as the importance of leadership, tracking pupil progress, teacher quality, and school-to-school collaboration

column2: * Many Challenge advisers have moved into regional consortia roles to spread best practices

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
858,"Here is a summary of the discussion about why children on free school meals were less resilient in the exam system last year:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ There is no one single reason why free school meal children were less resilient in exams last year

column2: ‚Ä¢ Possible factors include the move from BTECs to science GCSEs and the impact of studying literature
‚Ä¢ The Cabinet Secretary will have a deep dive discussion on this topic at the next ministerial policy board in May
‚Ä¢ Officials are working with Qualifications Wales to better understand the issue

column1: ‚Ä¢ While the overall gap widened in 2017, there has been a narrowing of the gap over the period that PDG has been employed

column2: ‚Ä¢ In 2009, 1 in 5 free school meal children got Level 2 plus, improving to 1 in 3 by 2016
‚Ä¢ Some schools saw improved free school meal performance in 2017 compared to 2016
‚Ä¢ Need to understand what enabled free school meal children to do well in certain schools

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Cabinet Secretary emphasized that broad conclusions cannot be drawn and school-level factors are important

column2: ‚Ä¢ Large variations in free school meal performance can be seen even between similar schools in the same local authority
‚Ä¢ One school in Swansea had free school meal Level 2 performance of 88% while another similar school was in the 20% range
‚Ä¢ The challenge is to go into individual schools and understand what led to their children doing well or not

column1: ‚Ä¢ The government is moving away from using Level 2 plus as the main performance measure

column2: ‚Ä¢ A new, more sophisticated performance measure looking at individual pupil progress will be announced soon
‚Ä¢ Level 2 plus is seen as too narrow and has driven unintended behaviors in schools
‚Ä¢ Value added by schools in pupil performance will be a key part of the new measure

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
859,"Here is a summary of the key points from the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The EAS consortium uses the looked-after and adopted PDG as part of a broader approach targeted at vulnerable learners

column2: ‚Ä¢ This approach is not unique to EAS but is used across all 4 regions
‚Ä¢ The Cabinet Secretary believes if they get it right for the most vulnerable learners, they'll get it right for all learners

column1: ‚Ä¢ Attainment data for looked-after children is extremely disappointing and concerning

column2: ‚Ä¢ 66% of looked-after learners have some additional learning need (ALN)
‚Ä¢ Addressing ALNs and well-being is crucial to supporting looked-after children, not just PDG funding

column1: ‚Ä¢ Some Schools Challenge Cymru schools made sustained improvement while others did not

column2: ‚Ä¢ Differences were due to varying complexity of needs and effectiveness of support advisers
‚Ä¢ Key lessons learned include importance of leadership, systems and processes, teacher quality, and collaboration

column1: ‚Ä¢ There are differing views on the level of engagement between the government and Professor Ainscow after Schools Challenge Cymru ended

column2: ‚Ä¢ Prof. Ainscow felt there was little follow-up to learn lessons from the program
‚Ä¢ The Cabinet Secretary and officials said there were some meetings and discussions to gain insights and transfer staff to regional consortia

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
860,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Kirsty Williams discussed the progress and condition of Schools Challenge Cymru

column2: ‚Ä¢ The program aimed to improve outcomes in underperforming schools
‚Ä¢ It was a 3-year time-limited program that some felt needed more time
‚Ä¢ There were mixed results, with some schools showing improvement and others not
‚Ä¢ Factors like leadership changes and quality of advisors impacted success

column1: ‚Ä¢ Lessons learned from the program are being applied to wider school improvement efforts

column2: ‚Ä¢ Successful interventions and best practices are being embedded in regional consortia support
‚Ä¢ Some personnel from the program transitioned to roles in the regional consortia
‚Ä¢ The program helped build capacity in the regional school improvement services
‚Ä¢ A whole-system approach is now being taken rather than just focusing on select schools

column1: ‚Ä¢ There was disagreement over whether the program had a ""fade out"" in its final year

column2: ‚Ä¢ The government saw it as a planned transition, not a fading out
‚Ä¢ But the program director felt there was less emphasis and momentum at the end
‚Ä¢ A formal closing event was held to recognize successes and thank participants
‚Ä¢ Key staff transitioned to the consortia to continue applying the work more broadly

column1: ‚Ä¢ Discussions were held with various stakeholders to gather lessons learned

column2: ‚Ä¢ This included school staff, consortia, local authorities, and government officials
‚Ä¢ However, the program director felt he wasn't engaged with enough afterwards
‚Ä¢ There seemed to be some disagreement over the level of follow-up that occurred
‚Ä¢ The Cabinet Secretary felt there was appropriate engagement, not a freezing out

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
861,"Here is a summary of the meeting using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Eva presented an update on her work with Probabilistic Relational Models (PRMs) for the travel planning system

column2: * She simplified the model and constructed classes like user, site, time, route, and query with relations between them
* The output is a rating of how desirable a site is for a user and the mode of visit (the EVA decision)

column1: * The group discussed the need to find an existing PRM implementation to use rather than building their own

column2: * If an implementation is found, Eva's model could be run to solve the travel planning problems
* Elaborations like planning for groups could be added later but the focus now is on finding an implementation

column1: * Andreas, a visiting researcher from Germany, introduced his work on smart FAQ systems for e-learning

column2: * The system tries to retrieve relevant documents to answer a user's question based on context information
* Challenges include representing context formally, performing inference, and scaling the system

column1: * The group suggested Andreas look into FrameNet as a potentially useful resource for his project

column2: * FrameNet could help map keywords to semantic frames to find more relevant documents
* Dan Gildea at ICSI has done related work on topic spotting using FrameNet that Andreas should discuss with him

column1: * Professor Feldman shared a story about Tom Kalil, who works on the CITRIS project at Berkeley

column2: * Kalil is interested in projects with high social impact, giving the example of an adult literacy tutoring system
* This resonated with the group's past unfunded proposal on a language tutoring system for non-native English speaking children in California

column1: * Robert mentioned he is in the process of writing up notes from their daily meetings and revising the original construal proposal

column2: * He hopes to have something to present on construal once Professor Feldman returns
* Pending items and distractions should be resolved soon to focus back on this

column1: * The group did not meet last week and likely will not meet next week due to several people being out of town

column2: * When Daphne returns, they plan to get more connected with the Stanford group working on similar PRM research
* Someone from Berkeley will likely visit Stanford regularly to facilitate collaboration

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

863,"Here is a summary of the discussion about the Industrial Designer's presentation on technical design:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Industrial Designer described the basic components of a remote control:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Battery power supply
‚Ä¢ User interface (LCD or push buttons)
‚Ä¢ Electronic chip for numerical computation
‚Ä¢ Infrared LED to send signals to the TV

864,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Dr Frank Atherton and Nathan Cook discussed the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy with the committee

column2: ‚Ä¢ They are confident it will deliver for children and young people and have engaged with them during the consultation process

column1: ‚Ä¢ Targets for reducing childhood obesity were discussed

column2: ‚Ä¢ Dr Atherton advised that any targets chosen need to balance deliverability with challenge

column1: ‚Ä¢ The level of investment needed to implement the plan is estimated at ¬£8-10 million per year

column2: ‚Ä¢ This would need to be drawn from existing programs and there may be a case for new investment

column1: ‚Ä¢ Expanding the child measurement program to include a second measurement later in childhood was considered

column2: ‚Ä¢ This could provide helpful longitudinal data but has resource implications that need to be weighed

column1: ‚Ä¢ Using the planning system to restrict fast food outlets near schools is an idea to explore further

column2: ‚Ä¢ Some local authorities in England have implemented this but the effectiveness is still to be determined

column1: ‚Ä¢ Building health considerations into the design of new schools and public infrastructure is important

column2: ‚Ä¢ Health impact assessments should be used more to inform these decisions

column1: ‚Ä¢ Engaging children in physical activity at school requires making sports and exercise enjoyable and attractive

column2: ‚Ä¢ Guidance for schools on physical education could be considered

column1: ‚Ä¢ Reviewing and updating the clinical obesity pathway for children is underway

column2: ‚Ä¢ Key elements include information access, identifying overweight children, and targeted support for the very overweight

column1: ‚Ä¢ Supporting low-income families to make healthy choices is critical given higher obesity rates in deprived areas

column2: ‚Ä¢ Broader issues like food affordability, product formulation, and minimum wage need to be addressed

column1: ‚Ä¢ Expanding access to dietetic support and weight management advice in primary care is desirable

column2: ‚Ä¢ Redesigning care pathways is needed so people know where to go for help with weight issues

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
865,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Dr. Frank Atherton said they need to consult on whether to set a target for reducing childhood obesity in Wales

column2: * A target should balance deliverability with challenge
* Targets are one tool that could be used for performance management
* The final strategy may consider including a target

column1: * Gaps in childhood obesity data could be addressed by expanding the child measurement program

column2: * Measuring children at school entry and again later would provide a longitudinal view
* This would have significant resource implications for funding and schools
* It would help with better understanding and evaluation of interventions

column1: * The strategy aims to create healthy environments and settings to promote healthy weight

column2: * Considering restricting hot food takeaways near schools through the planning system
* Ensuring new schools have adequate facilities like changing rooms to enable community use
* Working with education on teacher training and embedding physical activity in the curriculum

column1: * Reviewing and updating the clinical obesity pathway for children is important

column2: * Public Health Wales is undertaking this review to inform the final strategy
* The pathway involves a tiered approach with interventions at different levels
* More targeted support is needed for severely overweight children

column1: * The first 1,000 days are critical in shaping children's lives and preventing obesity

column2: * Improving breastfeeding rates and the Healthy Start scheme are key
* Pregnancy is an opportune time to work with mothers on behavior change
* Supporting low-income families to afford healthy food is also important

column1: * Making every contact count requires availability of professionals to provide advice and referrals

column2: * Expanding the range of health professionals in primary care, like dietitians
* Redesigning care pathways to improve access to weight management support
* This applies to both adults and children who are overweight or obese

column1: * The committee's input on the strategy from a children's perspective is welcomed

column2: * Funding from the soft drinks levy could potentially be used for obesity initiatives
* Leadership and accountability for delivering the strategy need to be clarified
* An evaluation framework with metrics to measure progress will be critical

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
866,"Here is a summary of the discussion in 5 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

868,"Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column1: ‚Ä¢ Targets and investment for reducing childhood obesity were discussed

column2: ‚Ä¢ Dr Atherton advised that a deliverable target, rather than an aspirational one, is needed

column1: ‚Ä¢ The importance of creating healthy environments and settings was emphasized

column2: ‚Ä¢ Restricting hot food takeaways near schools through the planning system is being considered
‚Ä¢ Ensuring new schools have adequate facilities for community sports and activities was discussed

column1: ‚Ä¢ Embedding healthy habits early on through preschools, the foundation phase, and the new curriculum was seen as crucial

column2: ‚Ä¢ Teacher training and accountability for student health outcomes were debated
‚Ä¢ Making physical education engaging for all children, not just team sports, was highlighted

column1: ‚Ä¢ Reviewing and updating school nutrition regulations and clinical obesity pathways is planned

column2: ‚Ä¢ School meal quality and packed lunch contents were identified as key areas to address
‚Ä¢ The clinical obesity pathway review aims to identify gaps in targeted support for overweight children

column1: ‚Ä¢ Supporting low-income families to make healthy choices was recognized as important for reducing inequalities

column2: ‚Ä¢ Addressing deeper socioeconomic determinants of health was seen as necessary for real progress

column1: 870,"Here is a summary of the meeting recap using 7 bullet points with 1 level of sub-points:
<summary>

‚Ä¢ The user interface designer presented that the remote should have 9 channel buttons, next/volume/subtitle buttons, memory switch, mute button, and speech recognition. It should be child-friendly with few colorful buttons.

column2: ‚Ä¢ She presented an oversized remote design that would be hard to lose.

column1: ‚Ä¢ The industrial designer wants a strong plastic recyclable case, sophisticated temperature-resistant integrated circuit board, timer/alarm, and rechargeable battery. It would use simple push-button technology.

column2: ‚Ä¢ The circuit board would be inexpensive to build.

column1: ‚Ä¢ The marketing expert wants the remote to be small, easy to use, eye-catching, and beat the competition to market by focusing on 1-2 key features. She prefers a fruit/vegetable design with a soft feel.

column2: ‚Ä¢ The team decided to focus on speech recognition, battery power, trendy compact design, and buttons.

column1: ‚Ä¢ The team presented a snail-shaped prototype with raised colorful buttons that can all be reached with one thumb. It has a menu button, volume buttons, channel buttons, and a special swapping button.

column2: ‚Ä¢ The marketing expert really liked the shape, colors, and one-handed usability of the prototype.

column1: ‚Ä¢ The prototype is estimated to cost ‚Ç¨8.20 to produce, well within the ‚Ç¨12.50 target. However, this does not include the cost of adding voice recognition.

column2: ‚Ä¢ The team realizes they need to research if the remaining ‚Ç¨4.30 in the budget is enough to cover adding quality voice recognition.

column1: ‚Ä¢ The marketing expert plans to test the prototype with focus groups and make final tweaks before launching the product. The unique voice recognition feature and cute, easy-to-use snail design will be the key selling points.

column2: ‚Ä¢ Some final button consolidation may be needed to make room for the voice recognition feature while staying in budget.

column1: ‚Ä¢ Overall, the team is very satisfied with their creativity, leadership, teamwork and the final product design. They believe it will be feasible to produce and very marketable.

column2: ‚Ä¢ The project is considered complete, under budget, and evaluated positively by the team. It's time to celebrate!

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

873,"Here is a summary of the key points from the meeting:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The PDA microphones have a lot of low frequency noise at 5 Hz that needs to be filtered out

column2: ‚Ä¢ Dan Ellis suggested using a smaller capacitor or digital filter to remove the noise without changing the data already collected

column1: ‚Ä¢ Stephane's changes to the system, including a new filter, did not improve performance convincingly and hurt performance slightly on the well-matched case

column2: ‚Ä¢ The weighting of improvements in the final score calculation makes small changes on the well-matched case have a large effect

column1: ‚Ä¢ The group discussed focusing efforts and avoiding duplicating work that OGI is doing on spectral subtraction

column2: ‚Ä¢ They identified other areas to work on like latency reduction, a second feature stream, and voice activity detection

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

875,"Here is a summary of the key points from the discussion:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Professor C announces that Hans-Guenter will be visiting for 3 weeks to collaborate and provide input on their research

column2: ‚Ä¢ He is very knowledgeable and easy to talk to
‚Ä¢ The grad students should plan to discuss their work with him

column1: ‚Ä¢ Sunil presents results on using Wiener filtering for noise reduction

column2: ‚Ä¢ A single stage Wiener filter gives a 30% improvement over the MFCC baseline
‚Ä¢ Using a second stage of Wiener filtering with smoothing improves performance to 56.5% over baseline
‚Ä¢ Using the channel 0 VAD endpoints further improves performance to 67% over baseline, showing the importance of good VAD

column1: ‚Ä¢ Stephane presents results on using spectral subtraction for noise reduction

column2: ‚Ä¢ Subtracting more at low SNRs by overestimating the noise does not improve performance alone
‚Ä¢ Applying nonlinear smoothing of the spectral subtraction gain helps, giving slightly better results than Wiener filtering on Italian data
‚Ä¢ The smoothing helps reduce musical noise artifacts

column1: ‚Ä¢ They discuss how spectral subtraction can lead to negative spectrum values which are typically thresholded or filled in

column2: ‚Ä¢ Leaving the negatives or not subtracting those bins are alternative approaches to consider
‚Ä¢ Musical noise may sound bad but it's unclear if it actually hurts recognition performance

column1: ‚Ä¢ The France Telecom system uses a variant of Wiener filtering with both time and frequency domain smoothing

column2: ‚Ä¢ Stephane's and Sunil's approaches are conceptually similar with multiple stages of noise reduction and smoothing
‚Ä¢ They are evaluating multiple techniques like Wiener filtering, spectral subtraction, and subspace methods to determine what works best

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

895,"Here is a summary of the discussion about options for energy sources in the given text:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The main internal feature of the remote control is a circuit board containing electronics and contacts with the power source

column2: ‚Ä¢ Components include the integrated circuit (chip), diodes, transistors, resonators, resistors, and capacitors
‚Ä¢ An LED (light emitting diode) allows for flexibility with colors
‚Ä¢ The positioning of all components in the circuit needs to be considered

column1: ‚Ä¢ Several possibilities exist for the energy source of the remote control

column2: ‚Ä¢ A basic battery has drawbacks like the need for recharging, bulk, and environmental disposal issues
‚Ä¢ A hand-powered dynamo, where the user manually charges the power, is considered outdated
‚Ä¢ Kinetic energy, where shaking the device provides power, is a recently developed option
‚Ä¢ Solar power may not be useful inside a building where the remote will be used

column1: ‚Ä¢ The group prefers the kinetic energy source as an advanced, attractive, and energy-saving technology

column2: ‚Ä¢ It eliminates the need for an external battery supply or solar panels
‚Ä¢ Shaking the device instantly generates the energy needed to power the circuit
‚Ä¢ This could be a selling point as a cutting-edge feature of the remote control

column1: ‚Ä¢ A backup power option is discussed in case the kinetic energy source has issues

column2: ‚Ä¢ Suggestions include using a single backup battery or possibly solar power
‚Ä¢ Solar power would require the remote to be left in light for a few hours each day to charge
‚Ä¢ The group decides solar is impractical since the remote may be kept in the dark, requiring daily charging

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

899,"Here is a summary of the key points from the text in the requested format:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Professor discussed the Aurora project and competition between different groups

column2: ‚Ä¢ French Telecom Alcatel and the Professor's group both had voice activity detectors, which was seen as unfair by other groups
‚Ä¢ There was disagreement over whether the evaluation should be redone without voice activity detectors or if the algorithm could be modified
‚Ä¢ French Telecom was concerned other groups would copy their code if a new evaluation was done
‚Ä¢ The Professor's group was willing to share their code and techniques

column1: ‚Ä¢ There was debate over the criteria and weighting for the Aurora evaluation

column2: ‚Ä¢ Some groups wanted to lower the improvement threshold from 50% to 25% for mismatched conditions
‚Ä¢ The Professor thought this was a major decision being made too lightly and that they should try to reach 50% again
‚Ä¢ Nokia and Qualcomm supported keeping the 50% threshold
‚Ä¢ The Professor thought some groups were trying to match the criteria to their existing solution rather than improve the technology

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Professor's group at OGI was working on improving their system, especially noise separation

column2: ‚Ä¢ They were looking at using the LPC spectrum instead of FFT to be more robust to noise
‚Ä¢ They considered techniques like spectral subtraction and adding noise to all data to make any additive noise less effective
‚Ä¢ Most of their effort was on a new recognition approach using temporal patterns (TRAPs)

column1: ‚Ä¢ Stephane observed that the C1 cepstral coefficient was not very useful in their system

column2: ‚Ä¢ Removing C1 had little effect on performance
‚Ä¢ This led to a discussion on how to adjust the importance of different coefficients by modifying the model variances
‚Ä¢ Increasing variance would decrease importance of a coefficient; decreasing variance would increase importance

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Professor shared anecdotes highlighting inefficiencies and lack of oversight in some organizations

column2: ‚Ä¢ One company had an employee hitting carriage returns to inflate billable computer usage time
‚Ä¢ Soldiers manning a lookout post outsourced their one daily task of reporting a passing plane to a pub owner

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

903,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales provided evidence on the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education:

column2: * EU student applications to Wales decreased 8% while increasing 2% to England
* Non-EU international student applications to Wales also decreased 9%
* Reduced investment in Welsh university infrastructure compared to England may be a factor
* Universities are scenario planning but the uncertainty makes it challenging

column1: * The sector faces financial pressures from reduced EU funding, student recruitment, and pension costs

column2: * In 2017-18, PS38 million was expected from EU students and PS91 million from EU programs
* The sector had a PS17 million operating deficit in 2016-17
* Implementing the Diamond review recommendations on funding is crucial for sustainability
* Banks are becoming more risk averse in lending to universities

column1: * Replacing the Erasmus+ student mobility program would be difficult and costly if access is lost

column2: * Erasmus is a well-established infrastructure that enables international partnerships
* Some universities are allocating more of their own funding to support student mobility
* Maintaining access to the successor Horizon Europe research program is a priority

column1: * Brexit may impact the diversity and quality of the student experience if EU student numbers decline

column2: * Having international students enriches the curriculum and experience for all
* Financial pressures could strain universities'ability to maintain quality
* The sector wants to continue adhering to European higher education quality standards

column1: * Investment is needed to enable Welsh universities to better compete for UK research council funding

column2: * Wales has high quality and productive research but lacks sufficient scale and resources
* More QR funding would provide flexibility to pursue opportunities and cover overhead costs
* Engaging more in research council processes and committees would also help competitiveness

column1: * Uncertainty over future funding arrangements is a major challenge alongside Brexit

column2: * The sector needs confirmation that funding released from the Diamond review will be reinvested
* Demographic changes will also impact student recruitment in the coming years
* Delays in resolving these issues while the Brexit timeline advances is concerning

column1: * The Higher Education Funding Council is working to support and challenge universities through this period

column2: * Analyzing financial forecasts and sustainability of the sector and individual institutions
*",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

910,"Here is a summary of the team's brainstorming process for raising initial thoughts:
<summary>
* Project manager Heather introduced the team and the goal of designing a new television remote control
* Needs to be trendy, original, and marketable to appeal to a new generation
* Should be user-friendly, such as an ergonomic design or features for visually impaired
* Team will brainstorm ideas alone, then meet to discuss functional, conceptual and detailed designs
* Target selling price is 25 euros, with a maximum production cost of 12.50 euros
* Team did a whiteboard exercise to get acquainted, drawing their favorite animals
* Heather drew an elk, Poppy drew a cat, Tara attempted a dog, Genevieve drew a butterfly
* Exercise helped them practice using the whiteboard tool they will use for the project
* Drawings revealed a bit about each person's personality and artistic skills
* Discussion of initial ideas and personal experiences with remote controls
* Hard to see buttons in the dark, remote is easy to lose in the house
* Many buttons go unused and functions are unknown, could hide less-used buttons
* Consider non-standard shapes like a seashell that are still comfortable to hold
* Key aspects discussed for the new remote design
* Needs a way to make buttons visible in low light and include a locator feature
* Balance including novel features with universal appeal to maximize profitability
* Avoid a boring design, but not too outrageous - aim for trendy and original
* Next steps are for team members to brainstorm further on their own
* Will reconvene in 30 minutes to discuss ideas in more detail
* Industrial designer will begin working design, UI designer on technical functions
* Marketing expert to provide user requirements; all will get specific instructions
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

913,"Here is a summary of the team's discussion and decision on the energy source of the remote control:
<summary>
* The team discussed various power options for the remote control including:

column2: * Solar cells
* Hand dynamo
* Kinetic power (shaking the remote to charge it)

column1: * They debated between using a charging base station or regular batteries

column2: * A base station would require the remote to be larger
* Batteries would allow for a more compact remote size
* Customers tend to prefer smaller electronics based on current trends

column1: * The team decided against a charging base station in favor of regular batteries

column2: * This allows the remote to be more compact and portable
* Batteries are cheaper than a charging base station
* Lithium batteries were suggested as a longer-lasting option

column1: * They discussed possibly including 1 lithium battery with the initial purchase

column2: * Lithium batteries can be acquired cheaply in bulk
* The battery could last up to 5 years before needing replacement
* Providing the initial battery is more convenient for the customer

column1: * The final decision was to power the remote with 1 included lithium battery

column2: * This balances cost, size, and customer convenience
* Extra batteries can be purchased separately by the customer as needed
* The compact battery allows the remote to remain small and portable

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

917,"Here is a summary of the meeting in 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The team discussed components concepts and user interface concepts for the remote control

column2: * They decided on a combination of battery and kinetic energy for power
* The case will be double-curved and made of rubber in a flashy, fruity color with a removable cover
* Buttons will be on a touch-screen with a simple menu structure and not too many levels
* Games will be incorporated into the remote

column1: * Marketing presented trend research findings from Paris and Milan

column2: * The main audience (below 40) prefers fresh, bright colors and soft, spongy materials
* The secondary audience (above 40) prefers dark, traditional colors and materials like wood
* New remotes should look fancy, be technologically innovative, and easy to use
* Removable covers could allow for customization, like in the mobile phone market

column1: * The user interface will have a large touch screen with primary buttons always visible

column2: * The menu structure will be changeable to show relevant options
* It should be usable with one hand, with the thumb on main buttons
* They want to avoid too many functions at once and too many menu levels

column1: * Voice recognition was deemed too complex and not suitable for a remote control
* Parental control functionality will be incorporated but kept simple, as an optional menu setting

column2: * Parents can restrict certain channels or set time limits for when the remote won't work
* The team acknowledged kids could still access the TV buttons directly, but felt that was the parents' responsibility

column1: * The team wants to present their company as a single, large, trustworthy provider

column2: * The company name and ""We put fashion in electronics"" slogan could appear on the remote's screen at startup
* A small spinning logo could remain in the corner of the screen

column1: * The industrial designer and user interface designer will work together on a prototype using a SMARTboard
* The marketing expert will work on product evaluation
* More specific instructions will be emailed to the team members
* The project manager thanked everyone for a good session and reminded them the next meeting is in 30 minutes
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
918,"Here is a summary of the key points about the marketing expert's evaluation of the prototype based on past user requirements and trends analysis:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The marketing expert led an evaluation of the prototype remote control design using a 7-point scale on various criteria

column2: ‚Ä¢ The group had to reach consensus on each rating through discussion

column1: ‚Ä¢ Overall, the prototype scored well, with an average rating of 1.86, meaning most requirements were rated as ""true"" or ""very true""

column2: ‚Ä¢ Key strengths included being innovative, having fresh colors, and including advanced features like speech recognition and games

column1: ‚Ä¢ A few areas were rated lower, such as not being designed only for those under 40 and not being extremely easy to use

column2: ‚Ä¢ This was due to trade-offs made to include more advanced functionality while still appealing to a broad age range

column1: ‚Ä¢ The marketing expert compiled the individual ratings and calculated the overall favorable average score of 1.86 out of 7

column2: ‚Ä¢ This indicated the prototype effectively met most of the key user requirements and trends identified earlier

column1: ‚Ä¢ With a positive evaluation, the project could proceed forward, as long as the prototype could be produced within the ‚Ç¨12.50 cost target

column2: ‚Ä¢ The project manager would need to assess the production costs to determine if any design changes were needed to meet the cost requirement

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
