922,"Here is a summary of the key points from the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The Cabinet Secretary for Education values the Welsh baccalaureate qualification and believes it provides a broad and balanced curriculum

column2: * Many learners have expressed positive experiences studying for the Welsh bac
* Some concerns exist around workload and the qualification's impact on student well-being

column1: * There is variability in how the Welsh bac is delivered across schools

column2: * Leadership and teacher attitudes play a key role in the perception of the qualification
* The government is working to ensure greater consistency in delivery

column1: * The Cabinet Secretary is confident that universities, including Russell Group institutions, value the Welsh bac

column2: * The graded Welsh bac is considered equivalent to an A-level by many universities
* Project-based skills developed through the Welsh bac are beneficial for university study

column1: * The government expects universal adoption of the Welsh bac by 2020

column2: * All institutions should be able to deliver the qualification, though some flexibility may be needed
* Professional learning is crucial to ensure teachers can deliver the Welsh bac effectively

column1: * Studying the Welsh bac alongside A-levels can be stressful for some students

column2: * The government recognizes the need to support student well-being during this challenging time
* Flexibility and guidance may be needed to ensure the Welsh bac is suitable for all learners

column1: * The Welsh bac is not believed to narrow the curriculum at Key Stage 4

column2: * It should be part of a wide range of opportunities and not prioritized over other subjects
* Ongoing review aims to address concerns about teacher workload and assessment

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
923,"Here is a summary of the discussion using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Deputy Minister responded to concerns that nearly 70% of individuals who responded to the consultation do not support the bill to ban physical punishment of children

column2: ‚Ä¢ She said the bill aims to prohibit all forms of physical punishment to protect children's rights, not address child abuse
‚Ä¢ She acknowledged people have different views but believes the law should not defend physical punishment of children

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Deputy Minister was asked how the government will work with parents who consider physical punishment part of their parenting toolkit given limited resources

column2: ‚Ä¢ She said bringing up children is hard but there are many alternative methods to physical punishment
‚Ä¢ She pointed to support from professionals and representative surveys for the bill's principles

column1: ‚Ä¢ Concerns were raised about statistics from Sweden showing increased child-on-child violence after banning physical punishment

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Deputy Minister said evidence is mixed, with a large cross-national study of 88 countries showing less youth violence when corporal punishment is prohibited
‚Ä¢ She said the decision is based on a commitment to children's rights

column1: ‚Ä¢ It was noted the bill's explanatory memorandum says there is no definitive evidence that reasonable physical punishment causes negative outcomes, contrary to some views

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Deputy Minister said they commissioned balanced independent research showing all physical punishment is potentially harmful
‚Ä¢ She said there is no peer-reviewed research showing physically punishing a child has favorable outcomes

column1: ‚Ä¢ Concerns were raised about how agencies will address malicious reporting and whether the public interest test will be applied appropriately

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Deputy Minister said an implementation group with key stakeholders is working on addressing many of these issues
‚Ä¢ She is confident the legislation will be implemented in a practical and workable way with the commitment of agencies

column1: ‚Ä¢ Questions were asked about whether social services may change their thresholds for intervention if more cases are referred to them

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Deputy Minister said social services already investigate reports of physical punishment and use standard procedures
‚Ä¢ She does not expect the threshold of significant harm to change based on evidence from the Association of Directors of Social Services Cymru

column1: ‚Ä¢ The need for consistently effective multi-agency safeguarding hubs across the country was discussed

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Deputy Minister said effective implementation does not depend on MASHs as social services already work closely with police
‚Ä¢ She said other joint working mechanisms are in place but MASH",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

940,"Here is a summary of the key points from the meeting transcript:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The meeting discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Schools are currently open in many settings as hubs for vulnerable children and children of key workers
‚Ä¢ The Minister will decide to move to a new phase of reopening schools more widely when advised it is safe to do so by the chief medical officer, but this is not imminent

‚Ä¢ Principles for the decision include safety, alignment with the wider Welsh Government pandemic response, clear communication to parents and staff, consideration of which groups of children should return first, and how to operationalize the reopening safely

column1: ‚Ä¢ Efforts are being made to support vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs:

column2: ‚Ä¢ The number of vulnerable children attending school hubs has doubled recently but is still small
‚Ä¢ Local authorities are risk assessing vulnerable children and exploring ways to support them, whether by attending hubs or through other contact if staying home is more appropriate
‚Ä¢ Schools are keeping in touch with vulnerable children and can still refer any concerns, and additional funding has been provided for remote counseling support

column1: ‚Ä¢ Plans are in place to address potential widening of inequalities and the attainment gap:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Officials are working with local authorities to ensure all children have access to the hardware and connectivity needed for digital learning
‚Ä¢ Advice for parents on supporting home learning is available on the Hwb platform
‚Ä¢ Grades for cancelled GCSE and A-level exams will be awarded based on teacher assessments and rankings, with a moderation process applied by Qualifications Wales

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

947,"Here is a summary of the key points about policies and measures related to free-school-meal children during the pandemic:
<summary>
* Schools will have a new purpose to support vulnerable children, children of key workers, and those who receive free school meals

column2: * Plans are being developed with local authorities to provide meals, even if children are not attending school
* Where schools start on Monday may change as more time allows for developing longer-term programs
* Youth services and other local authority staff may be deployed to help provide worthwhile activities for children

column1: * Provision aims to be seamless through the Easter holiday period

column2: * The goal is to have ongoing support and avoid gaps in the 2-week holiday
* This is important for families of front-line workers who will still need to work
* England may handle the holidays differently than Wales' plan for continuous provision

column1: * Discretion will be given to headteachers to identify vulnerable children who may need the provision

column2: * This could include those known to be in pressured home environments, even if not formally identified as vulnerable
* Young carers and those witnessing domestic abuse are highlighted as groups who may need access to school
* Teacher judgment will be respected to include children needing extra support

column1: * The overall provision has to balance supporting children with the public health goal of closing schools to help manage disease spread

column2: * Too many children still attending could undermine the epidemic mitigation efforts
* Displacement activities like children gathering at each other's houses needs to be discouraged
* The situation and public health advice is evolving rapidly so plans may need to adapt

column1: * Communicating the arrangements to parents is a priority

column2: * Multiple platforms are being used including social media, but a systematic approach through local authorities is key
* A dedicated web page with frequently asked questions will be set up to provide updated information
* Schools are already reaching out to parents to identify key worker families who will need provision

column2: * Universities have processes in place to support learners, drawing from lessons learned with students isolated in China and other parts of Asia

column1: * Consideration is being given to potentially refunding some tuition fees if the academic year is not completed

column1: * Universities have established feedback mechanisms for students to raise any concerns

955,"Here is a summary of the key points from the meeting:
<summary>
* The Children, Young People and Education Committee met with the Minister for Education and other officials to discuss the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales

column2: * Schools in Wales will close for statutory education provision but will have a new purpose to support vulnerable children, children of key workers, and ensure continuity of learning
* Arrangements are being made to continue providing free school meals and support for children with additional learning needs
* Local authorities are working with schools to determine which schools will remain open and how to staff them
* Childcare settings are expected to remain open unless advised otherwise by public health officials

column1: * The committee also discussed the cancellation of exams and how qualifications will be awarded

column2: * Students in years 11 and 13 will be awarded grades based on a range of evidence including previous exams and coursework
* Discussions are ongoing regarding how to handle AS-levels and vocational qualifications
* Universities have indicated they will accept the grades awarded to students
* Student finance payments and support will continue as normal

957,"Here is a summary of the meeting in the requested format:
<summary>
* The team received a newsflash with updated project requirements, but not everyone saw it

* The remote will have an LCD screen for advanced functions and a menu system
* Menu options include sound settings, channel programming, and screen settings
* Dedicated buttons will be used to navigate the on-screen menu
* Other features discussed include:
* A microphone for speech recognition
* Placing the company logo on the remote
* Illuminating active buttons with LED lights
* The industrial designer was unable to complete their full presentation in time

* More work is needed to incorporate the new project requirements
* The team sketched out a rough design for the remote control layout
* The LCD screen will be placed at the top
* Numeric buttons and volume/channel controls in the middle
* Menu navigation buttons near the bottom
* The user interface designer will create the on-screen menu layout and structure
* The industrial designer will provide a list of functions to include
* The menu will be organized into different screens with a layered structure
* Two groups of buttons were proposed - one for basic functions and one for the screen
* The arrow keys will be multi-functional for both menu navigation and volume/channel
* Dedicated ""Okay"" and ""Back"" buttons will be added for the on-screen menu
* The team was running short on time, so had to wrap up the discussion
* The project manager needs to prepare meeting minutes
* A short working session will follow after the lunch break
* Some open questions remain around the exact target age range and user group
* The remote should appeal to users from ages 16-40

column1: 960,"Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The group discussed the need for clarity in the law regarding physical punishment of children

column2: ‚Ä¢ Current law is unclear and ineffective in protecting children's rights
‚Ä¢ Physical punishment is harmful to children based on their own views and social services' experience
‚Ä¢ Reasonable punishment defense undermines child protection and can lead to more serious abuse
‚Ä¢ Greater clarity is needed in the definition of corporal punishment

column1: ‚Ä¢ The group emphasized the importance of awareness raising and support for parents if the law changes

column2: ‚Ä¢ Local authorities have been working with the Welsh Government on implementation plans
‚Ä¢ Additional resources will be needed to support prevention and early intervention services for families
‚Ä¢ Schools will play a key role in discussing the issues with children and supporting families
‚Ä¢ Some unintended positive consequences could be increased focus on children's rights and their voices

column1: ‚Ä¢ The group does not anticipate a major impact on social services' capacity to implement the law

column2: ‚Ä¢ Thresholds for intervention are not expected to change significantly
‚Ä¢ Most referrals will likely require no action after initial assessment
‚Ä¢ Prevention and support services will be offered to families when concerns are identified
‚Ä¢ Emergency and out-of-hours services have been considered as part of implementation planning

column1: ‚Ä¢ The group is confident that education professionals will be clear on their duties to report suspected harm

column2: ‚Ä¢ Existing training and guidance for safeguarding will be updated
‚Ä¢ The duty to report will remain paramount, with social services determining thresholds
‚Ä¢ Trust between professionals and families is important and consent is sought for most referrals
‚Ä¢ Family support officers in schools are critical in engaging with families

column1: ‚Ä¢ The group believes clearly communicating that the law is not meant to criminalize parents is crucial

column2: ‚Ä¢ A broad awareness campaign using various avenues will be needed
‚Ä¢ The numbers of parents prosecuted is expected to be very small
‚Ä¢ Placing a duty on ministers to raise awareness, as in Scotland, should be considered
‚Ä¢ The Welsh Government has committed to an awareness campaign if the law passes

column1: ‚Ä¢ The group argues that the costs of implementing the law are justified to protect children's rights

column2: ‚Ä¢ Costs will be spread across training, awareness, and some potential increase in referrals
‚Ä¢ Much of the training aligns with existing programs on child protection and adverse childhood experiences",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column1: 961,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ The Children, Young People and Education Committee heard evidence on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill from:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Representatives of the Association of Directors of Social Services, Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Welsh Local Government Association

column1: ‚Ä¢ The representatives expressed general support for the Bill, saying it would bring needed clarity and reflect a cultural shift in Wales on physical punishment of children
‚Ä¢ On the impact on social services, the representatives said:

column2: ‚Ä¢ They do not expect a large increase in referrals, and each case would be assessed proportionately

column1: ‚Ä¢ On the impact on education, the representatives said:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Training and awareness for education professionals would be key, but their duty to report safeguarding concerns would remain the same

column1: ‚Ä¢ The representatives emphasized the importance of an awareness campaign to avoid criminalizing parents, possibly making this a duty in the legislation
‚Ä¢ Regarding costs and resources, the representatives:

column2: ‚Ä¢ Felt the Bill was worthwhile despite pressures on social services, and that additional costs could be managed

column1: ‚Ä¢ The Committee also discussed trying to forecast and identify any unknown costs in the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
962,"Here is the summary with the requested formatting:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Alastair Birch expressed confidence that teachers and education professionals would be clear on how to support the implementation of the Bill, noting that:

column2: ‚Ä¢ The universal tier 1 safeguarding training emphasizes the duty to report concerns
‚Ä¢ More specialist safeguarding leads in schools are highly skilled in understanding when referrals need to be made based on significant harm
‚Ä¢ As long as there is clarity that the duty to report remains, and additional training is provided as needed, education professionals will be prepared

column1: ‚Ä¢ Birch also noted some potential positive consequences of the Bill for education, such as:

column2: ‚Ä¢ An increased focus on the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child
‚Ä¢ More discussions with children around the issues that affect them, as the voice of the child is fundamental in education
‚Ä¢ Reinvigorating the voice of the child in various educational contexts

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
963,"Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The committee discussed the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill with representatives from local authorities

column2: * They support the Bill as it upholds children's rights and brings clarity for children, parents and professionals
* Physical punishment is harmful to children and the current law is unclear
* Legislation should reflect societal changes in attitudes towards physical punishment

column1: * Implementing the Bill will require awareness raising and support for parents

column2: * Local authorities have been working with the Welsh Government on the Bill
* They want to avoid criminalizing parents and take a proportionate response to any reports
* Existing preventative and support services for families need more investment

column1: * The impact on social services is expected to be limited as physical punishment is rare

column2: * Short-term increases in reports are anticipated but numbers should settle
* Social services already get many police referrals they take no action on
* Assessment processes are in place to determine appropriate responses

column1: * Education professionals will need clear training and guidance on their reporting duties

column2: * The duty to report significant harm will remain the same
* Schools play a key role in supporting families and building trust
* Guidance like ""Keeping learners safe"" may need updating

column1: * Putting a duty for Ministers to promote awareness on the face of the Bill was suggested

column2: * This could provide clarity on who is responsible for awareness raising
* The Welsh Government has committed to an awareness campaign regardless
* Funding for the awareness campaign needs to be clear

column1: * Work is underway to estimate the costs of implementing the Bill

column2: * Additional costs for training, awareness and potential referrals are expected
* These costs need to be fully met so as not to impact existing services
* Some costs like awareness campaigns are easier to predict than others

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

967,"Here is a summary of the meeting discussion using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Discussed agenda items including NSF ITR proposal, digits, and naming conventions

column2: * Professor A provided an update on the NSF ITR pre-proposal
* Grad B discussed issues with digits that were misread and how to handle them
* Grad B brought up naming conventions for sound files to make sorting easier

column1: * Discussed progress on transcriptions and challenges encountered

column2: * Postdoc F switched to doing channel-by-channel transcriptions
* Discovered issues like time lags and overlooked backchannels during dense overlaps
* Considering having transcribers focus on single channels and piecing together later

column1: * PhD C provided an update on his work with harmonicity detection

column2: * Trying to improve the harmonicity detector and distinguish between harmonic and non-harmonic frequency peaks
* Discussed different approaches like using energy ratios and instantaneous frequency
* Plans to prepare results and have further discussions to understand the issues

column1: * Discussed the NSF ITR proposal and its potential impact on ICSI

column2: * If awarded, it would extend research beyond current Meeting Recorder work to higher-level issues
* Would require hiring new students and expanding the team at ICSI and UW
* Proposal is due in about a month, with a lot of the work being done by others besides Professor A

column1: * Discussed how to handle breaths in the transcriptions

column2: * Question raised about whether breaths are needed for speech recognition research
* Argument made to keep breaths as they are part of real speech data
* Considered ways to more efficiently annotate breaths, such as using a breath detector

column1: * Discussed the contrast between needs for speech recognition vs. discourse research

column2: * Discourse research focuses on what is communicative, while speech recognition needs to handle all real phenomena
* Plan to have a master transcript with everything, and scripts to extract subsets for different uses
* Looking for ways to efficiently annotate breaths, such as only within transcribed segments

981,"Here is a summary of the discussion between the user interface designer and project manager about the trigger button:
<summary>
* The user interface designer noted there is no button where the user's finger naturally rests on the remote, which feels like there should be a button there
* However, they couldn't decide what function was important enough to put a button there
* They didn't want to accidentally hit the power button in that location
* So they left that area of the remote blank in the current design
* They may tweak this in a final design phase
* The project manager suggested combining a trigger button with the scroll wheel
* This would prevent the scroll wheel from rotating if the remote lands on that side
* It would require hitting the trigger and scroll wheel simultaneously to scroll
* This provides options for different models based on that design
* But the scroll wheel came off the prototype, revealing a potential issue with it not being secured well
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

989,"Here is a summary of the key points from the meeting:
<summary>
* The group discussed results from testing their speech recognition system on the Aurora dataset in different languages and noise conditions

column2: * The system showed improvements of 30-60% error rate reduction compared to the baseline
* However, even with these improvements, the error rates are still too high (8-9% per digit) for practical use in real applications

column1: * They compared their results to other top performing systems and discussed ideas for further improving performance

column2: * Combining the best aspects of different systems, such as spectral subtraction, cepstral normalization, and the group's modulation filtering, could yield even better results
* More analysis is needed to understand the sources of errors, such as confusion between phoneme classes in noisy conditions

column1: * The group brainstormed additional experiments and directions to explore going forward

column2: * Taking a closer look at the realistic noise conditions in the Aurora and in-house datasets
* Revisiting ideas that didn't work well initially, such as articulatory features, MSG, and multi-band processing
* Training multiple neural networks on data from different acoustic conditions or languages

991,"Here is a summary of the discussion about the functions for the new remote control:
<summary>
* The remote control is for a specific television, not an all-in-one device
* Teletext should be excluded because it is outdated
* The remote should have a limited number of buttons and a simple design
* 50% of users only use 10% of the buttons on current remotes
* Speech recognition is a desired feature, especially for users aged 15-35
* There are concerns about noise interference and cost of implementation
* The remote should be easy to locate if lost
* Ideas include a glow-in-the-dark feature or a ""remote finder"" activated by a separate device by the TV
* An LCD/TFT screen interface was considered but ultimately rejected
* Concerns about cost, fragility, and fitting it into an organic design
* The remote should have an organic, ergonomic design made of durable material
* A large foam ball design with no external buttons was jokingly suggested
* The company color (yellow) and slogan should be incorporated into the design
* But not to an excessive degree (e.g. all yellow)
* Additional considerations include programmable buttons, child safety, and overall fashion/trendiness
* The marketing expert emphasized the importance of an attractive design
</summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
992,"Here is a summary of the key points from the discussion, with 9 main bullet points and 2 sub-points for each:
<summary>
* The team discussed market research findings about consumer preferences for remote controls

column2: * 75% of users find current remote controls ugly, and 80% are willing to pay more for better-looking remotes
* 50% of users only use 10% of the buttons, so the design should focus on key functions rather than many buttons

column1: * Speech recognition was considered as a novel feature to differentiate the product

column2: * Younger age groups (15-35 years old) showed strong interest in speech recognition
* However, there are technical challenges in making speech recognition work reliably with background noise interference

column1: * The industrial designer presented some initial design concepts

column2: * One concept combined features from the company's previous products like spacecraft, coffee makers, and bullet trains
* A more realistic design would use a cheap plastic casing, standard batteries, and a simple user interface

column1: * The team decided on the key features to include in the remote control

column2: * Speech recognition for key functions, despite the technical challenges
* A limited number of physical buttons and a simple, easy-to-use interface

column1: * Programmable options were suggested to allow users to set favorite channels and volume

column2: * This would require a small amount of non-volatile memory to be included
* An option to locate a lost remote by sending a signal from the TV was also proposed

column1: * Using a TFT/LCD screen was considered but rejected due to cost and fragility concerns

column2: * Speech recognition was deemed cheaper to implement than an LCD screen
* There were concerns an LCD screen could get damaged with the abuse remote controls face

column1: * The remote control will have an organic, curved shape for better ergonomics

column2: * Rubber or flesh-like materials were suggested to make it more durable and differentiated

column2: * The team wants to avoid an all-yellow color scheme, so only accents of yellow will be used
* The logo and slogan will be prominently featured, possibly surrounded by a yellow strip

column1: * Next steps are for team members to share their reports and continue gathering information

column1: 993,"Here is a summary of the discussion about schools causing concern with questions from Irranca-Davies:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Identifying schools needing support is done through the school categorisation system and Estyn inspections

column2: ‚Ä¢ Categorisation is used to triage where resources should be focused, not for accountability
‚Ä¢ Estyn inspections hold schools accountable but only happen every 7 years

column1: ‚Ä¢ 11% of secondary schools inspected in last 2 years were judged as unsatisfactory

column2: ‚Ä¢ This is too high and these schools are not being identified early enough
‚Ä¢ A new multi-agency approach is being piloted to provide more support to schools causing concern

column1: ‚Ä¢ The multi-agency approach involves the school, local authority, regional consortia, Estyn and Welsh Government

column2: ‚Ä¢ It looks at fundamentals needing addressing, school capacity, and what sustainable improvement looks like
‚Ä¢ Initial feedback on the pilot is very positive

column1: ‚Ä¢ Local authorities have powers to intervene in schools causing concern but there is variation in how these are used

column2: ‚Ä¢ The Minister expects local authorities to be proactive in intervening when needed
‚Ä¢ She would want to see Neath Port Talbot's plans for school improvement if they withdraw from their regional consortium

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"

column2: ‚Ä¢ A new multi-agency approach is being piloted to provide more support to schools causing concern and move them forward more quickly

column2: ‚Ä¢ Erica and Jack defend Lily and say Ethan lied
‚Ä¢ An upset Kendall leaves, refusing to believe Ethan deceived her

column1: ‚Ä¢ Zach asks Livia to get him released on bail so he can protect Lily

column2: ‚Ä¢ Ethan makes plans to go after Erica for not supporting his relationship with Kendall
‚Ä¢ Greenlee leaves a loving voicemail for Ryan, unaware of the danger

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
1025,"Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Annie insists Tori is real but Aidan believes Annie imagined her as a friend to help remember things

column2: ‚Ä¢ Annie gets very upset and has to be sedated

column1: ‚Ä¢ Adam returns to Pine Valley after crashing his car and is hiding out at Erica's place

column2: ‚Ä¢ J.R. and Tad find him there; Adam doesn't want people knowing about his health issues

column1: ‚Ä¢ Little Ian undergoes heart surgery performed by David

column2: ‚Ä¢ The surgery goes well but the next 24 hours are crucial

column1: ‚Ä¢ Kendall and Zach wait at the hospital, reflecting on their relationship troubles

column2: ‚Ä¢ Reese shows up, causing some tension with Kendall and Ryan

column1: ‚Ä¢ Krystal tells David that Adam's crashed car was found; David wants Adam arrested

column2: ‚Ä¢ Tad tries to convince Jesse to drop the kidnapping charges against Adam

column1: ‚Ä¢ Aidan reveals to Annie that a girl named Tori went missing from Annie's hometown when Annie was 7

column2: ‚Ä¢ Annie remembers that Tori was her friend and believes she killed her

column1: ‚Ä¢ Adam assures J.R. he is fine and wants to save Chandler Enterprises and take down David

column2: ‚Ä¢ Adam still believes in Erica's business abilities with Fusion

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
1026,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Jesse and Angie celebrate their vows in a hotel honeymoon suite

column2: ‚Ä¢ Their romantic evening is interrupted by a fire and being seen naked by wedding guests next door

column1: ‚Ä¢ Erica and Carmen confront Armando and his mother Louisa about the bank robbery Armando committed

column2: ‚Ä¢ Erica offers them the opportunity to star in her new reality TV show in exchange for confessing

column1: ‚Ä¢ Jack and Zach review security camera footage of Erica and Carmen at a store

column2: ‚Ä¢ They deduce Erica is giving Carmen a makeover and flirting lessons to get Armando to confess

column1: ‚Ä¢ Greenlee realizes she is trying to fix Ryan and his memory loss for her own reasons

column2: ‚Ä¢ She decides she should go back home to Aidan instead of staying with Ryan

column1: ‚Ä¢ Aidan drunkenly almost reveals to Annie that he slept with Kendall

column2: ‚Ä¢ Kendall covers for him but Annie remains suspicious

column1: ‚Ä¢ Annie meets with a lawyer to draw up divorce papers for her and Ryan

column2: ‚Ä¢ The lawyer cautions Annie about giving up on Ryan too soon

column1: ‚Ä¢ Kendall assures Aidan that he didn't ruin things between her and Zach

column2: ‚Ä¢ Zach calls to update Kendall that they may know where Erica is

column1: ‚Ä¢ Louisa begins confessing details about her and Armando's crimes to Erica

column2: ‚Ä¢ Something strange suddenly happens during the confession

column1: ‚Ä¢ Jesse and Angie leave the eventful hotel suite, ready to go home together

column2: ‚Ä¢ They laugh about their unforgettable night

column1: ‚Ä¢ As Greenlee is leaving, Ryan stops her to tell her Aidan is lucky to have her

column2: ‚Ä¢ Greenlee wonders if Ryan is really okay

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '‚Ä¢'}"
1027,"Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
‚Ä¢ Ryan and Annie discuss ending their marriage, but Ryan asks for more time

column2: ‚Ä¢ Annie tears up the divorce papers, hoping to save their relationship
‚Ä¢ Ryan feels trapped by the unknown and wants something to hope for
‚Ä¢ Annie leaves, trying not to cry, to go home to their daughter Emma

column1: ‚Ä¢ Greenlee asks Zach to help her win back Aidan, the love of her life

column2: ‚Ä¢ Zach questions if Greenlee would truly forgive Aidan for anything
‚Ä¢ Greenlee insists she has moved on from Ryan and wants to be with Aidan
‚Ä¢ Zach agrees to help keep Greenlee and Aidan together

column1: ‚Ä¢ Jesse tells Jenny Jr. stories about her namesake, his dear friend Jenny

column2: ‚Ä¢ Jenny was Jesse's best friend who supported him despite prejudice
‚Ä¢ Jesse and Jenny ran away to New York City one summer
‚Ä¢ Jenny passed away too young, but her love and memory live on

column1: ‚Ä¢ Erica and Carmen discuss their chances of getting out of prison

column2: ‚Ä¢ Carmen believes their different backgrounds determine their fates
‚Ä¢ Erica vows to use her celebrity status to help free Carmen
‚Ä¢ Kendall visits Erica, worried about her ordeal with Carmen

column1: ‚Ä¢ Tad, Krystal, and others celebrate Jenny Jr.'s birthday

column2: ‚Ä¢ Colby brings many gifts, including a special birthday outfit
‚Ä¢ Jesse and Angie, newly remarried, arrive with presents
‚Ä¢ Tad introduces Jenny Jr. to her ""Uncle"" Jesse

column1: ‚Ä¢ Jack updates Erica and Carmen on their legal situation

column2: ‚Ä¢ Jack files motions and works with the DA, but has little hope
‚Ä¢ Erica refuses to give up and believes in fighting for justice
‚Ä¢ Carmen thanks Jack for his efforts, calling him ""Jackie""

column1: ‚Ä¢ Greenlee and Zach discuss her feelings for Aidan at ConFusion

column2: ‚Ä¢ Greenlee admits a part of her will always love Ryan
‚Ä¢ She insists Aidan is the one she truly wants and needs now
‚Ä¢ Zach eventually agrees to support Greenlee's pursuit of Aidan

column1: ‚Ä¢ Jesse gives a heartfelt speech at Jenny's memorial service
